content.text: 11.6	Expenses and Costs.
content.caption: Expenses and Costs.

content.text: 11.6.1	Leasing Costs, Security Deposits and Prepaid Rents.  Leasing Costs shall be allocated as provided in Section 7.3, and security deposits and prepaid rents shall be credited as set forth in Section 7.4.
content.caption: Leasing Costs, Security Deposits and Prepaid Rents.

section_hierarchy.caption: Leasing Costs, Security Deposits and Prepaid Rents.

content.text: 11.6.2	Seller Closing Costs.  Seller shall pay: (a) 50% of the Escrow Agent’s escrow fee; (b) the premium for the standard coverage portion of the premium for the Title Policy and any related sales tax; (c) those commissions, if any, payable by Seller pursuant to Section 1.14; and (d) any additional costs and charges customarily charged to sellers in accordance with common escrow practices in the state and county in which the Property is located.
content.caption: Seller Closing Costs.

content.text: 11.6.3	Purchaser Closing Costs.  Purchaser shall pay: (a) 50% of the Escrow Agent’s escrow fee; (b) the premium for the extended coverage portion of the premium for the Title Policy and the costs of any endorsements Purchaser may require and any related sales tax; (c) the cost of recording the Deed; (d) those commissions, if any, payable by Purchaser pursuant to Section 1.14; and (e) any additional costs and charges customarily charged to purchasers in accordance with common escrow practices in the state and county in which the Property is located.  In addition to the foregoing, Purchaser shall be solely responsible for any costs incurred in connection with Purchaser’s Due Diligence investigations of the Property, including Inspections and Surveys.
content.caption: Purchaser Closing Costs.

content.text: 11.6.4	Other Expenses and Legal Costs.  Except as provided above, each party hereto shall pay its own expenses incurred in connection with this Agreement and the transactions contemplated hereby, including in the case of Purchaser, all third-party engineering and environmental review costs incurred by or on behalf of Purchaser, its inspection costs and Due Diligence costs.  Each party shall pay for the costs of their respective counsel in connection with Closing and this transaction.
content.caption: Other Expenses and Legal Costs.

content.text: 11.7	Prorations.
content.caption: Prorations.

content.text: 11.7.1	Proration Items.  Seller and Purchaser agree to adjust, as of 11:59 pm Pacific Time on the day immediately preceding the Closing Date, all revenue and expenses relating to the Property (“Proration Items”), including the following:  (a) real estate taxes and assessments (including any adjustments to real estate taxes and assessments and refunds of any payments thereof that are made following the Closing but relate to periods of time prior to Closing, which obligation will survive the Closing); (b) expenses already incurred by Seller that relate to services to be provided to the Property after the Closing Date and all fees and charges under the Assumed Contracts; and (c) all rentals and other income collected from the Property (including operating costs and other tenant reimbursements).  Seller will be charged and credited for the amounts of all of the Proration Items relating to the period up to and including 11:59 pm Pacific Time on the day immediately preceding the Closing Date, and Purchaser will be charged and credited for all of the Proration Items relating to the period on and after the Closing Date.
content.caption: Proration Items.

content.text: 11.7.2	Method of Proration.  For purposes of calculating prorations, Purchaser shall be deemed to hold title to the Property and be entitled to the income therefrom and responsible for the expenses thereof for the entire day upon which the Closing occurs.  All such prorations shall be made on the basis of the actual number of days of the month that shall have elapsed as of the day of the Closing and based upon the actual number of days in the month and a 365 day year.
content.caption: Method of Proration.

content.text: 11.7.3	Items Not Prorated.  Seller and Purchaser agree that: (a) none of the insurance policies relating to the Property will be assigned to Purchaser and Purchaser shall be responsible for arranging for its own insurance as of the Closing Date; (b) utilities, including telephone, electricity, water and gas, shall be read on the Closing Date, and Purchaser shall be responsible for all the necessary actions needed to arrange for meters to be read and utilities to be changed to the name of Purchaser on the Closing Date, including the posting of any required deposits; provided, however, that Seller shall be entitled to a credit at the Closing for any utility deposits which it or its predecessors have made prior to the Closing Date, to the extent the same are transferred to Purchaser.  Seller shall be entitled to recover and retain from the providers of such utilities any refunds or overpayments to the extent applicable to the period prior to the Closing Date, and any utility deposits for which it does not receive a credit hereunder.  If accounts are not set up in Purchaser’s name on the Closing Date, all charges for such utilities shall be prorated outside of escrow within 60 days after the Closing Date.
content.caption: Items Not Prorated.

content.text: 11.8	Closing Statement.  The estimated Closing costs, allocations and prorations shall be set forth on a preliminary closing statement to be prepared by the Escrow Agent and submitted to the parties for their reasonable approval at least 5 Business Days prior to the Closing Date.  The parties shall then use reasonable, diligent and good faith efforts to agree upon the final closing statement that is consistent with the terms of this Agreement at least 2 Business Days prior to the Closing Date (“Closing Statement”).  If, despite using reasonable, diligent and good faith efforts, the parties are unable to reach agreement on the Closing Statement at least 2 Business Days prior to the Closing Date, either party by written notice to the other party may elect to extend the Closing Date to such date that is 2 Business Days after the date on which the parties reach agreement upon the Closing Statement.
content.caption: Closing Statement.

content.text: 11.9	Reconciliation.  Any item which cannot be finally allocated or prorated because of the unavailability of information shall be tentatively prorated on the basis of the best data then available and adjusted when the information is available.  Such allocations or prorations shall be initially performed by Seller and Purchaser pursuant to the Closing Statement, but shall be subject to adjustment in cash after the Closing outside of escrow as and when complete and accurate information becomes available, if such information is not available at the Closing.  If the allocations and prorations made under the Closing Statement shall prove to be incorrect or incomplete for any reason, then either party shall be entitled to an adjustment to correct the same; provided, however, that any adjustment shall be made, if at all, within 90 days after the Closing Date, and if a party fails to request an adjustment to the Closing Statement by a written notice delivered to the other party within the applicable period set forth above (such notice to specify in reasonable detail the items within the Closing Statement that such party desires to adjust and the reasons for such adjustment), then the allocations and prorations set forth in the Closing Statement shall be binding and conclusive against such party.  Until final reconciliation under this Section, Purchaser and its representatives and auditors shall be afforded reasonable access during normal business hours to Seller’s books and records with respect to the Property to confirm the accuracy of the Closing Statement.
content.caption: Reconciliation.

content.text: 11.10	Escrow Agent.  Escrow Agent executes this Agreement solely to evidence its agreement to hold escrowed funds in accordance with the terms and conditions of this Agreement.  The following provisions shall control with respect to the rights, duties and liabilities of Escrow Agent.  Escrow Agent acts hereunder as a depository only and is not responsible or liable in any manner whatsoever for the (a) sufficiency, correctness, genuineness or validity of any written instrument, notice or evidence of a party’s receipt of any instruction or notice which is received by Escrow Agent, or (b) identity or authority of any person executing such instruction notice or evidence.  Escrow Agent shall have no responsibility hereunder except for the performance by it in good faith of the acts to be performed by it hereunder, and Escrow Agent shall have no liability except for its own willful misconduct or gross negligence.  If a dispute arises between the parties with respect to the disposition of the Earnest Money Deposit or any other amounts held in escrow, Escrow Agent shall be entitled, at its own discretion, to deliver such amount to an appropriate court of law pending resolution of the dispute.  Escrow Agent shall invest the amount in escrow in accounts which are federally insured, which invest solely in government securities, or which are reasonably satisfactory to Seller and Purchaser, and shall be applied in accordance with the terms of this Agreement.
content.caption: Escrow Agent.

content.text: 11.11	Escrow Instructions. Upon execution of this Agreement, the parties shall deposit an executed counterpart of this Agreement with the Escrow Agent, and this Agreement shall serve as escrow instructions to the Escrow Agent for consummation of the purchase and sale contemplated hereby.  Seller and Purchaser agree to execute such reasonable additional and supplementary escrow instructions as may be appropriate to enable the Escrow Agent to comply with the terms of this Agreement; provided, however, that if there is any conflict between the provisions of this Agreement and any such supplementary escrow instructions, the terms of this Agreement shall control.
content.caption: Escrow Instructions.

content.text: 11.12	Designation of Reporting Person.  To assure compliance with the requirements of Section 6045(e) of the Code, the parties hereto agree as follows:
content.caption: Designation of Reporting Person.

content.text: 11.12.1	Reporting.  Provided that Escrow Agent executes a counterpart of this Agreement to evidence Escrow Agent’s agreement to assume all responsibilities for information reporting required under Section 6045(e) of the Code, Seller and Purchaser shall designate the Escrow Agent as the person responsible for all information reporting under Section 6045(e) of the Code (“Reporting Person”).  If Escrow Agent refuses to execute a counterpart of this Agreement pursuant to which it agrees to be the Reporting Person, Seller and Purchaser shall agree to appoint another third party as the Reporting Person.
content.caption: Reporting.

content.text: 11.12.2	Reporting Requirements.  Seller and Purchaser shall each (a) provide to the Reporting Person all information and certifications regarding such party, as reasonably requested by the Reporting Person or otherwise required to be provided by a party to the transaction described herein under Section 6045 of the Code; (b) provide to the Reporting Person such party’s taxpayer identification number and a statement (on Internal Revenue Service Form W-9 or an acceptable substitute form, or on any other form the applicable current or future Code sections and regulations might require and/or any form requested by the Reporting Person), signed under penalty of perjury, stating that the taxpayer identification number supplied by such party to the Reporting Person is correct; and (c) retain this Agreement for not less than 4 years from the end of the calendar year in which the Closing occurred, and to produce it to the Internal Revenue Service upon a valid request therefor.
content.caption: Reporting Requirements.

content.text: 12.	CAsualty and Condemnation
content.caption: CAsualty and Condemnation

content.text: 12.1	Minor Loss/Condemnation. Purchaser shall be bound to purchase the Property for the full Purchase Price as required by the terms hereof, without regard to the occurrence or effect of any damage to the Property or condemnation of any portion of the Property, provided that: (a) the insured cost to repair any such damage or destruction, or the diminution in the value of the remaining Property as a result of a partial condemnation, equals $1,000,000 or less, (b) any such condemnation does not impair access to the Property, and (c) upon the Closing, there shall be a credit against the Purchase Price due hereunder equal to the amount of any insurance proceeds or condemnation awards collected by Seller prior to Closing as a result of any such damage or destruction or condemnation, plus the amount of any insurance deductible not recoverable under the Leases, less any sums expended by Seller toward the restoration or repair of the Property, including barricades and other temporary repairs required for safety purposes, or in collecting such insurance proceeds or condemnation awards.  If the proceeds or awards have not been collected as of the Closing, then no credit shall be given but such proceeds or awards shall be assigned to Purchaser, except to the extent needed to reimburse Seller for sums expended prior to the Closing to repair or restore the Property or to collect any such proceeds or awards.
content.caption: Minor Loss/Condemnation.

content.text: 12.2	Major Loss/Condemnation. If the amount of the damage or destruction or condemnation as specified above exceeds $1,000,000 or such damage or destruction is not covered by insurance maintained by Seller or any condemnation impairs access to the Property, then Purchaser may at its option, to be exercised by written notice to Seller within 10 Business Days after Seller’s notice to Purchaser of the occurrence of the damage or destruction or the commencement of condemnation proceedings, terminate this Agreement or proceed with the purchase and sale transaction in accordance with the terms of this Agreement.  If Purchaser does not elect to terminate this Agreement within such 10 Business Day period, Purchaser shall be deemed to have elected to proceed with the purchase in accordance with this Agreement and to have waived its right to terminate.  If Purchaser elects to terminate this Agreement within such 10 Business Day period, the Earnest Money Deposit shall be returned to Purchaser and neither party shall have any further rights or obligations hereunder except for those obligations expressly stated to survive termination.  If Purchaser elects to proceed with the purchase, Seller shall not be obligated to repair any damage or destruction and upon the Closing, there shall be a credit against the Purchase Price due hereunder equal to the amount of any uninsured loss, insurance proceeds or condemnation awards collected by Seller before Closing as a result of any such damage or destruction or condemnation, plus the amount of any insurance deductible not recoverable under the Leases, less any sums expended by Seller toward the restoration or repair of the Property, including barricades and other temporary repairs required for safety purposes, or in collecting such insurance proceeds or condemnation awards.  If the proceeds or awards have not been collected as of the Closing, then such proceeds or awards shall be assigned to Purchaser, except to the extent needed to reimburse Seller for sums expended prior to the Closing to repair or restore the Property, including barricades and other temporary repairs required for safety purposes, or to collect any such proceeds or awards.
content.caption: Major Loss/Condemnation.

content.text: 13.	DEFAULT AND REMEDIES
content.caption: DEFAULT AND REMEDIES

content.text: 13.1	Seller Default.  If the sale of the Property is not consummated due to a default by Seller which is not cured within 5 Business Days after notice from Purchaser (with the Closing Date extended as may be necessary to accommodate such cure period), then Purchaser shall be entitled, as its sole remedy, to either (a) enforce specific performance of this Agreement and to recover from Seller any reasonable out-of-pocket costs incurred by Purchaser in connection with such enforcement action; provided, the remedy for specific performance shall only be available if Purchaser commences the action for specific performance within 60 days after first becoming aware of Seller’s material default, or (b) terminate this Agreement and receive back the Earnest Money Deposit.  Except as expressly provided in this Section, Purchaser shall have no other remedy for any default by Seller under this Agreement.
content.caption: Seller Default.

content.text: 13.2	Purchaser Default; Liquidated Damages.  If the sale of the Property is not consummated due to a default by Purchaser which is not cured within 5 Business Days after notice from Seller (with the Closing Date extended as may be necessary to accommodate such cure period), then Seller shall be entitled, as its sole remedy, to retain the Earnest Money Deposit as liquidated damages, this Agreement shall terminate and such termination shall release Purchaser from any and all liability hereunder, except for those obligations of Purchaser that expressly survive termination of this Agreement.  THE PARTIES HAVE AGREED THAT SELLER’S ACTUAL DAMAGES, IN THE EVENT OF A FAILURE TO CONSUMMATE THIS SALE WHEN LEGALLY OBLIGATED TO DO SO WOULD BE EXTREMELY DIFFICULT OR IMPRACTICABLE TO DETERMINE.  AFTER NEGOTIATION, THE PARTIES HAVE AGREED THAT, CONSIDERING ALL THE CIRCUMSTANCES EXISTING ON THE EFFECTIVE DATE OF THIS AGREEMENT, THE AMOUNT OF THE EARNEST MONEY DEPOSIT IS A REASONABLE ESTIMATE OF THE DAMAGES THAT SELLER WOULD INCUR IN SUCH EVENT, AND SELLER WAIVES ITS RIGHT TO RECOVER DAMAGES OR SEEK SPECIFIC PERFORMANCE AGAINST PURCHASER.  EACH PARTY CONFIRMS THE ACCURACY OF THE STATEMENTS MADE ABOVE AND THE FACT THAT EACH PARTY WAS REPRESENTED BY COUNSEL WHO EXPLAINED, AT THE TIME THIS AGREEMENT WAS MADE, THE CONSEQUENCES OF THIS LIQUIDATED DAMAGES PROVISION.
content.caption: Purchaser Default; Liquidated Damages.

content.text: 14.	CONFIDENTIALITY
content.caption: CONFIDENTIALITY

content.text: 14.1	Definition of Confidential Information.  As used herein, “Confidential Information” shall mean the non-public, confidential information related to (a) Seller’s operations and businesses, which may include leases, rent rolls, operating budgets, net operating income figures and capital expenditure summaries, (b) the existence or pendency of this transaction, (c) the material economic terms of this transaction, and (d) any other information or materials shared by the other party of its Affiliates and/or their agents related to this transaction, whether shared before or after the Effective Date, that either a party or its agents has expressly designated as confidential or would otherwise be reasonably considered to be confidential.  Notwithstanding the foregoing, in no event shall the following be considered Confidential Information: (w) any information that becomes publicly available without breach of this Agreement; (x) any information that can be shown by documentation to have been previously known to a party and/or its Affiliates at the time of its disclosure or delivery by the other party, its Affiliates and/or their agents; (y) any information rightfully received by a party and/or its Affiliates or from a third party who did not acquire or disclose such information by a wrongful or tortious act; and (z) any information that a party can demonstrate was independently developed by such party and/or its Affiliates without use of or reference to any Confidential Information.
content.caption: Definition of Confidential Information.

content.text: 14.2	Non-Disclosure of Confidential Information.  Each party shall treat the Confidential Information with the same degree of care and confidentiality that such party exercises in protecting and preserving its own confidential information and shall use reasonable and good faith efforts to avoid and prevent the disclosure of the Confidential Information to third parties; except that (a) each party may disclose the Confidential Information if so compelled by judicial or other governmental order, provided the disclosing party shall give the other party reasonable opportunity to seek a protective order or equivalent, or obtain written assurance from the applicable judicial or governmental entity that it will afford the Confidential Information the highest level of protection afforded under applicable law or regulation, (b) each party may disclose the Confidential Information to those third parties integral to the transactions contemplated under this Agreement such as Escrow Agent, Title Company and Tenants where such disclosure either falls expressly or implicitly with the scope of the transactions and other actions contemplated under this Agreement, but only to the extent such disclosure is necessary or appropriate to carry out such contemplated transactions or actions, and (c) each party may disclose the Confidential Information to existing or potential investors, joint venture partners or lenders, as well as to the officers, employees, attorneys, advisors, consultants or Affiliates of Seller or Purchaser, as the case may be, or of any of the foregoing parties (collectively, “Permitted Recipients”); provided that the disclosing party first makes those Permitted Recipients aware of the confidential nature of the Confidential Information and such Permitted Recipients acknowledge their responsibility to preserve the confidentiality of the Confidential Information.
content.caption: Non-Disclosure of Confidential Information.

content.text: 14.4	Survival of Non-Disclosure Obligations.  The parties’ obligations under this Section 14 shall terminate if and when Closing occurs and otherwise shall survive any earlier termination of this Agreement for 12 months.
content.caption: Survival of Non-Disclosure Obligations.

content.text: 14.5	Effect on Prior NDA.  To the extent Seller and Purchaser and/or their Affiliates previously executed a confidentiality agreement, non-disclosure agreement or similar agreement with respect to the Property (“Prior NDA”), the Prior NDA is hereby deemed superseded, replaced and terminated by this Agreement and the materials and other information that were subject to the Prior NDA shall be deemed governed by this Section 14.
content.caption: Effect on Prior NDA.

content.text: 15.	Responsibility for Broker Commissions
content.caption: Responsibility for Broker Commissions

content.text: Each of Purchaser and Seller represents and warrants to the other that it did not employ or use any broker or finder to arrange or bring about this transaction, except for Seller’s Broker and Purchaser’s Broker (if any are identified in Section 1.11 or 1.12 above)  and that there are no claims or rights for brokerage commissions or finder’s fees in connection with the transactions contemplated by this Agreement or arising out of actions or statements by the representing party except to the extent otherwise provided in this Section 15.  If any person brings a claim against Seller for a commission or finder’s fee based upon any contact, dealings or communication with Purchaser in connection with the transactions contemplated by this Agreement for which Seller is not expressly responsible under Section 1.14, then Purchaser shall defend Seller from such claim, and shall indemnify Seller and hold Seller harmless from any and all costs, damages, claims, liabilities or expenses (including reasonable attorneys’ fees and disbursements) incurred by Seller with respect to the claim.  If any person brings a claim against Purchaser for a commission or finder’s fee based upon any contact, dealings or communication with Seller in connection with the transactions contemplated by this Agreement for which Purchaser is not expressly responsible under Section 1.14, then Seller shall defend Purchaser from such claim, and shall indemnify Purchaser and hold Purchaser harmless from any and all costs, damages, claims, liabilities or expenses (including reasonable attorneys’ fees and disbursements) incurred by Purchaser with respect to the claim.
content.caption: Each of Purchaser and Seller represents and warrants to the...

content.text: 16.2	Time.  Time is of the essence in the performance of all obligations under this Agreement.  “Business Day” means any day other than a Saturday, a Sunday, or any day that is recognized as a holiday in Washington State or in the state in which the Property is located.  Unless this Agreement expressly refers to “Business Days”, all references in this Agreement to days shall be deemed to mean calendar days.  The time periods under this Agreement shall be computed by excluding the first day and including the last day, but, if the last day falls on a calendar day that is not a Business Day, or if the computed date for Closing or any other event that requires recording of documents falls on a day on which the applicable county recording office is closed, then the time period or date in question shall extend to the next Business Day.
content.caption: Time.

content.text: 16.3	US Dollars.  All monetary amounts set forth in this Agreement are in US Dollars.
content.caption: US Dollars.

content.text: 16.4	Definition of Affiliate.  As used herein, “Affiliate” means any person or entity that directly, or indirectly through one or more intermediaries, controls, is controlled by or is under common control with a person or entity, as the case may be.  For the purposes of this definition, “control” and “controlled” mean the possession, direct or indirect, of the power to direct or cause the direction of the management and policies of a person or entity, whether through the ownership of voting securities, by contract or otherwise.
content.caption: Definition of Affiliate.

content.text: 16.5	Successors and Assigns. This Agreement will be binding upon and inure to the benefit of Seller and Purchaser and their respective permitted successors and assigns, and no other party will be conferred any rights by virtue of this Agreement or be entitled to enforce any of the provisions hereof.  Whenever a reference is made in this Agreement to Seller or Purchaser, such reference will include the successors and permitted assigns of such party under this Agreement.
content.caption: Successors and Assigns.

content.text: 16.6	Assignment.  Purchaser shall not have the right to assign this Agreement without the prior written consent of Seller, which consent may be granted or withheld in Seller’s sole and absolute discretion; provided, however, that if Purchaser elects to proceed with the acquisition of the Property following the Due Diligence Period, Purchaser may assign this Agreement to one or more Affiliates of Purchaser without consent from Seller.  Notice of any proposed assignment to Purchaser’s Affiliate, which notice shall include the full legal name and signature block for the proposed assignee, must be given to Seller at least 2 Business Days before Closing.  No assignment by Purchaser shall release it from any liability hereunder.
content.caption: Assignment.

content.text: 16.7	1031 Like-Kind Exchange.  Purchaser may purchase the Property and Seller may sell the Property by completing one or more Internal Revenue Code Section 1031 tax-deferred exchange(s).  Each party agrees to cooperate with the other in effecting such an exchange; provided, however, the cooperating party shall not incur any additional liability or financial obligations and the Closing Date shall not be extended or accelerated as a consequence of any such exchange.
content.caption: 1031 Like-Kind Exchange.

content.text: 16.8	Governing Law; Venue.  This Agreement shall be governed by, and construed in accordance with, the laws of the state in which the Property is located, without regard to any otherwise applicable principles of conflicts of laws.  Venue for any action arising out of this Agreement shall be in the state courts in the state and county in which the Property is located or in U.S. Federal District Court for the applicable district in which the Property is located.
content.caption: Governing Law; Venue.

content.text: 16.9	Waiver of Trial by Jury. EACH PARTY TO THIS AGREEMENT EXPRESSLY WAIVES ANY RIGHT TO TRIAL BY JURY OF ANY CLAIM, DEMAND, ACTION OR CAUSE OF ACTION (A) ARISING UNDER THIS AGREEMENT OR ANY OTHER INSTRUMENT, DOCUMENT OR AGREEMENT EXECUTED OR DELIVERED IN CONNECTION HEREWITH, OR (B) IN ANY WAY CONNECTED WITH OR RELATED OR INCIDENTAL TO THE DEALINGS OF THE PARTIES HERETO OR ANY OF THEM WITH RESPECT TO THIS AGREEMENT OR ANY OTHER INSTRUMENT, DOCUMENT OR AGREEMENT EXECUTED OR DELIVERED IN CONNECTION HEREWITH, OR THE TRANSACTIONS RELATED HERETO OR THERETO, IN EACH CASE WHETHER NOW EXISTING OR HEREAFTER ARISING, AND WHETHER SOUNDING IN CONTRACT OR TORT OR OTHERWISE.  EACH PARTY AGREES THAT ANY SUCH CLAIM, DEMAND, ACTION OR CAUSE OF ACTION SHALL BE DECIDED BY COURT TRIAL WITHOUT A JURY.  THE PARTIES AGREE THAT THE PROVISIONS CONTAINED HEREIN HAVE BEEN NEGOTIATED ON AN ARMS-LENGTH BASIS, WITH BOTH PARTIES AGREEING TO THE SAME KNOWINGLY AND BEING AFFORDED THE OPPORTUNITY TO HAVE THEIR RESPECTIVE LEGAL COUNSEL ADVISE THEM AS TO THE MATTERS CONTAINED HEREIN.
content.caption: Waiver of Trial by Jury.

content.text: 16.10	Attorneys’ Fees.  If any action is brought by any party to this Agreement to enforce or interpret its terms or provisions, the prevailing party will be entitled to reasonable attorneys’ fees and costs incurred in connection with such action prior to and at trial and on any appeal therefrom.
content.caption: Attorneys’ Fees.

content.text: 16.11	No Memorandum.  Purchaser shall not record any memorandum disclosing this Agreement.
content.caption: No Memorandum.

content.text: 16.12	Limited Liability. Neither the members, managers, employees or agents of Seller, nor the shareholders, officers, directors, employees or agents of any of them, shall be liable under this Agreement and all parties hereto shall look solely to the assets of Seller for the payment of any claim or the performance of any obligation by Seller.  None of the individual members, managers, employees or agents or Purchaser, nor the shareholders, officers, directors, partners, members, employees or agents of any of them, shall be liable under this Agreement.
content.caption: Limited Liability.

content.text: 16.13	No Joint Venture.  Nothing in this Agreement shall be construed to create a joint venture between Purchaser and Seller.
content.caption: No Joint Venture.

content.text: 16.14	No Third Party Beneficiaries.  Nothing in this Agreement is intended to benefit any third party or create any third party beneficiary.
content.caption: No Third Party Beneficiaries.

content.text: 16.15	No Waiver.  No waiver of any of the provisions of this Agreement shall be deemed, or shall constitute, a waiver of any other provision, whether or not similar, nor shall any waiver constitute a continuing waiver, nor shall a waiver in any instance constitute a waiver in any subsequent instance.  No waiver shall be binding unless executed in writing by the party making the waiver.
content.caption: No Waiver.

content.text: 16.16	Entire Agreement.  This Agreement (including any and all exhibits and/or schedules attached hereto) and any other document to be furnished pursuant to the provisions hereof embody the entire agreement and understanding of the parties hereto as to the subject matter contained herein.  There are no restrictions, promises, representations, warranties, covenants or undertakings other than those expressly set forth or referred to in such documents.  This Agreement and such documents supersede all prior agreements and understandings among the parties and/or their affiliates with respect to the subject matter hereof (including, without limitation, any previously executed letters of intent, early access agreements and/or non-disclosure or confidentiality agreements).
content.caption: Entire Agreement.

content.text: 16.17	Severability.  Any term or provision of this Agreement that is invalid or unenforceable in any jurisdiction will, as to such jurisdiction, be ineffective to the extent of such invalidity or unenforceability without rendering invalid or unenforceable the remaining terms and provisions of this Agreement, or affecting the validity or enforceability of any of the terms or provisions of this Agreement.
content.caption: Severability.

content.text: 16.18	No Merger.  Subject to the limitations set forth in Section 5.4 and Section 14, the covenants, agreements, representations, and warranties made herein shall survive the Closing Date and shall not merge into the deed and its recordation in the official records or the delivery at Closing of any assignment of leases, general assignment, or bill of sale.
content.caption: No Merger.

content.text: 16.19	Amendment and Modification.  This Agreement may only be amended, modified or supplemented by a written agreement signed by Purchaser and Seller.
content.caption: Amendment and Modification.

content.text: 16.20	Further Acts.  Each party, at the request of the other, shall execute, acknowledge or have notarized (if appropriate) and deliver in a timely manner such additional documents, and do such other additional acts, also in a timely manner, as may be reasonably required in order to accomplish the intent and purposes of this Agreement.
content.caption: Further Acts.

content.text: 16.21	Not an Offer.  Presentation of any draft of this Agreement by one party to the other shall not be deemed an offer, and this Agreement shall only become a binding and enforceable contract upon execution hereof by both parties.
content.caption: Not an Offer.

content.text: 16.22	Counterparts; Electronic Delivery.  This Agreement may be executed in two or more counterparts, each of which shall be deemed an original and all of which together shall constitute the same agreement, whether or not all parties execute each counterpart.  Signatures transmitted by email shall have the same effect as original ink signatures.
content.caption: Counterparts; Electronic Delivery.

content.text: [SIGNATURES FOLLOW ON NEXT PAGE(S)]
content.caption: [SIGNATURES FOLLOW ON NEXT PAGE(S)]

content.text: IN WITNESS WHEREOF, the parties hereto have caused this Agreement to be duly executed.
content.caption: IN WITNESS WHEREOF, the parties hereto have caused this Agre...

risk_inventory.title: Ambiguous Effective Date Determination
risk_inventory.description: The Effective Date is defined as 'the date of mutual execution' established by dates shown below signatures. If Buyer and Seller sign on different dates, it creates ambiguity about which date controls. This could affect calculation of all subsequent deadlines (Due Diligence, Title Objection, Closing) and create disputes about timing obligations. As Seller, unclear timeline could delay your ability to enforce deadlines or claim Buyer default.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: "Effective Date" means the date of mutual execution of this Agreement established by the dates shown below each of the signatures of Seller and Buyer
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Clarify Effective Date as the later of the two signature dates.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise the Effective Date definition to eliminate ambiguity. Replace with: '"Effective Date" means the later of the dates shown below the signatures of Seller and Buyer, such that mutual execution has occurred.' Alternatively, specify that Effective Date shall be the date this Agreement is fully executed by both parties, as evidenced by the later of the signature dates.

risk_inventory.title: Excessive Closing Date Extension Provisions
risk_inventory.description: The Closing Date is subject to extensions under at least eight different sections (4.4, 5.3, 7.2, 11.2.1, 11.2.2, 11.8, 13.1, and 13.2). This creates significant uncertainty for Seller regarding when closing will actually occur and extends Seller's exposure period. Multiple extension mechanisms favor Buyer by allowing delays while Seller remains bound. Seller cannot market the property to other buyers during extended periods and bears ongoing carrying costs.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: The Closing Date is subject to possible extensions as provided in Sections 4.4, 5.3, 7.2, 11.2.1, 11.2.2, 11.8, 13.1 and 13.2 below
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Cap total extensions and add Seller termination right after maximum period.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add a limitation on cumulative extensions: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing extension rights, in no event shall the Closing Date be extended more than sixty (60) days beyond April 30, 2026, unless Seller agrees in writing. If Closing has not occurred by such outside date, Seller may terminate this Agreement upon written notice to Buyer and retain the Earnest Money Deposit as liquidated damages.' Review each referenced section to ensure Seller has appropriate protections and consider whether all extension rights are necessary.

risk_inventory.title: No Seller Right to Accelerate Closing
risk_inventory.description: The provision allows for earlier closing only if agreed by both parties. Seller has no unilateral right to accelerate closing even if Buyer's conditions are satisfied early. This limits Seller's flexibility to close quickly if circumstances warrant (e.g., favorable market conditions, Seller's business needs).
risk_inventory.problematic_text: or such earlier date as may be agreed to by Buyer and Seller in writing
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider adding Seller acceleration right with reasonable notice.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Consider adding language allowing Seller to accelerate closing with adequate notice: 'Seller may accelerate the Closing Date to any date not less than ten (10) Business Days after written notice to Buyer, provided all conditions to Buyer's obligation to close have been satisfied or waived.' Alternatively, leave as-is if Seller prefers the certainty of the fixed date.

risk_inventory.title: Due Diligence Deadline Subject to Expansion
risk_inventory.description: The Due Diligence Deadline can be extended by operation of Sections 3.3 and 4.1. Extended due diligence periods keep Seller bound while Buyer can terminate with deposit return, increasing Seller's market exposure and opportunity cost. The cross-references create uncertainty about the actual deadline Seller must plan for.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: as may be adjusted by operation of Section 3.3 and/or Section 4.1
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Cap maximum due diligence extensions with outside date.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add a cap on extensions: 'as may be adjusted by operation of Section 3.3 and/or Section 4.1; provided, however, that in no event shall the Due Diligence Deadline be extended beyond March 31, 2026.' Review Sections 3.3 and 4.1 to ensure the extension triggers are reasonable and not subject to Buyer manipulation. Consider requiring Buyer to pay additional consideration for any extended due diligence period.

risk_inventory.title: Very Short Due Diligence Delivery Window
risk_inventory.description: Seller has only 3 Business Days from Effective Date to deliver all due diligence materials. This is an extremely tight deadline that may be difficult to meet, especially if closing teams need to coordinate, compile documents from multiple sources, or if the Effective Date falls near a holiday period. Failure to deliver on time could trigger extension of the Due Diligence Deadline per Section 3.3, further delaying the transaction at Seller's expense.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: the date that is 3 Business Days after the Effective Date
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Extend to 5-7 Business Days or use commercially reasonable efforts standard.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to provide more reasonable time: '"Due Diligence Items Delivery Date" means 5:00 p.m., on the date that is five (5) Business Days after the Effective Date.' Alternatively, add a qualifier: 'Seller shall use commercially reasonable efforts to deliver the Due Diligence Items by such date, and any delay in delivery shall not constitute a default hereunder but may extend the Due Diligence Deadline as provided in Section 3.3.' Review Section 3.3 to understand the penalty for late delivery and ensure it is proportionate.

risk_inventory.title: Title Objection Date Tied to Buyer Receipt
risk_inventory.description: The Title Objection Date is triggered by Buyer's receipt of Title Commitment and Title Documents, not by Seller's delivery or a date certain. This creates uncertainty for Seller because: (1) Buyer could claim late or incomplete receipt to extend the objection period; (2) there is no mechanism to confirm receipt date; (3) Seller cannot predict when title objections will come. This floating deadline makes transaction timing unpredictable and could delay closing.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: 10 Business Days after the later of (a) Buyer's receipt of the Title Commitment and Title Documents
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Tie deadline to delivery date with deemed receipt provision.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to create certainty: '"Title Objection Date" means 10 Business Days after the later of (a) Seller's delivery of the Title Commitment and Title Documents to Buyer (which delivery shall be deemed to have occurred on the Title Commitment Delivery Date if Seller has caused the Title Company to make such items available to Buyer by such date), or (b) the Effective Date.' Add a deemed receipt provision: 'Buyer shall be deemed to have received any documents made available through the Title Company's online portal on the date of such availability.'

risk_inventory.title: Fixed Title Commitment Delivery Date
risk_inventory.description: The Title Commitment Delivery Date is a fixed date (January 25, 2026) with no provision for extension. If Seller or the Title Company fails to deliver by this date due to circumstances beyond Seller's control, this could create complications or potential breach claims, even though Seller may not be responsible for Title Company delays.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: "Title Commitment Delivery Date" means January 25, 2026
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add language permitting reasonable extension if Title Company causes delay.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise the definition to include flexibility for Seller: '"Title Commitment Delivery Date" means January 25, 2026, or such later date as may result from delays by the Title Company that are not caused by Seller, provided Seller uses commercially reasonable efforts to cause the Title Company to deliver the Title Commitment by such date.' Alternatively, add a separate provision stating that Seller shall not be in default for delays caused solely by the Title Company.

risk_inventory.title: Estoppel Deadline Extension Favors Buyer
risk_inventory.description: The Estoppel Deadline can be extended 'by operation of Section 7.1,' which typically contains provisions that allow extension when Seller is unable to obtain estoppels. This creates an open-ended potential extension that could delay closing and keep Seller bound to the contract indefinitely while Buyer retains optionality.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: as may be extended by operation of Section 7.1
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Review Section 7.1 to confirm extension limits and add a cap on extensions.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Review Section 7.1 (p_87) to understand the scope of potential extensions. Consider adding language to cap extensions: 'as may be extended by operation of Section 7.1, provided that in no event shall such deadline be extended more than [30] days beyond April 15, 2026.' This protects Seller from indefinite delays while still allowing reasonable accommodation for estoppel collection.

risk_inventory.title: Fixed Major Tenant List May Become Outdated
risk_inventory.description: The definition of 'Major Tenants' lists three specific tenants by name. If any of these tenants assigns their lease, changes their name, or if new significant tenants are added before closing, this definition will not automatically update. This could create issues with estoppel requirements if a named Major Tenant is no longer in the building or has been replaced by a larger tenant.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: "Major Tenants" means (i) Northwest Technology Partners, (ii) Cascade Financial Services and (iii) Pacific Law Group LLP
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider whether definition should include successor/assign language.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Consider revising to address potential changes: '"Major Tenants" means (i) Northwest Technology Partners (or any successor or assign thereof under its Lease), (ii) Cascade Financial Services (or any successor or assign thereof under its Lease) and (iii) Pacific Law Group LLP (or any successor or assign thereof under its Lease), provided that if any such tenant has vacated or been released from its Lease prior to Closing, such tenant shall no longer be deemed a Major Tenant.' This ensures the definition remains functional even if tenant circumstances change.

risk_inventory.title: Broad Property Definition Includes Uncertain Items
risk_inventory.description: The Property definition is extremely broad, potentially including items Seller may not own or intend to convey. Phrases like 'all rights, privileges, interests' and 'whether existing or after acquired' could sweep in assets Seller did not intend to sell. The inclusion of 'all minerals, oil, gas and other hydrocarbon substances' may not reflect prior severances, and 'all rights of Seller, if any, in any property lying in the bed of any street' may include valuable rights Seller wishes to retain.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: all rights, privileges, interests, licenses, claims, easements, benefits, covenants, conditions and servitudes of any type or nature which are appurtenant to or otherwise benefiting the Land or Improvements, whether existing or after acquired, including all minerals, oil, gas and other hydrocarbon substances on the Land or Improvements
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm mineral rights ownership and consider limiting 'after acquired' language.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Review and potentially narrow the definition: (1) For minerals, add qualifier: 'including all minerals, oil, gas and other hydrocarbon substances on the Land or Improvements to the extent owned by Seller and not previously severed or reserved'; (2) Consider removing or limiting 'whether existing or after acquired' to 'as of the Effective Date' to avoid conveying rights Seller may acquire between signing and closing; (3) Ensure Seller has confirmed ownership of all listed categories before agreeing to this broad definition. Add explicit carve-outs for any assets Seller intends to retain.

risk_inventory.title: Assignability Qualifiers Create Potential Gaps
risk_inventory.description: Several categories of Property are qualified by 'to the extent assignable' or 'to the extent owned by Seller.' While these qualifications are appropriate, Buyer may later claim Seller failed to convey items that Seller believed were non-assignable. Seller should document what items are not assignable before closing to avoid post-closing disputes.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: to the extent assignable
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider requiring pre-closing documentation of non-assignable items.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add a protective provision: 'Seller shall provide Buyer prior to Closing with a list of any Licenses and Permits, warranties, guarantees, or other items included in the definition of Property that Seller believes are not assignable or transferable without third-party consent. Buyer's acceptance of such list (or failure to object within 5 Business Days) shall conclusively establish that Seller has no obligation to assign such items and shall not be in breach for failure to do so.' This protects Seller from post-closing claims regarding non-assignable items.

risk_inventory.title: Seller Pays Both Broker Commissions
risk_inventory.description: This provision requires Seller to pay commissions to BOTH Seller's Broker AND Buyer's Broker. This is an unusual and potentially costly arrangement where Seller bears the full commission burden for both sides of the transaction. Typically, each party pays their own broker or the seller pays only the listing broker who then splits with the buyer's broker. Here, Seller has direct payment obligations to Buyer's Broker pursuant to a 'separate agreement with Buyer's Broker' - but Seller may not have visibility into or control over what that separate agreement provides.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller shall pay any commissions or fees due or payable to Buyer's Broker pursuant to a separate agreement with Buyer's Broker.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Revise so Buyer pays its own broker or cap Seller's obligation to Buyer's Broker.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Modify the second sentence to either: (1) state that Buyer shall be responsible for any commissions or fees due to Buyer's Broker, or (2) if Seller must pay Buyer's Broker, add language that caps Seller's obligation at a specific percentage or dollar amount, requires Seller's prior written approval of the separate agreement terms, and provides that Seller's obligation is limited to the amount set forth in a commission agreement attached as an exhibit to this Agreement.

risk_inventory.title: No Cap on Broker Commission Amounts
risk_inventory.description: The provision obligates Seller to pay 'any commissions or fees' without any stated cap or limitation on the amount. The commission amounts are determined by separate agreements that are not incorporated or attached to this Agreement, leaving Seller exposed to potentially unknown commission obligations. There is no representation from Buyer regarding the terms of its broker agreement.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: any commissions or fees due or payable
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Attach broker agreements as exhibits and cap Seller's total commission liability.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add language requiring that copies of all broker agreements be attached as exhibits to this Agreement, and add a cap on total broker commissions payable by Seller (e.g., 'not to exceed [X]% of the Purchase Price in the aggregate'). Consider adding: 'Seller's obligation to pay broker commissions shall be limited to the amounts set forth in the commission agreements attached hereto as Exhibit [__], and Seller shall have no liability for any commissions or fees in excess of such amounts.'

risk_inventory.title: Express Representations Carve-Out May Be Broad
risk_inventory.description: While the AS-IS provision is generally protective of Seller, the multiple carve-outs for 'Seller's Representations and Warranties expressly set forth in this Agreement or in the Closing Documents' could expose Seller to liability if the representations in Section 5.1 or the Closing Documents are broadly drafted. The effectiveness of this AS-IS clause depends entirely on how narrowly the express representations are drafted elsewhere in the Agreement.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: OTHER THAN SELLER'S REPRESENTATIONS AND WARRANTIES EXPRESSLY SET FORTH IN THIS AGREEMENT OR IN THE DOCUMENTS TO BE DELIVERED BY SELLER AT CLOSING ("CLOSING DOCUMENTS")
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure representations in Section 5.1 are narrowly drafted with appropriate qualifiers.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Review this clause in conjunction with Section 5.1 representations to ensure consistency. Consider adding language clarifying that the Closing Documents referenced shall only include those documents expressly listed in Section 11.4, and that any representations in such Closing Documents shall be subject to the same limitations, survival periods, and caps set forth in Sections 5.4 and 16.21 of this Agreement.

risk_inventory.title: Short Deposit Deadline
risk_inventory.description: Buyer has only 2 Business Days after the Effective Date to wire the Earnest Money Deposit. While this creates urgency for Buyer (generally favorable to Seller), Seller should be aware that if Buyer fails to deposit timely, Seller's remedies and the status of the Agreement may need to be addressed. The Agreement should clearly address consequences of late or non-deposit.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Within 2 Business Days, as defined in Section 16.2 below, after the Effective Date, Buyer shall deposit with Escrow Agent via wire transfer the Earnest Money Deposit
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider adding explicit remedy if Buyer fails to timely deposit earnest money.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Consider adding a sentence stating: 'Buyer's failure to timely deposit the Earnest Money Deposit shall constitute a default under this Agreement and Seller may, at its sole option, terminate this Agreement by written notice to Buyer, whereupon this Agreement shall be null and void and neither party shall have any further obligations hereunder except for those that expressly survive termination.'

risk_inventory.title: Earnest Money Refund Exceptions Undefined Here
risk_inventory.description: The clause states the Earnest Money Deposit is non-refundable after Buyer delivers Buyer Approval Notice 'except as otherwise expressly provided in this Agreement.' This cross-reference to other provisions means Seller needs to carefully track all provisions that might trigger a refund of earnest money, including title objection failures, financing contingencies, casualty provisions, seller default, and closing condition failures.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: except as otherwise expressly provided in this Agreement
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider listing all refund exceptions in one location for clarity.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: For tracking purposes, review and compile a complete list of all provisions that allow return of the Earnest Money Deposit to Buyer, including but not limited to: Section 3.2 (due diligence termination before Buyer Approval Notice), Section 4.3/4.4 (title objection matters), Section 10.1 (buyer closing condition failures), Section 12 (casualty/condemnation), and Section 13.1 (seller default). Consider adding a parenthetical listing these specific section references for clarity.

risk_inventory.title: Independent Consideration Well Protected
risk_inventory.description: This provision properly secures $100 as independent consideration that is non-refundable under any circumstances. The language 'notwithstanding anything to the contrary in this Agreement' provides strong protection. However, the amount ($100) is minimal and may not adequately compensate Seller for taking the property off the market during the due diligence period.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: $100 of the Earnest Money Deposit
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider increasing the independent consideration amount to a more meaningful sum.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: While the current independent consideration amount of $100 is legally sufficient, consider increasing this amount to better compensate Seller for the opportunity cost of taking the property off the market. A more substantial amount (e.g., $10,000-$50,000 depending on deal size) would provide greater compensation if Buyer terminates. Revise to: '$[AMOUNT] of the Earnest Money Deposit ("Independent Contract Consideration")...'

risk_inventory.title: Due Diligence Period Subject to Extensions
risk_inventory.description: The Due Diligence Period is subject to 'possible extension as provided in Sections 3.3 and 4.1 below.' This creates uncertainty for Seller regarding how long the property will be tied up. Extensions could delay Closing or allow Buyer to hold the property off-market for an extended period while Seller bears holding costs and market risk.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: The Due Diligence Deadline and the Due Diligence Period are subject to possible extension as provided in Sections 3.3 and 4.1 below.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add a cap on maximum extensions to the Due Diligence Period.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add language limiting the aggregate extensions to the Due Diligence Period. Consider adding: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, in no event shall the Due Diligence Period be extended more than [15/30] days in the aggregate beyond the original Due Diligence Deadline without Seller's prior written consent.' This prevents indefinite delays while still allowing reasonable flexibility for legitimate issues.

risk_inventory.title: Buyer Has Broad Termination Rights During Due Diligence
risk_inventory.description: The Due Diligence Period grants Buyer extensive investigation rights with what appears to be a 'free look' right to terminate for any reason until the Due Diligence Deadline. This ties up the property and takes it off the market while Buyer can walk away with a full deposit refund (minus the $100 independent consideration). Combined with the extension provisions, this creates significant risk that Seller's property remains in limbo.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer and its employees, agents, contractors, consultants and representatives ("Buyer's Due Diligence Team") may conduct its due diligence investigation and feasibility review of the Property
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider requiring Buyer to go hard on a portion of the deposit earlier.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Consider adding a 'day one hard' deposit structure or requiring a portion of the Earnest Money to become non-refundable at an earlier milestone before the full Due Diligence Deadline. For example, add: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, [AMOUNT or PERCENTAGE] of the Earnest Money Deposit shall become non-refundable to Buyer upon the earlier of (a) [DATE], or (b) [NUMBER] days following the Effective Date, regardless of whether Buyer has completed its due diligence.' This provides Seller greater assurance of Buyer's commitment.

risk_inventory.title: Broad Definition of Due Diligence Team
risk_inventory.description: The definition of 'Buyer's Due Diligence Team' is broad, including 'employees, agents, contractors, consultants and representatives.' While Section 3.4 contains limitations, this broad access could result in numerous parties entering the property and potentially disrupting tenants or operations. Seller should ensure the indemnification in Section 3.4.3 adequately covers all these parties' actions.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: its employees, agents, contractors, consultants and representatives ("Buyer's Due Diligence Team")
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify indemnification coverage extends to all Due Diligence Team members' actions.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Cross-reference with Section 3.4.3 to ensure the indemnification provisions expressly cover all actions of the broadly-defined Due Diligence Team. Consider adding language requiring Buyer to provide Seller with a list of all parties who will be accessing the property and requiring each to be covered under Buyer's insurance policy referenced in Section 3.4.4.

risk_inventory.title: Unlimited Buyer Termination Right
risk_inventory.description: This clause gives Buyer an absolute, unfettered right to terminate the Agreement for any reason or no reason at all during the Due Diligence Period. Buyer can simply issue a Disapproval Notice or remain silent, and the Earnest Money Deposit is fully refunded. Seller has no recourse and bears all opportunity costs of keeping the Property off-market during this period. The clause contains no requirement that Buyer's disapproval be based on any objective findings or good faith concerns discovered during due diligence.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: If Buyer decides not to proceed with the acquisition of the Property, Buyer may give Seller written notice of its disapproval of its Due Diligence contingency
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require Buyer to specify legitimate due diligence concerns as basis for termination.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Modify the termination right to require Buyer's disapproval to be based on material concerns discovered during due diligence. Consider adding language such as: 'If Buyer discovers any matter during its due diligence investigation that is materially unsatisfactory to Buyer in its reasonable judgment, Buyer may give Seller written notice of its disapproval specifying in reasonable detail the matters forming the basis for such disapproval.' Alternatively, consider making a portion of the Earnest Money non-refundable upon execution or at a mid-point during the due diligence period.

risk_inventory.title: Passive Termination by Buyer Silence
risk_inventory.description: Buyer can terminate the Agreement simply by failing to deliver the Buyer Approval Notice by the Due Diligence Deadline. This 'deemed termination' mechanism creates risk that Seller may not receive clear communication about Buyer's intentions, making it difficult to promptly re-market the Property. Buyer has no obligation to affirmatively communicate its decision.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: If Buyer fails to deliver the Buyer Approval Notice by the Due Diligence Deadline
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require affirmative written notice of either approval or disapproval from Buyer.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to require Buyer to deliver either an Approval Notice or Disapproval Notice by the Due Diligence Deadline, with consequences for failure to deliver any notice. Consider language such as: 'Buyer shall deliver to Seller either the Buyer Approval Notice or the Buyer Disapproval Notice on or before the Due Diligence Deadline. If Buyer fails to deliver either notice by the Due Diligence Deadline, Buyer shall be deemed to have approved the Due Diligence contingency, and the Earnest Money Deposit shall become non-refundable.'

risk_inventory.title: Broad Refundability Exception Language
risk_inventory.description: Even after Buyer delivers the Approval Notice and the Earnest Money becomes 'non-refundable,' the clause preserves refundability 'except as otherwise expressly provided in this Agreement.' This creates uncertainty about the actual circumstances under which Buyer may still recover the deposit post-approval. Seller should understand the full scope of refund rights throughout the Agreement.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: except as otherwise expressly provided in this Agreement
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Identify and limit the specific exceptions to non-refundability.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Consider enumerating the specific exceptions to non-refundability rather than using broad catch-all language. Revise to: 'the Earnest Money Deposit shall be non-refundable, except in the event of (i) Seller's default under Section 13.1, (ii) a Major Loss or Condemnation under Section 12.2 where Buyer elects to terminate, or (iii) failure of a Buyer closing condition under Section 10.1 that is not waived by Buyer.' This provides clarity and prevents unanticipated refund scenarios.

risk_inventory.title: Unlimited Due Diligence Extension for Delivery Delays
risk_inventory.description: If Seller fails to timely deliver any due diligence items, the Due Diligence Deadline automatically extends day-for-day with no cap. This creates potentially unlimited extension of Buyer's free termination right. Minor or disputed delivery delays could significantly extend Seller's exposure period. There is no mechanism to resolve disputes about whether items were properly delivered.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: If Seller fails to timely deliver or post all Delivered Due Diligence Items, the Due Diligence Deadline shall be extended on a day for day basis for each day of Seller's delay
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Cap the extension period and add dispute resolution mechanism.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Modify to cap the automatic extension and provide clarity: 'If Seller fails to timely deliver or post all Delivered Due Diligence Items, the Due Diligence Deadline shall be extended on a day-for-day basis for each day of Seller's delay in delivering or posting such items; provided, however, that (a) such extension shall not exceed ten (10) Business Days in the aggregate, (b) Buyer must notify Seller in writing within three (3) Business Days after the Due Diligence Items Delivery Date of any items Buyer claims were not delivered or posted, and (c) any disputes regarding delivery shall be resolved by reference to Seller's delivery receipts or Data Room upload logs.'

risk_inventory.title: Expansive Additional Information Obligation
risk_inventory.description: Beyond the enumerated Exhibit C items, Seller must make available 'any other written information concerning the Property' in Seller's possession or control. While there are some exclusions (appraisals, drafts, internal materials), this obligation is broad and could require significant additional effort. The 2 Business Day response requirement adds operational burden.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller shall make available any other written information concerning the Property, to the extent in Seller's possession or control, for review at the Property or Seller's office upon at least 2 Business Days prior written notice
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Limit additional information to materials reasonably necessary for due diligence.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to narrow the scope: 'In addition, upon Buyer's reasonable written request identifying specific documents or categories of documents reasonably necessary for Buyer's due diligence investigation, Seller shall use commercially reasonable efforts to make available such information, to the extent in Seller's possession or control and subject to the exclusions set forth below, for review at the Property or Seller's office upon at least five (5) Business Days prior written notice. Seller shall have no obligation to search for, compile, or create any documents or information not readily available in Seller's files.'

risk_inventory.title: Extensive Physical Access Rights
risk_inventory.description: Buyer and its 'Due Diligence Team' (undefined and potentially unlimited in scope) have broad rights to conduct 'tours, inspections, examinations, studies, surveys, measurement or tests' with only 1 Business Day notice. While Seller can accompany and Seller's approval is required (not to be unreasonably withheld), this creates operational burden and potential liability exposure for an occupied property.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer and Buyer's Due Diligence Team may request reasonable access to the Property during normal business hours to conduct tours, inspections, examinations, studies, surveys, measurement or tests
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Define 'Due Diligence Team' and extend notice period to 2-3 Business Days.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add definition and extend notice: 'As used herein, "Buyer's Due Diligence Team" means Buyer's employees, officers, consultants, engineers, architects, contractors, and lenders, in each case who have been identified to Seller in writing prior to accessing the Property. Buyer and Buyer's Due Diligence Team may request reasonable access to the Property during normal business hours (excluding weekends and holidays) to conduct tours, inspections, examinations, studies, surveys, measurement or tests (collectively, "Inspections"). Such requests must be made by email to Seller at least three (3) Business Days in advance of when access is requested and shall specify the nature of the Inspection and the names and affiliations of all individuals who will be accessing the Property.'

risk_inventory.title: Seller Retains Invasive Inspection Control
risk_inventory.description: Seller has sole discretion to approve or deny invasive inspections. This is favorable to Seller but should be noted as a point that may be negotiated by Buyer. Seller should maintain this protection.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer may only conduct invasive Inspections of the Property with Seller's prior written consent, which consent may be withheld in Seller's sole discretion
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Retain this protective language; do not agree to weaken.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: This provision is favorable to Seller. If Buyer requests modification, consider requiring Buyer to provide detailed scope, methodology, and restoration plan for any proposed invasive inspection, with Seller retaining final approval. Do not agree to change 'sole discretion' to 'reasonable discretion' or similar standards.

risk_inventory.title: Subjective Non-Disruption Standard
risk_inventory.description: The requirement that inspections be conducted 'in a manner which is not disruptive to Tenants and does not interfere with the normal operation of the Property' is subjective and may be difficult to enforce. If Buyer's activities do cause disruption, Seller's remedies are unclear. Tenant complaints could expose Seller to liability under existing leases.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer and Buyer's Due Diligence Team shall conduct the Inspections in a manner which is not disruptive to Tenants and does not interfere with the normal operation of the Property
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add specific prohibitions and remedies for disruption.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Strengthen with specific requirements: 'Buyer and Buyer's Due Diligence Team shall conduct the Inspections in a manner which is not disruptive to Tenants and does not interfere with the normal operation of the Property. Without limiting the foregoing, Buyer shall: (a) not contact any Tenant directly without Seller's prior written consent; (b) ensure that all Inspections in common areas are conducted outside of peak business hours as reasonably designated by Seller; (c) immediately cease any Inspection activity upon Seller's request if Seller determines that such activity is causing or may cause disruption; and (d) indemnify Seller for any claims by Tenants arising from Buyer's inspection activities. Any violation of this Section shall constitute a default by Buyer under this Agreement.'

risk_inventory.title: Pre-Existing Condition Discovery Carve-Out
risk_inventory.description: The indemnification excludes liability arising from 'the mere discovery of any pre-existing condition at the Property.' This carve-out is ambiguous and could be interpreted broadly. If Buyer's inspections reveal contamination or other issues that trigger reporting obligations or remediation requirements, Seller may bear responsibility even though Buyer's activities initiated the discovery.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: except to the extent arising out of (a) the mere discovery of any pre-existing condition at the Property
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Clarify that carve-out applies only to conditions not exacerbated by Buyer.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Narrow the carve-out: 'except to the extent arising out of (a) the mere discovery of any pre-existing condition at the Property that Buyer did not exacerbate, disturb, or release during its Inspections, provided that Buyer complied with all applicable laws in conducting such Inspections and promptly notified Seller of any such discovery.' Consider adding: 'For the avoidance of doubt, Buyer shall indemnify Seller for any costs or liabilities arising from any governmental reporting obligations triggered solely by Buyer's inspection activities.'

risk_inventory.title: Unlimited Survival of Indemnification
risk_inventory.description: The inspection indemnification obligation 'shall survive termination of this Agreement' without any time limitation. This creates perpetual exposure for Buyer, but more importantly for Seller, it means Seller must pursue any claims against Buyer indefinitely. Consider whether a defined survival period would be more practical for both parties.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: This obligation shall survive termination of this Agreement.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider adding a reasonable survival period of 2-3 years.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: While unlimited survival favors Seller, a defined period may be more practical: 'This obligation shall survive termination of this Agreement for a period of two (2) years; provided, however, that such survival period shall be extended with respect to any claim for which Seller has provided written notice to Buyer prior to the expiration of such two-year period until such claim is finally resolved.'

risk_inventory.title: Insurance Limit May Be Insufficient
risk_inventory.description: The $1,000,000 commercial general liability insurance requirement may be inadequate for a commercial property of significant value. If Buyer's inspections cause substantial damage (e.g., environmental contamination from Phase II testing, structural damage, fire), this limit may not fully cover Seller's losses. The clause does not require umbrella or excess coverage, property damage coverage, or environmental liability coverage for invasive testing.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: commercial general liability (occurrence) insurance in an amount no less than $1,000,000
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Increase minimum coverage to $2-5M and require environmental liability coverage.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise the insurance requirement to increase the minimum coverage amount to at least $2,000,000 (or higher based on property value), and add requirements for: (i) umbrella/excess liability coverage of at least $5,000,000, (ii) property damage coverage, and (iii) pollution/environmental liability coverage if any invasive testing is contemplated. Also specify that coverage must be primary and non-contributory.

risk_inventory.title: Additional Insureds List Incomplete
risk_inventory.description: The clause only requires Seller and its property manager to be listed as additional insureds. This may leave other parties with an interest in the Property (such as Seller's lender, asset manager, or other affiliated entities) without coverage protection from Buyer's inspection activities.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: that lists Seller and its property manager as additional insureds
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Expand additional insureds to include Seller's lender and affiliates.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Expand the additional insured requirement to read: 'that lists Seller, Seller's property manager, Seller's lender(s) and their servicers, and their respective Affiliates, members, managers, officers, directors, employees and agents as additional insureds.'

risk_inventory.title: Subjective Restoration Standard
risk_inventory.description: The restoration obligation requires Buyer to restore the Property to 'substantially the same condition' which is a subjective standard that could lead to disputes about what constitutes adequate restoration. Additionally, there is no timeframe specified for completing restoration, no requirement for Seller approval of restoration work, and no remedy if Buyer fails to properly restore.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer shall restore the Property and Improvements to substantially the same condition in which the same were found before any such entry upon the Property and Inspections were undertaken
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add objective standards, timeframe, and Seller approval requirements for restoration.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise the restoration obligation to add specificity: 'Buyer shall, within ten (10) days after termination (or such longer period as reasonably necessary with Seller's approval), restore the Property and Improvements to the same condition in which the same were found before any such entry, to Seller's reasonable satisfaction. Such restoration shall include, without limitation, filling all test holes, removing all equipment and materials, repairing any damage to landscaping, structures, or improvements, and remediating any environmental conditions caused by Buyer's activities. If Buyer fails to complete such restoration within the required timeframe, Seller may complete the restoration at Buyer's sole cost and expense, which amounts shall be due immediately upon demand.'

risk_inventory.title: No Security for Restoration/Lien Obligations
risk_inventory.description: While Buyer has obligations to pay inspection costs, prevent liens, and restore the Property, there is no mechanism to ensure Buyer has the financial ability to satisfy these obligations after termination. The Earnest Money Deposit may be refunded to Buyer upon termination, leaving Seller with only an unsecured claim against Buyer.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer shall promptly pay when due all costs of all Inspections done with regard to the Property and shall not permit any liens to attach to the Property
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Allow Seller to retain portion of deposit or require bond for restoration obligations.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add the following provision: 'Notwithstanding any provision to the contrary in this Agreement, if this Agreement terminates prior to Closing for any reason other than Seller default, Seller may retain from any refund of the Earnest Money Deposit an amount reasonably estimated by Seller to cover any outstanding restoration obligations, unpaid inspection costs, or lien claims. Any amounts so retained in excess of actual costs shall be refunded to Buyer within thirty (30) days after Seller's determination that all such obligations have been satisfied.'

risk_inventory.title: Prior Access Agreement Liability May Be Unclear
risk_inventory.description: While the clause supersedes the Prior Early Access Agreement and subjects prior activities to Section 3.4, it does not clearly address whether Buyer's indemnification obligations under Section 3.4.3 apply retroactively to activities conducted under the Prior Early Access Agreement. If the prior agreement had lesser protections, there may be a gap in coverage for claims arising from those earlier activities.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: all other activities undertaken by Buyer, Buyer's Affiliates or their employees, agents, contractors, consultants and representatives under such Prior Early Access Agreement shall be deemed governed by this Section 3.4
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Clarify that indemnification applies retroactively to prior access activities.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add clarifying language: 'For the avoidance of doubt, Buyer's indemnification obligations under Section 3.4.3 and all other obligations under this Section 3.4 shall apply to all activities undertaken by Buyer and Buyer's Due Diligence Team under any Prior Early Access Agreement as if such activities had been undertaken under this Agreement, regardless of when such activities occurred.'

risk_inventory.title: No Limits on Tenant Interview Scope or Seller Presence
