risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add 'to Seller's knowledge' qualifier to the Leasing Costs representation.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Modify to read: 'Seller represents and warrants that, to Seller's Knowledge, Exhibit L attached hereto sets forth all Leasing Costs still outstanding under those Leases in effect as of the Effective Date.' This aligns the representation with the knowledge standard used elsewhere in the Agreement and prevents strict liability for inadvertent omissions.

risk_inventory.title: Late Documentation Deadline for Leasing Costs
risk_inventory.description: Seller must deliver the statement of Existing Leasing Costs paid 'no later than 5 Business Days prior to the Closing Date.' This is a tight timeline that may create last-minute closing complications if there are discrepancies between the statement and Exhibit L, particularly for a complex property with multiple tenants.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: No later than 5 Business Days prior to the Closing Date, Seller shall deliver to Buyer a statement, with reasonable supporting documentation, of the Existing Leasing Costs actually paid by Seller between the Effective Date and the date of delivery of such statement
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider extending to 10 Business Days to allow time to resolve discrepancies.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Consider changing 'No later than 5 Business Days' to 'No later than 10 Business Days' to provide adequate time for Buyer to review the documentation and for the parties to resolve any discrepancies before Closing without causing closing delays.

risk_inventory.title: Buyer Assumption Limited to Credit Amount
risk_inventory.description: Buyer only assumes responsibility for Existing Leasing Costs 'up to the amount of the credit that Buyer received at Closing.' This means if there are Existing Leasing Costs that were not on Exhibit L or that exceed the credit amount, Seller may remain liable. This provision should be cross-referenced with the representation above.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer shall assume responsibility for paying the remaining Existing Leasing Costs up to the amount of the credit that Buyer received at Closing
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure Exhibit L is comprehensive; consider uncapped assumption by Buyer.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Consider revising to: 'Buyer shall assume responsibility for paying all remaining Existing Leasing Costs as set forth on Exhibit L (as such exhibit may be updated by mutual agreement prior to Closing).' This removes the cap tied to the credit amount and ensures Buyer assumes all scheduled obligations. Alternatively, add language that any Existing Leasing Costs not listed on Exhibit L shall remain Seller's responsibility only if Seller had actual knowledge of such costs prior to Closing.

risk_inventory.title: Due Diligence Deadline Reference for Leasing Costs
risk_inventory.description: New Leasing Costs allocation uses the Due Diligence Deadline as the dividing line. This is appropriate, but Seller should be aware that leases entered into between Effective Date and Due Diligence Deadline (even if approved by Buyer) would have their Leasing Costs treated as Existing Leasing Costs under Section 7.3.2, requiring Seller credit.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer shall be responsible for the payment of all Leasing Costs payable for (a) any new Leases entered into after the Due Diligence Deadline that have been approved (or deemed approved) by Buyer
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Clarify treatment of leases approved between Effective Date and DD Deadline.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Consider adding clarifying language: 'For the avoidance of doubt, Leasing Costs for any new Lease entered into between the Effective Date and the Due Diligence Deadline with Buyer's approval (or deemed approval) shall be treated as New Leasing Costs and shall be Buyer's responsibility.' This shifts the cost allocation to Buyer for any deals Buyer approved during due diligence.

risk_inventory.title: Unfunded Ongoing Cooperation Obligation for Non-Transferable LOCs
risk_inventory.description: For non-transferable letters of credit, Seller is obligated to provide 'reasonable cooperation' to Buyer and the tenant after Closing to facilitate reissuance of a new letter of credit. This creates an open-ended post-closing obligation for Seller with no time limit, no cap on the extent of cooperation required, and could involve ongoing administrative burden. While the parenthetical excludes expenditure of funds, the cooperation requirement itself could be time-consuming and extend indefinitely.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: shall provide reasonable cooperation to Buyer and the applicable tenant (including after Closing, but without the need for expenditure of funds) to facilitate the reissuance of a new letter of credit
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add time limit (e.g., 90 days post-closing) for cooperation obligation.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise the sentence to add a reasonable time limitation on Seller's post-closing cooperation obligation. Suggested revision: 'shall provide reasonable cooperation to Buyer and the applicable tenant for a period not to exceed ninety (90) days after Closing (but without the need for expenditure of funds or more than de minimis administrative effort) to facilitate the reissuance of a new letter of credit to replace the letter of credit previously held by Seller.'

risk_inventory.title: Six-Month Billing Requirement Extends Seller's Dependence on Buyer
risk_inventory.description: While Buyer has no duty to collect delinquent rents, Buyer is required to bill tenants for delinquent rents for 6 months after Closing. This creates a situation where Seller is dependent on Buyer's good faith performance of billing obligations to collect pre-closing arrears. There is no remedy specified if Buyer fails to bill properly or in a timely manner, potentially impairing Seller's ability to collect amounts owed.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: shall be required to bill Tenants for delinquent rents in the ordinary course of business for 6 months after Closing
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add remedy or recourse if Buyer fails to properly bill tenants.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add language providing Seller with recourse if Buyer fails to bill tenants as required. Suggested addition after the first sentence: 'Buyer shall provide Seller with copies of all billing statements sent to Tenants for delinquent rents within ten (10) Business Days of sending. If Buyer fails to bill Tenants as required herein, Seller shall have the right, upon written notice to Buyer, to directly bill such Tenants and Buyer shall reasonably cooperate with Seller's collection efforts.'

risk_inventory.title: Rent Payment Waterfall Subordinates Seller's Pre-Closing Claims
risk_inventory.description: The payment application waterfall applies payments: (a) first to the month of Closing, (b) second to Buyer's period of ownership, and (c) third to Seller's period of ownership. This structure subordinates Seller's pre-closing delinquent rent claims to Buyer's post-closing claims. If a tenant is chronically delinquent, Seller may never receive payment for pre-closing arrears as new delinquencies will take priority.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: (a) first toward the delinquent rent (or other tenant charge) for the actual month in which Closing occurred, (b) second toward the delinquent rent (or other tenant charge) owed to Buyer for its period of ownership and (c) third toward the delinquent rent (or other tenant charge) owed to Seller for its period of ownership
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Revise waterfall to prioritize oldest delinquencies first.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise the payment application waterfall to apply payments in chronological order, which would benefit Seller for pre-closing arrears. Suggested revision: 'such payments shall be applied (a) first toward the delinquent rent (or other tenant charge) for the actual month in which Closing occurred, (b) second toward the oldest outstanding delinquent rent (or other tenant charge) chronologically, allocating between Seller's and Buyer's respective periods of ownership accordingly, unless the Tenant designates the payment for a specific period.'

risk_inventory.title: Seller Cannot Terminate Lease or Possession for Collection
risk_inventory.description: Seller's reserved right to pursue remedies for delinquent rents is limited by the prohibition against terminating any Lease or Tenant's right to possession. While this is a reasonable protection for Buyer's asset, it limits Seller's collection leverage for pre-closing delinquencies and may make collection impractical for significant arrears.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: but shall not be entitled to terminate any Lease or any Tenant's right to possession
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider whether this limitation is appropriate for your transaction.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: This is a market-standard provision protecting Buyer's tenancies, but Seller should be aware of the limitation. If Seller has significant pre-closing delinquencies with particular tenants, consider negotiating a specific carve-out or addressing the delinquency as a Purchase Price adjustment at Closing rather than relying on post-closing collection rights.

risk_inventory.title: Short Window for Rent Roll Delivery Before Closing
risk_inventory.description: The updated rent roll must be delivered no sooner than 10 Business Days and no later than 5 Business Days prior to Closing. This creates a 5-Business-Day delivery window that could be operationally challenging if Closing is accelerated or if there are administrative delays in compiling accurate rent roll data.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: No sooner than 10 Business Days prior to Closing and no later than 5 Business Days prior to Closing
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure internal processes can meet this delivery window.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: This is an informational risk for Seller's awareness. Ensure property management has processes in place to generate updated rent rolls within this window. If operationally challenging, consider negotiating a wider window: 'No sooner than 15 Business Days prior to Closing and no later than 3 Business Days prior to Closing.'

risk_inventory.title: Unlimited Survival for Reconciliation Obligations
risk_inventory.description: Seller retains responsibility for 2025 Reconciliation Statements, including responsibility for tenant overpayment refunds and audit costs, with an express survival provision but no time limit. Tenant audit rights often extend 2-3 years under leases, meaning Seller could face claims for reconciliation errors or audit costs years after Closing with no cap or limitation.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: The provisions of this Section 7.7 shall survive the Closing.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add survival period limit aligned with tenant audit rights in leases.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add a reasonable time limitation on the survival of these obligations. Suggested revision: 'The provisions of this Section 7.7 shall survive the Closing for a period of twenty-four (24) months or, if longer, until the expiration of any applicable Tenant audit rights under the Leases with respect to 2025 operating expenses, but in no event longer than thirty-six (36) months after Closing.'

risk_inventory.title: No Cap on Seller's Reconciliation and Audit Cost Liability
risk_inventory.description: Seller is obligated to pay tenant overpayments and audit costs related to 2025 reconciliations without any cap or limitation. In a multi-tenant property with significant operating expense pass-throughs, errors in the 2025 reconciliation could result in substantial refund obligations. Additionally, multiple tenant audits could generate significant costs with no aggregate limit.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller shall promptly remit such overpayment to the Tenant
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider capping reconciliation liability or tying to representation survival cap.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add a cap on Seller's aggregate liability for reconciliation-related payments. Suggested addition: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, Seller's aggregate liability for overpayment refunds, underpayment credits against delinquent rent, and audit costs under this Section 7.7 shall not exceed [$ amount or percentage of Purchase Price], and any amounts in excess thereof shall be Buyer's responsibility.' Alternatively, tie this liability to the overall representation and warranty cap in Section 5.4.

risk_inventory.title: Broad Contract Definition Includes Leasing and Brokerage Agreements
risk_inventory.description: The definition of 'Contracts' includes 'leasing, brokerage' agreements. This overlaps with the separate treatment of leases in Article 7 and brokerage commissions in Section 7.3. The breadth of this definition could create ambiguity about which provisions govern lease-related agreements and could inadvertently capture agreements that should be addressed separately under the leasing provisions.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: management, leasing, brokerage, maintenance, construction and service contracts and agreements relating to the Property
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm Exhibit D accurately segregates contracts from lease-related agreements.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Review Exhibit D to ensure clear delineation between Contracts subject to Article 8 and lease-related agreements subject to Article 7. Consider adding clarifying language: 'As used herein, "Contracts" means all currently effective management, maintenance, construction and service contracts and agreements relating to the Property (but excluding the Leases and any leasing commission agreements listed on Exhibit M), including all amendments thereto, relating to the ownership, operation and maintenance of the Property, all of which are identified in Exhibit D attached hereto.'

risk_inventory.title: Seller Bears Contract Termination Costs
risk_inventory.description: Seller is obligated to terminate at its 'sole cost and expense' any Contracts that Buyer does not elect to assume. This creates significant financial exposure for Seller, as some contracts may have substantial early termination fees, penalties, or buyout provisions. Buyer has complete discretion to designate which contracts to assume (or none at all), leaving Seller exposed to potentially unlimited termination costs without any cap or limitation.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller, at Seller's sole cost and expense, shall terminate any Contracts that are not Assumed Contracts
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add cap on termination costs or require Buyer to share expenses above threshold.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise the sentence to limit Seller's exposure by adding: (i) a cap on termination costs Seller must bear, (ii) a requirement that Buyer assume contracts with termination costs exceeding a specified threshold, or (iii) a sharing mechanism where Buyer pays termination costs above a certain amount. Consider language such as: 'Seller, at Seller's cost and expense (not to exceed $[AMOUNT] in the aggregate), shall terminate any Contracts that are not Assumed Contracts; provided, however, that if the aggregate termination costs exceed $[AMOUNT], Buyer shall either assume such Contracts or pay the excess termination costs.'

risk_inventory.title: Buyer Has Unlimited Contract Selection Discretion
risk_inventory.description: Buyer has unfettered discretion to elect which contracts to assume and may elect to assume none of the Contracts. This one-sided approach allows Buyer to cherry-pick favorable contracts while forcing Seller to bear termination costs and potential liability for all others, with no requirement that Buyer's decisions be reasonable or made in good faith.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer shall designate on or before the Due Diligence Deadline which Contracts Buyer elects to assume at Closing
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require Buyer to act reasonably or assume contracts terminable without penalty.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Consider adding a reasonableness standard to Buyer's contract selection process, or require Buyer to assume contracts that are (i) terminable without penalty within a specified period, (ii) market-standard for properties of this type, or (iii) necessary for ongoing property operations. Alternative language: 'Buyer shall designate on or before the Due Diligence Deadline which Contracts Buyer elects to assume at Closing; provided that Buyer shall be required to assume any Contracts that are terminable on thirty (30) days or less notice without penalty.'

risk_inventory.title: Broad Buyer Consent Right Over Contract Amendments
risk_inventory.description: Seller cannot amend any Assumed Contracts without Buyer's prior consent, even though the 'not unreasonably withheld' standard applies. This limits Seller's operational flexibility during the period between contract designation and Closing, potentially preventing necessary amendments for property operations. Buyer could delay consent, creating operational difficulties.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: amend any of the Assumed Contracts without the prior consent of Buyer
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add deemed approval mechanism for amendments and time limit for Buyer response.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add a time-limited response requirement and deemed approval mechanism for amendments. Consider adding: 'Buyer shall respond to any such request within five (5) Business Days, failing which Buyer shall be deemed to have consented to such amendment. Notwithstanding the foregoing, Seller may amend any Assumed Contract without Buyer's consent if such amendment (i) does not increase the economic obligations under such Contract, (ii) does not extend the term beyond the existing term, and (iii) is reasonably necessary for the continued operation of the Property.'

risk_inventory.title: Limited Exception for New Service Contracts
risk_inventory.description: While the carve-out for new service contracts that are cancelable on 30 days' notice provides some operational flexibility, Seller must still pay all amounts owing under such contracts unless they become Assumed Contracts. This could create cash flow obligations during the interim period that Seller cannot recover.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: as to which all amounts owing thereunder have been or shall be paid by Seller unless they become an Assumed Contract
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Clarify that interim contract costs are prorated at Closing if assumed.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Clarify the treatment of amounts paid by Seller under interim service contracts by adding: 'provided, further, that if any such service contract becomes an Assumed Contract, Seller shall receive a credit at Closing for any prepaid amounts applicable to periods after Closing, and Buyer shall reimburse Seller at Closing for any reasonable amounts paid by Seller under such contract during the period between execution thereof and Closing.'

risk_inventory.title: Extensive Notice Obligations on Seller
risk_inventory.description: Seller has broad obligations to notify Buyer 'promptly' of numerous categories of matters including tenant defaults, contract disputes, condemnation, environmental matters, zoning proceedings, violations, litigation, and claims. The 'promptly' standard is vague and creates risk that Seller could be found in breach for delayed notification even of minor matters. The scope is very broad and could be burdensome to administer.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller shall notify or shall cause its property manager to notify Buyer of any written notice received by Seller or its property manager of any of the following matters promptly after Seller or its property manager has knowledge of such matter
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Define 'promptly' as specific timeframe and add materiality qualifier.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise the notification provision to provide clarity and limit exposure: (i) define 'promptly' as a specific timeframe (e.g., 'within five (5) Business Days'), (ii) add a materiality threshold for required notifications, and (iii) limit the knowledge standard to actual knowledge of Seller's Designated Representatives. Consider: 'Seller shall notify Buyer within five (5) Business Days after any Designated Representative obtains actual knowledge of any material written notice received by Seller regarding the following matters...'

risk_inventory.title: Insurance Maintenance Obligation Through Closing
risk_inventory.description: Seller must maintain existing insurance coverage with premiums paid through Closing Date. While standard, this obligates Seller to continue paying insurance premiums even if Closing is delayed by Buyer-caused extensions, potentially increasing Seller's carrying costs without recourse.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller shall maintain in full force and effect its existing insurance coverage with premiums paid through the Closing Date
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require Buyer to reimburse insurance costs for any Buyer-caused Closing delays.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add a provision requiring Buyer to reimburse Seller for insurance premium costs attributable to any extension of the Closing Date requested or caused by Buyer. Consider adding: 'In the event the Closing Date is extended at Buyer's request or due to Buyer's failure to satisfy a condition to Closing within Buyer's control, Buyer shall reimburse Seller at Closing for the pro rata portion of insurance premiums paid by Seller attributable to the period of such extension.'

risk_inventory.title: Buyer Consent Required for Material Alterations
risk_inventory.description: Seller cannot make 'material alterations' to the Property without Buyer's prior written approval. The term 'material' is undefined, creating ambiguity about what alterations require consent. Additionally, there is no deemed approval mechanism if Buyer fails to respond, potentially allowing Buyer to delay necessary property improvements through inaction.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller shall not make any material alterations to the Property without Buyer's prior written approval
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Define 'material alterations' with dollar threshold and add deemed approval timeline.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to provide certainty by: (i) defining 'material alterations' with a specific dollar threshold, (ii) adding a deemed approval mechanism, and (iii) carving out emergency repairs. Consider: 'Seller shall not make any alterations to the Property costing in excess of $[50,000] individually or $[150,000] in the aggregate ('Material Alterations') without Buyer's prior written approval (which approval shall not be unreasonably withheld, conditioned, or delayed and shall be deemed granted if Buyer fails to respond within five (5) Business Days after written request); provided, however, that Seller may make emergency repairs necessary to protect life, safety, or property without Buyer's prior consent.'

risk_inventory.title: Missing Closing Parenthesis in Approval Standard
risk_inventory.description: There is a typographical error in this provision - the parenthetical phrase regarding Buyer's approval standard is missing the closing parenthesis. While likely a minor drafting oversight, this could create ambiguity in interpretation.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: (which approval shall not be unreasonably withheld, conditioned, or delayed.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add closing parenthesis after 'delayed.'
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Correct the typographical error by adding a closing parenthesis after 'delayed' so the sentence reads: '...without Buyer's prior written approval (which approval shall not be unreasonably withheld, conditioned, or delayed).'

risk_inventory.title: Vague Cooperation Standard Creates Disputes
risk_inventory.description: The phrase 'reasonably cooperate' is subjective and undefined, which could lead to disputes about whether Seller has fulfilled its obligations. Buyer could claim Seller's cooperation was insufficient even when Seller believes it acted reasonably. Additionally, the obligation to 'request financial information' from tenants is open-ended and could require ongoing efforts.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller shall reasonably cooperate with Buyer's efforts to obtain financing for its acquisition of the Property
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Define specific cooperation tasks with clear limits on duration and scope.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Replace 'reasonably cooperate' with a defined list of specific cooperation items Seller agrees to perform, with express limitations. Add language such as: 'Seller's cooperation obligations shall be limited to: (i) providing not more than [2] sets of financial information requests to tenants during the period prior to Closing; (ii) delivering estoppel certificate and SNDA request forms prepared by Buyer to tenants within [5] Business Days of receipt; and (iii) permitting not more than [2] lender inspections of the Property. Seller shall have no obligation to negotiate with tenants regarding the content of estoppels or SNDAs or to take any action beyond delivery of Buyer's requests.'

risk_inventory.title: Ambiguous Lease Enforcement Obligation
risk_inventory.description: Seller is required to 'enforce' estoppel and SNDA requirements in leases. While there is a carve-out for filing claims or incurring substantial costs, the term 'substantial' is undefined and subjective. This could create disputes about what level of enforcement is required and expose Seller to claims of breach if Buyer believes enforcement efforts were insufficient.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: enforcing such requirements for estoppel certificates and SNDAs to the extent the same may be required under the Leases (but without any need to file claims or incur substantial costs)
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Define 'substantial costs' with a dollar threshold and limit enforcement to written requests only.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise the enforcement language to clearly limit Seller's obligations. Replace with: 'Seller's enforcement obligations shall be limited to delivering written notices to tenants requesting compliance with estoppel and SNDA requirements under the applicable Leases, but Seller shall have no obligation to (a) file any legal action, (b) incur costs in excess of $[500] in connection with such enforcement, (c) threaten or pursue lease termination or default remedies, or (d) negotiate estoppel or SNDA content with any tenant.'

risk_inventory.title: Mandatory Cure Period for All Condition Failures
risk_inventory.description: Seller is given only 5 Business Days to cure any condition failure before Buyer can terminate. While a cure period is protective, certain conditions (such as title matters or third-party estoppels) may be impossible to cure within 5 Business Days, yet Buyer cannot terminate until this period expires. This could also delay Seller's ability to remarket the property. More critically, this applies even to conditions outside Seller's control.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer shall not terminate this Agreement without giving Seller notice of the failure of such condition and a period of 5 Business Days after delivery of such notice for Seller to cause such condition to be satisfied
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Limit cure period to conditions within Seller's reasonable control.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Modify the cure period provision to distinguish between conditions Seller can control and those it cannot. Add: 'provided, further, that the foregoing 5 Business Day cure period shall only apply to conditions that are within Seller's reasonable control to satisfy (such as Seller's performance of covenants under Section 10.1.1), and shall not apply to conditions dependent upon third parties or circumstances outside Seller's reasonable control (such as the conditions set forth in Sections 10.1.2, 10.1.3, and any loan assumption approval condition).'

risk_inventory.title: Broad Buyer Termination Right with Deposit Return
risk_inventory.description: Buyer can terminate and receive the Earnest Money Deposit back if ANY of the closing conditions are not satisfied, regardless of fault. This includes conditions that depend on third parties (Title Company, tenants for estoppels, lender for loan assumption) and are outside Seller's control. Seller bears the risk of deal failure for circumstances it cannot control, yet loses the benefit of the Earnest Money Deposit.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: If any of the conditions described below are not satisfied (or waived in writing by Buyer) prior to the Closing, then Buyer shall be entitled to: (a) to terminate this Agreement and receive the Earnest Money Deposit
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Limit deposit return to conditions within Seller's control or caused by Seller's default.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add qualification to the deposit return provision: 'Buyer shall be entitled to receive the Earnest Money Deposit upon termination under this Section 10.1 only if the failed condition is (i) within Seller's reasonable control to satisfy, (ii) results from Seller's default or material breach of this Agreement, or (iii) is expressly designated elsewhere in this Agreement as entitling Buyer to return of the Earnest Money Deposit. For conditions dependent on third parties or circumstances outside Seller's control, the parties shall share the risk and, upon termination, the Earnest Money Deposit shall be [split equally between Buyer and Seller / retained by Seller as compensation for taking the Property off the market].'

risk_inventory.title: Representations Must Remain True Through Closing
risk_inventory.description: Seller's representations must not only be true at signing but must 'remain true and correct in all material respects' through Closing. This creates ongoing exposure for matters that may change between signing and closing due to circumstances outside Seller's control (e.g., a new governmental notice, tenant bankruptcy). While the 'material respects' qualifier provides some protection, Seller bears risk for changed circumstances.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: such representations and warranties shall have remained true and correct in all material respects
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add knowledge qualifier and limit to matters within Seller's control.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Consider adding protective language: 'such representations and warranties shall have remained true and correct in all material respects as of Closing, except for changes (i) resulting from actions taken by Seller with Buyer's prior written consent, (ii) disclosed in writing to Buyer prior to Closing and accepted by Buyer, or (iii) arising from matters outside Seller's reasonable control that do not have a Material Adverse Effect on the Property.' Define Material Adverse Effect with a dollar threshold if desired.

risk_inventory.title: Title Company Commitment as Buyer Condition
risk_inventory.description: Buyer's obligation to close is conditioned on Title Company being 'irrevocably committed' to issue the Title Policy. This is a third-party condition outside Seller's control. If Title Company has issues (staffing, internal policy changes, disputes over coverage) that prevent it from being 'irrevocably committed,' Buyer can terminate and receive its deposit back even though Seller did nothing wrong.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: The Title Company shall be irrevocably committed and ready, willing and able to issue the Title Policy
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require Buyer to work in good faith to resolve Title Company issues before terminating.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add protective language: 'The Title Company shall be irrevocably committed and ready, willing and able to issue the Title Policy; provided, however, that if the Title Company's failure to be so committed results from matters other than defects in Seller's title or Seller's failure to deliver required title clearance documents, Buyer shall use commercially reasonable efforts for a period of [10] Business Days to obtain such commitment from an alternative nationally-recognized title insurance company before exercising any termination right under this Section.'

risk_inventory.title: Loan Assumption Approval as Buyer Condition
risk_inventory.description: If this optional provision is included, Buyer's obligation to close is conditioned on obtaining the Existing Loan Assumption Approval. Lender approval is entirely outside Seller's control and depends on Buyer's creditworthiness and lender's discretion. Yet if approval is not obtained, Buyer can presumably terminate and receive its deposit back, leaving Seller with no deal and no compensation for taking the property off market.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: The Existing Loan Assumption Approval has been obtained
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Make loan assumption Buyer's risk or require deposit going hard after diligence.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: If this provision is included, add significant protections: 'The Existing Loan Assumption Approval has been obtained; provided, however, that (i) Buyer shall diligently pursue such approval in good faith, including promptly providing all information and documentation requested by Existing Lender, (ii) if such approval has not been obtained by [DATE] due to Buyer's failure to diligently pursue such approval or Buyer's failure to satisfy Existing Lender's underwriting requirements, Buyer shall not be entitled to terminate this Agreement or receive return of the Earnest Money Deposit, and (iii) Buyer's right to terminate under this condition shall expire on [DATE], after which Buyer shall be obligated to close or be in default.' Alternatively, consider making this a Buyer-only risk with no termination right.

risk_inventory.title: Burdensome Estoppel Threshold for Closing
risk_inventory.description: This condition requires Seller to obtain Conforming Tenant Estoppels from ALL Major Tenants plus additional tenants covering at least 80% of leased square footage. This is a high bar that gives Buyer significant leverage since Seller cannot control tenant responsiveness. If even one Major Tenant fails to provide a conforming estoppel, the condition fails regardless of the 80% threshold for other tenants. The conjunctive 'all of the Major Tenants plus' language creates a dual requirement that could allow Buyer to walk away from the deal even if substantially all tenants have provided estoppels.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: all of the Major Tenants plus a sufficient number of other Tenants under Leases so that Buyer has received Conforming Tenant Estoppels for Leases covering at least 80%
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Reduce to Major Tenants OR 80% threshold, add Seller estoppel option
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise this condition to be less burdensome on Seller by: (1) changing 'all of the Major Tenants plus' to 'Major Tenants representing at least [X]% of leased square footage and' making it an alternative rather than cumulative requirement; (2) reducing the 80% threshold to 70% or 75%; (3) adding language permitting Seller to provide a Seller estoppel certificate (with liability capped and limited survival) in lieu of any non-responsive tenant estoppels; and (4) adding a materiality qualifier such that minor deviations in tenant estoppels from lease terms do not render them non-conforming. Consider adding: 'provided, however, that if a tenant fails to deliver an estoppel despite Seller's commercially reasonable efforts, Seller may deliver a Seller's Estoppel Certificate with respect to such tenant's Lease, which shall satisfy this condition with respect to such tenant.'

risk_inventory.title: Conforming Tenant Estoppels Undefined Here
risk_inventory.description: The term 'Conforming Tenant Estoppels' is critical to this closing condition but is not defined in this section. If the definition elsewhere in the agreement is broad or allows Buyer significant discretion in determining what 'conforms,' Seller faces risk that estoppels may be rejected on technical grounds, potentially allowing Buyer to avoid closing even when tenants have substantially confirmed lease terms.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Conforming Tenant Estoppels
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify definition of Conforming Tenant Estoppels limits Buyer discretion
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Review the definition of 'Conforming Tenant Estoppels' in Section 7.1 or elsewhere in the Agreement to ensure it includes objective standards and does not grant Buyer subjective discretion to reject estoppels. If the definition allows Buyer to reject estoppels for immaterial discrepancies or contains 'Buyer's satisfaction' language, recommend revising to include objective standards with materiality thresholds. Consider adding language that deviations are only non-conforming if they reveal a material adverse difference from the rent roll or could materially impact the value or operation of the Property.

risk_inventory.title: Seller Has Shorter Practical Cure Rights Than Buyer
risk_inventory.description: While Section 10.2 provides Seller with a 5 Business Day notice and cure period before terminating for Buyer's failure of conditions, this is a relatively short period for Buyer to cure certain failures. However, reviewing the Buyer's conditions in Section 10.1, there appears to be no reciprocal notice and cure period for Seller before Buyer can terminate. This asymmetry favors Buyer and should be addressed by either reducing Seller's obligation to provide cure notice or ensuring Buyer has a similar obligation to notify Seller of condition failures with a cure period.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller shall not terminate this Agreement without giving Buyer notice of the failure of such condition, and a period of 5 Business Days after delivery of such notice for Buyer to cause such condition to be satisfied
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add reciprocal notice and cure requirement for Buyer's termination rights
risk_inventory.model_instructions: This cure period provision benefits Buyer but creates asymmetry. Either: (1) remove this cure period requirement to put parties on equal footing, or (2) add parallel language to Section 10.1 requiring Buyer to give Seller notice of any failed Buyer's condition and a cure period of at least 5 Business Days (or preferably 10 Business Days for conditions within Seller's control like document delivery or estoppels) before Buyer may terminate. Also consider whether the 5 Business Day cure period is sufficient for Buyer to cure performance defaults and whether a shorter period would be more protective of Seller's interests.

risk_inventory.title: Material Respects Qualifier May Be Subjective
risk_inventory.description: The 'in all material respects' qualifier for Buyer's covenant performance provides appropriate flexibility but could be subject to interpretation disputes. While this is generally a balanced standard, Seller should ensure the Agreement does not elsewhere define 'material' in a way that is overly favorable to Buyer or that Buyer's key obligations (such as funding at Closing) are not subject to this materiality qualifier.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: in all material respects
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Acceptable standard; verify key payment obligations not subject to materiality
risk_inventory.model_instructions: This is a market-standard formulation that is generally acceptable for Seller. However, verify that Buyer's core obligations—particularly the obligation to deliver the Purchase Price at Closing under Section 11.5.1—are not subject to this materiality qualifier. Payment obligations should be absolute. No changes required to this specific provision unless Buyer seeks to weaken it further.

risk_inventory.title: Double Materiality Standard is Favorable
risk_inventory.description: This provision contains both 'no material breach' and 'true and correct in all material respects' qualifiers, which is protective of Buyer by providing a double layer of materiality requirements. From Seller's perspective, this is favorable as it requires symmetry—Seller should verify that Seller's equivalent condition in Section 10.1 contains similar materiality qualifiers for Seller's representations. This ensures Buyer cannot terminate for immaterial breaches of Seller's representations while Seller must tolerate material breaches of Buyer's representations.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: no material breach of any representations and warranties made by Buyer in Article 6 above, and such representations, warranties or covenants shall have remained true and correct in all material respects
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm equivalent materiality protection exists for Seller's reps in 10.1
risk_inventory.model_instructions: This provision is favorable to Seller in that it requires materiality for both breach and accuracy of Buyer's representations. Verify that Buyer's closing condition regarding Seller's representations (likely in Section 10.1 or incorporated by reference) contains equivalent materiality qualifiers. If Buyer's condition regarding Seller's representations does not include materiality qualifiers, recommend adding them to achieve symmetry. The current formulation for Buyer's reps is market-standard and protective of Seller.

risk_inventory.title: Closing Condition Tied to Buyer Deliveries
risk_inventory.description: This seller closing condition simply requires Buyer to deliver specified items per Section 11.5. While this is appropriate, Seller should verify that Section 11.5 contains all necessary buyer deliverables and that there are no gaps in required documentation that could create closing complications or leave Seller without necessary protections.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer's delivery to escrow of the funds, documents and items specified in Section 11.5 below
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify Section 11.5 contains all required Buyer deliverables.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Review Section 11.5 (p_137 through p_143) to confirm all necessary buyer deliverables are included. Consider whether Seller needs any additional documents not currently listed, such as: (1) evidence of Buyer's entity authorization/good standing, (2) assignment and assumption agreements for any assumed obligations, (3) required consents or approvals Buyer is responsible for obtaining, (4) Buyer's representations certificate at closing. If gaps exist, add the required items to Section 11.5 and ensure this cross-reference captures them.

risk_inventory.title: Mutual Extension Right is Balanced
risk_inventory.description: This provision grants both parties equal one-business-day extension rights with a nominal $5,000 payment. While facially balanced, Seller should be aware this gives Buyer an additional day to close beyond the scheduled date, which could delay Seller's receipt of proceeds and create uncertainty. The provision does appropriately require the payment to be funded (for Buyer) in advance.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Each of Buyer and Seller shall have the right to extend the Closing Date one time by 1 Business Day
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider whether $5,000 adequately compensates for one-day delay.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: The mutual one-business-day extension is relatively standard but consider whether the $5,000 payment adequately compensates Seller for a closing delay. For a significant transaction, Seller may want to increase this amount or require Buyer to provide evidence of readiness to close before exercising this right. If modification is desired, revise to state: 'Each of Buyer and Seller shall have the right to extend the Closing Date one time by 1 Business Day by delivering notice on or before the Closing Date of such extension to the other party and authorizing (and in the case of Buyer additionally funding) a $10,000 payment to the other party at Closing through escrow; provided, however, Buyer may only exercise such right if Buyer demonstrates to Seller's reasonable satisfaction that Buyer is ready, willing and able to close except for administrative matters requiring the additional day.'

risk_inventory.title: Buyer Has 20-Day Unilateral Extension
risk_inventory.description: This provision grants Buyer a unilateral right to extend closing by up to 20 Business Days (approximately one month of calendar time) with only a 50% additional deposit requirement. This is a significant risk to Seller as it creates substantial uncertainty about closing timing, ties up the Property for an extended period, delays Seller's receipt of proceeds, and may cause Seller to miss other opportunities or incur holding costs. The 'diligent and good faith effort' standard is subjective and difficult to enforce.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer shall have the right to extend the Closing Date one time for up to 20 Business Days
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Reduce extension period, increase deposit, or add objective conditions.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: This buyer-favorable extension right should be significantly modified to protect Seller. Consider the following revisions: (1) Reduce the extension period from 20 Business Days to 10 Business Days maximum; (2) Increase the additional deposit from 50% to 100% of the original Earnest Money; (3) Make the additional deposit non-refundable to Seller if Buyer fails to close during the extension; (4) Replace the subjective 'diligent and good faith effort' standard with objective conditions such as requiring Buyer to demonstrate that financing commitment is in place and only administrative/ministerial matters remain; (5) Require Buyer to identify the specific reason for the extension. Suggested revision: '11.2.2 Additional Buyer's Extension Option. If Buyer has obtained a binding financing commitment and is otherwise ready, willing and able to close but requires additional time solely to complete administrative closing mechanics, Buyer shall have the right to extend the Closing Date one time for up to 10 Business Days by delivering notice on or before the Closing Date identifying the specific reason for extension and, within 2 Business Days after delivering such notice, depositing with Escrow Agent in cash an amount equal to 100% of the original Earnest Money Deposit (the "Extension Deposit"). If Buyer fails to close during the extension period for any reason other than Seller default, the Extension Deposit shall be released to Seller as additional liquidated damages.'

risk_inventory.title: Subjective Good Faith Effort Standard
risk_inventory.description: The condition that Buyer must have made 'diligent and good faith effort to close' before exercising the extension option is subjective and difficult for Seller to verify or challenge. Buyer could claim good faith efforts while actually delaying intentionally, and Seller would bear the burden of proving otherwise. This creates uncertainty and potential for disputes.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: despite Buyer's diligent and good faith effort to close on the scheduled Closing Date
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Replace subjective standard with objective closing readiness requirements.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Replace the vague 'diligent and good faith effort' language with objective, verifiable conditions. Revised language: 'If Buyer (a) has obtained all necessary internal approvals and financing commitments, (b) has deposited all required funds with Escrow Agent, (c) has delivered or is prepared to deliver all documents required under Section 11.5, and (d) requires additional time solely due to circumstances beyond Buyer's reasonable control (which Buyer shall identify in writing), Buyer shall have the right to extend the Closing Date...' This provides Seller with clear, objective criteria to evaluate whether Buyer is entitled to the extension.

risk_inventory.title: Extension Deposit Becomes Refundable Earnest Money
risk_inventory.description: The additional deposit required for the extension becomes part of the Earnest Money Deposit, meaning it would be refundable to Buyer in circumstances where the original Earnest Money is refundable. Seller takes on extended closing risk without additional protection. The extension deposit should be non-refundable or at least harder-earned to adequately compensate Seller for the delay.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: which amount the Escrow Agent will deposit and hold in the same interest bearing account as the Earnest Money Deposit and shall, upon being deposited, constitute part of the Earnest Money Deposit
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Make extension deposit non-refundable or independent of Earnest Money.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Modify the treatment of the extension deposit to provide Seller with meaningful compensation for agreeing to delay closing. Revised language: '...depositing with Escrow Agent, in cash an amount equal to 50% of the original Earnest Money Deposit (the "Extension Deposit"). The Extension Deposit shall be held by Escrow Agent separately from the Earnest Money Deposit. The Extension Deposit shall be non-refundable to Buyer and shall be released to Seller upon disbursement of funds at Closing as a credit against the Purchase Price; provided, however, if Buyer fails to close during the extension period for any reason other than Seller's default or the failure of a Buyer closing condition set forth in Section 10.1, the Extension Deposit shall be immediately released to Seller as additional consideration for granting the extension, independent of and in addition to any liquidated damages to which Seller may be entitled under Section 13.2.'

risk_inventory.title: Recording Contingent on Both Parties' Deposits
risk_inventory.description: The closing mechanics require both Seller's and Buyer's documents to be deposited before the Escrow Agent will record the deed. If Buyer fails to timely deposit required items, closing is delayed through no fault of Seller. While this is standard escrow practice, the provision should be paired with clear consequences for Buyer's failure to timely deposit, which should trigger default provisions.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Provided that all funds and documents required under Sections 11.4 and 11.5 below have been deposited into escrow
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure Buyer's failure to deposit triggers default provisions.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add language clarifying that Buyer's failure to timely deposit required funds and documents constitutes a default. After the existing sentence, add: 'Buyer's failure to deposit all funds and documents required under Section 11.5 by the Deposit Deadline shall constitute a default by Buyer under this Agreement, entitling Seller to the remedies set forth in Section 13.2. For the avoidance of doubt, if Seller has deposited all items required under Section 11.4 by the Deposit Deadline but Buyer has not deposited all items required under Section 11.5 by such time, Buyer shall be in default and Seller shall have no obligation to proceed with Closing.'

risk_inventory.title: Placeholder for Local Time Zone
risk_inventory.description: The provision contains a placeholder '***INSERT LOCAL TIME***' that must be completed before execution. Failure to specify the correct time zone could create ambiguity about the actual deadline, particularly if parties are in different time zones.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: no later than 3:00 pm ***INSERT LOCAL TIME*** on the Closing Date
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure time zone is specified before execution (e.g., Pacific Time).
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Replace the placeholder with the specific time zone applicable to the Property location. Since the Property appears to be in Seattle, Washington based on the Escrow Agent address, the provision should read: 'no later than 3:00 pm Pacific Time on the Closing Date'. Ensure consistency with any other time references in the Agreement.

risk_inventory.title: Special Warranty Deed Appropriate for Seller
risk_inventory.description: The use of a Special Warranty Deed rather than a General Warranty Deed is favorable to Seller as it limits Seller's warranty of title to defects arising only during Seller's period of ownership. This is market-standard for commercial transactions and appropriately protects Seller from claims regarding title defects that predate Seller's ownership. No changes recommended.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: One Special Warranty Deed
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: No action needed - Special Warranty Deed is appropriate for Seller.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: No modifications required. The Special Warranty Deed form is favorable to Seller as it limits title warranties to the period of Seller's ownership only, which is the market-standard approach for commercial real estate transactions.

risk_inventory.title: Lease Assignment Without Liability Release
risk_inventory.description: The Assignment and Assumption of Leases assigns landlord obligations to Buyer, but the clause does not explicitly reference that Buyer assumes all obligations arising from and after Closing or that Seller is released from post-Closing obligations. Without clear release language in the assignment document (Exhibit F), Seller could remain liable to tenants for landlord obligations even after Closing. This risk depends on the specific language in Exhibit F, which should be reviewed.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Two counterparts of the Assignment and Assumption of Leases executed by Seller in the form attached hereto as Exhibit F
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure Exhibit F includes express release of Seller from post-Closing landlord obligations.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Review Exhibit F (Lease Assignment) to confirm it contains: (1) Buyer's express assumption of all landlord obligations arising from and after Closing; (2) Buyer's indemnification of Seller for all claims arising from Buyer's acts or omissions as landlord after Closing; and (3) if possible, language releasing Seller from all lease obligations accruing after Closing. If these protections are not in Exhibit F, add them or include a cross-reference here requiring such provisions.

risk_inventory.title: Contract Assignment Without Liability Release
risk_inventory.description: Similar to the Lease Assignment, the Assignment and Assumption of Contracts and Intangibles should include express assumption by Buyer of all obligations arising after Closing and an indemnification of Seller. The risk is that Seller could remain liable to vendors and service providers under assigned contracts if Buyer defaults on post-Closing obligations. The specific terms of Exhibit G should be reviewed to confirm adequate protection.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Two counterparts of the Assignment and Assumption of Contracts and Intangibles executed by Seller in the form attached hereto as Exhibit G
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure Exhibit G includes Buyer's assumption and indemnification for post-Closing obligations.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Review Exhibit G (Contract Assignment) to confirm it contains: (1) Buyer's express assumption of all obligations under the assigned contracts arising from and after Closing; (2) Buyer's indemnification of Seller for all claims, liabilities, and costs arising from Buyer's failure to perform obligations under assigned contracts after Closing; and (3) clear delineation that Seller remains responsible only for obligations accruing prior to Closing. If these protections are not in Exhibit G, they should be added.

risk_inventory.title: Bill of Sale Warranty Scope
risk_inventory.description: The Bill of Sale conveys personal property. Seller should ensure that Exhibit H provides only limited warranties (such as 'AS-IS' or warranty of title only without warranty of condition) consistent with the AS-IS provisions in Section 2.2. If the Bill of Sale contains broader warranties regarding the condition of personal property, it could create inconsistency with the AS-IS framework and expose Seller to claims.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Two counterparts of the Bill of Sale for the Personal Property executed by Seller in the form attached hereto as Exhibit H
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm Exhibit H Bill of Sale is consistent with AS-IS provisions.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Review Exhibit H (Bill of Sale) to confirm that: (1) personal property is conveyed 'AS-IS, WHERE-IS' without warranty of condition, consistent with Section 2.2; (2) Seller warrants only that it has title to the personal property and the right to convey it; and (3) there are no express or implied warranties of merchantability, fitness for a particular purpose, or condition. If the Bill of Sale contains broader warranties, revise to align with the AS-IS framework established in Section 2.2.

risk_inventory.title: Deposit Timing Linked to Closing
risk_inventory.description: The phrase 'On or before Closing' for Seller's delivery obligations is standard and appropriate. However, Seller should coordinate with Escrow Agent regarding actual timing of deposits to ensure closing mechanics in Section 11.3 are satisfied and there is no risk of Buyer claiming Seller failed to timely deposit required items.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: On or before Closing, Seller shall deposit into escrow the following items
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Coordinate with Escrow Agent on delivery timing before scheduled Closing.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: No substantive changes required to the contract language. The timing 'On or before Closing' is standard. Advise Seller to coordinate with Escrow Agent (First American Title) in advance of Closing to ensure all documents are deposited with sufficient time for review and to avoid any claim by Buyer that closing conditions were not timely satisfied. Consider establishing an internal deadline of 1-2 business days before Closing for delivery of all Seller documents.

risk_inventory.title: Unlimited Title Company Document Requirements
risk_inventory.description: This provision obligates Seller to provide not only the Owner's Title Affidavit but also 'such other documents as may be reasonably or customarily required by the Title Company or Escrow Agent.' This open-ended language gives the Title Company and Escrow Agent significant discretion to demand additional documents from Seller at closing, potentially creating unexpected obligations, delays, or liability exposure. While qualified by 'reasonably or customarily,' these standards are subjective and could be interpreted broadly by the Title Company.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: such other documents as may be reasonably or customarily required by the Title Company or Escrow Agent to issue the Title Policy and close this transaction
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add specificity or cap on additional document requirements.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to limit the scope of additional documents Seller must provide. Consider language such as: 'such other documents as may be reasonably required by the Title Company or Escrow Agent to issue the Title Policy and close this transaction, provided that (i) such documents shall be limited to customary affidavits and certifications that do not expand Seller's liability beyond what is expressly set forth in this Agreement, (ii) Seller shall not be required to provide any documents that would impose additional representations, warranties, or indemnities beyond those contained herein, and (iii) Seller shall have reasonable opportunity to review and approve the form of any such documents prior to execution.'

risk_inventory.title: Unlimited Lender Document Requirements for Assumption
risk_inventory.description: This optional provision requires Seller to execute 'Existing Loan Assumption Documents that Existing Lender is requiring' without any limitation on scope, content, or liability. Lenders in assumption scenarios often require broad indemnities, representations, and ongoing obligations from sellers. This provision gives the Existing Lender carte blanche to impose whatever document requirements it wishes, potentially exposing Seller to significant post-closing liability, indemnification obligations, or other burdensome terms that are not contemplated elsewhere in this Agreement.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: The Existing Loan Assumption Documents that Existing Lender is requiring Seller or other Seller-related parties to execute and deliver at Closing to carry out the assumption of the Existing Loan
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add limitations on lender-required documents and Seller's obligations.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to protect Seller from unlimited lender requirements. Suggested language: 'The Existing Loan Assumption Documents that Existing Lender is requiring Seller or other Seller-related parties to execute and deliver at Closing to carry out the assumption of the Existing Loan; provided, however, that (i) Seller shall not be required to execute any documents that impose indemnification obligations, representations, warranties, or covenants that survive Closing other than as expressly set forth in this Agreement, (ii) Seller shall not be required to execute any guaranty or remain liable for any obligations under the Existing Loan following Closing, (iii) any documents requiring Seller's execution shall be in form reasonably acceptable to Seller, and (iv) Buyer shall indemnify and hold Seller harmless from any claims arising from the Existing Loan from and after Closing, except to the extent arising from Seller's fraud or intentional misrepresentation.'

risk_inventory.title: Broad Post-Closing Document Delivery Obligation
risk_inventory.description: This provision requires Seller to deliver 'all keys,' 'originals' of Leases, Estoppels, Contracts, and 'other Due Diligence Materials' to Buyer. The phrase 'other Due Diligence Materials' is very broad and undefined, potentially encompassing a wide range of documents. Additionally, requiring delivery of 'all' keys and 'originals' creates an absolute standard that may be difficult to fully satisfy, potentially giving Buyer grounds to claim non-performance even for minor oversights.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: all keys to the Property and originals to the extent in Seller's possession and otherwise copies of all Leases, Conforming Tenant Estoppels, Assumed Contracts and other Due Diligence Materials
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Qualify with knowledge/possession limitations throughout.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to add appropriate qualifiers and specificity: 'Upon Closing, Seller shall deliver to Buyer outside of escrow, to the extent in Seller's actual possession and control, (i) keys to the Property that are in Seller's or Seller's property manager's possession, (ii) originals (or copies if originals are not in Seller's possession) of the Leases, Conforming Tenant Estoppels, and Assumed Contracts, and (iii) copies of any other Due Diligence Materials previously identified by Buyer in writing prior to Closing that are in Seller's possession. Seller makes no representation that it possesses all keys to the Property or all originals of the foregoing documents, and Seller's inadvertent failure to deliver any such items shall not constitute a default hereunder or give rise to any liability.'

risk_inventory.title: No Time Limit for Post-Closing Delivery
risk_inventory.description: The provision states delivery occurs 'Upon Closing' but does not specify a deadline for items delivered 'outside of escrow.' This creates ambiguity about when Seller must complete delivery and potentially leaves Seller exposed to claims for delayed delivery indefinitely after closing.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Upon Closing, Seller shall deliver to Buyer outside of escrow
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add reasonable timeframe for post-closing deliveries.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to add a specific timeframe: 'Within five (5) Business Days following Closing, Seller shall deliver to Buyer outside of escrow, to the extent in Seller's possession and control...' This provides clarity and a definite endpoint for Seller's delivery obligation.

risk_inventory.title: Undefined 'Additional Funds' Requirement
risk_inventory.description: The phrase 'such additional funds as are necessary to close this transaction' is vague and open-ended. While intended to cover closing costs and prorations, this language could theoretically be interpreted broadly by Buyer to limit amounts deposited or create disputes about what funds are 'necessary.' From Seller's perspective, this should be tied more specifically to the closing statement and defined obligations to ensure Buyer deposits all required amounts without dispute.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: such additional funds as are necessary to close this transaction
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Specify that funds must match the closing statement calculations.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise the clause to read: 'The balance of the Purchase Price and such additional funds as are reflected on the Closing Statement prepared pursuant to Section 11.8 hereof, including without limitation all closing costs, prorations, and other amounts payable by Buyer pursuant to this Agreement.' This ties the obligation to the specific closing statement mechanism and clarifies Buyer's complete funding obligation.

risk_inventory.title: No Wire Deadline Specified
risk_inventory.description: The clause requires deposit of funds but does not specify a deadline within the closing day for when funds must be wired. Late-day wire transfers could delay closing or push recording to the following day, creating title gap exposure for Seller. While Section 11.3 addresses closing mechanics generally, a specific wire deadline for Buyer's funds would strengthen Seller's position.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: On or before Closing, Buyer shall deposit into escrow the following items
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider adding a specific wire deadline (e.g., 12:00 PM on Closing Date).
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add timing language to the lead-in to Section 11.5 (found in p_137) or to this specific subsection: 'Buyer shall cause all funds required under this Section 11.5.1 to be deposited with Escrow Agent in immediately available funds no later than 12:00 p.m. Pacific Time on the Closing Date, or such earlier time as required by Escrow Agent to ensure same-day recording and disbursement.' This protects Seller from late-day funding issues.

risk_inventory.title: No Cure Period for Document Delivery Failure
risk_inventory.description: If Buyer fails to deliver the executed Lease Assignment by closing, there is no express cure period before Seller can declare default. While this is generally favorable to Seller as it creates strict compliance requirements, Seller should be aware this cuts both ways under Section 11.4 obligations. The provision is adequately protective of Seller's interests.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Two counterparts of the Lease Assignment executed by Buyer
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: No change needed - strict compliance requirement benefits Seller.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: No modification required. The absence of a cure period for document delivery is appropriate and protects Seller by ensuring Buyer must have all documents ready at closing without additional time allowances.

risk_inventory.title: Open-Ended Loan Assumption Document Obligations
risk_inventory.description: This optional clause requires Buyer to execute whatever documents 'Existing Lender is requiring' without any limitation or reasonableness standard. While the obligation appropriately falls on Buyer, the lack of any qualifier could create closing delays if Buyer objects to lender-required documents as unreasonable. From Seller's perspective, this should be strengthened to clearly obligate Buyer to execute all lender-required documents without objection.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: The Existing Loan Assumption Documents that Existing Lender is requiring Buyer or other Buyer-related parties to execute and deliver
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add language requiring Buyer to execute all lender documents without objection.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Strengthen the clause to read: 'The Existing Loan Assumption Documents that Existing Lender is requiring Buyer or other Buyer-related parties to execute and deliver at Closing to carry out the assumption of the Existing Loan, which documents Buyer agrees to execute without objection so long as such documents are consistent with the terms of the Existing Loan and do not impose material obligations on Seller beyond those contemplated by this Agreement.' This clarifies Buyer's obligation while providing reasonable protection.

risk_inventory.title: Existing Loan Assumption Documents Not Defined
risk_inventory.description: The term 'Existing Loan Assumption Documents' is used but does not appear to be defined in the definitions section. This creates ambiguity about exactly what documents Buyer must execute. For Seller's protection, a clear definition should be added to ensure Buyer cannot dispute document requirements at closing.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: The Existing Loan Assumption Documents
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add definition of 'Existing Loan Assumption Documents' to Article 1.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add a definition to Article 1: '"Existing Loan Assumption Documents" means all documents, instruments, and agreements required by Existing Lender in connection with Buyer's assumption of the Existing Loan, including without limitation assumption agreements, loan modification agreements, legal opinions, organizational documents, guaranties (if required), environmental indemnities, and any other documents customarily required by lenders in connection with commercial mortgage loan assumptions.' This provides clarity and prevents closing disputes.

risk_inventory.title: Undefined Buyer Document Obligations
risk_inventory.description: This catch-all provision requires Buyer to deliver 'such other documents as may be reasonably or customarily required' by the Title Company or Escrow Agent. While limited by 'reasonably,' this creates potential for last-minute document demands that could delay closing or impose unexpected burdens. More critically from Seller's perspective, this open-ended language could give Buyer an argument to object to closing if they disagree about what documents are 'reasonable' or 'customary,' potentially creating a manufactured condition to closing.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Such other documents as may be reasonably or customarily required by the Title Company or Escrow Agent
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add time limit and clarify disputes don't delay closing.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to add: (i) a requirement that any such document requests be made at least 5 Business Days prior to Closing; (ii) language stating that Buyer's good faith disagreement about whether a requested document is reasonable or customary shall not constitute a failure of a closing condition or excuse Buyer's obligation to close; and (iii) clarify that such documents shall be limited to standard affidavits, certifications, or similar documents that do not impose material additional liability on Buyer.

risk_inventory.title: Unlimited Customary Seller Costs
risk_inventory.description: Subsection (e) obligates Seller to pay 'any additional costs and charges customarily charged to sellers in accordance with common escrow practices.' This open-ended language creates significant exposure for Seller as 'customary' practices may vary, evolve, or be interpreted broadly. Unlike the specific enumerated costs in (a)-(d), this catch-all has no cap and could result in unexpected closing costs being imposed on Seller based on Title Company or Escrow Agent assertions about local 'custom.'
risk_inventory.problematic_text: any additional costs and charges customarily charged to sellers in accordance with common escrow practices in the state and county in which the Property is located
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Delete catch-all or cap at specific dollar amount.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Either delete subsection (e) entirely, or replace it with: '(e) any additional costs and charges customarily charged to sellers in accordance with common escrow practices in the state and county in which the Property is located, provided that any such additional costs under this subsection (e) shall not exceed $5,000 in the aggregate without Seller's prior written consent.' Alternatively, require that any claimed 'customary' costs be documented in writing and agreed to by Seller at least 10 Business Days prior to Closing.

risk_inventory.title: Recording Costs Beyond Deed Unclear
risk_inventory.description: Seller is obligated to pay 'the cost of recording the Deed' but the agreement does not address who pays for recording other documents that may be required at closing (releases, termination statements, memoranda, etc.). This ambiguity could be resolved against Seller under the catch-all 'customary' provision or lead to closing disputes.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: the cost of recording the Deed
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Clarify Buyer pays for all other recording costs.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Modify subsection (c) to read: '(c) the cost of recording the Deed and any documents necessary to release liens or encumbrances that Seller is obligated to remove under this Agreement;' and add to Section 11.6.3: 'Buyer shall pay for the recording of all other documents, including any memoranda, financing documents, or other instruments Buyer elects to record.'

risk_inventory.title: Buyer Due Diligence Costs Confirmed
risk_inventory.description: The final sentence confirms Buyer is solely responsible for due diligence investigation costs, which is favorable to Seller. This is noted for completeness as it reinforces Seller's position, but Seller should ensure this is consistent with any due diligence materials delivery obligations in Section 3.3 that may require Seller to bear costs of producing existing reports.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer shall be solely responsible for any costs incurred in connection with Buyer's Due Diligence investigations of the Property, including Inspections and Surveys
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm consistency with Section 3.3 obligations.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Review Section 3.3 (Due Diligence Materials) to ensure there is no inconsistency. Consider adding clarifying language: 'For avoidance of doubt, Seller's obligation to deliver existing Due Diligence Materials under Section 3.3 shall not be deemed to make Seller responsible for any costs associated with Buyer's independent investigations, inspections, or due diligence activities.'

risk_inventory.title: Each Party Bears Own Legal Costs
risk_inventory.description: This provision requires each party to pay its own counsel costs, which is market-standard but worth noting. Seller should be aware this may not apply in default situations where Section 16.10 (Attorneys' Fees) provides the prevailing party may recover fees. Ensure this provision does not inadvertently limit Seller's fee recovery rights under the default provisions.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Each party shall pay for the costs of their respective counsel in connection with Closing and this transaction
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm this doesn't limit fee recovery in disputes.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add clarifying language at the end of Section 11.6.4: 'The foregoing allocation of legal costs is without prejudice to either party's right to recover attorneys' fees and costs as the prevailing party in any action or proceeding pursuant to Section 16.10 or any other provision of this Agreement.'

risk_inventory.title: Unlimited Survival for Tax Adjustments
risk_inventory.description: The proration provision for real estate taxes and assessments includes a surviving obligation for post-closing adjustments and refunds 'which obligation will survive the Closing' without any time limitation. This creates an open-ended liability for Seller to potentially owe Buyer money for tax-related adjustments that could arise years after Closing, with no cap on duration or amount.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: including any adjustments to real estate taxes and assessments and refunds of any payments thereof that are made following the Closing but relate to periods of time prior to Closing, which obligation will survive the Closing
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add time limit (e.g., 12-18 months) for tax adjustment survival.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Modify the surviving obligation language to include a time limitation. Replace 'which obligation will survive the Closing' with 'which obligation will survive the Closing for a period of eighteen (18) months following the Closing Date, after which neither party shall have any further obligation with respect thereto'. This aligns the tax proration survival with the general reconciliation period concepts while providing reasonable finality for Seller.

risk_inventory.title: Buyer Credited Full Closing Day
risk_inventory.description: The proration method deems Buyer to hold title and be entitled to income for the 'entire day upon which the Closing occurs.' This is inconsistent with Section 11.7.1 which prorates items 'as of 11:59 pm on the day immediately preceding the Closing Date.' This means Seller is charged through 11:59 pm the day before Closing, but Buyer is credited the entire Closing day - resulting in Seller losing one day of income attribution.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer shall be deemed to hold title to the Property and be entitled to the income therefrom and responsible for the expenses thereof for the entire day upon which the Closing occurs
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm proration cut-off is consistent between sections.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Review and harmonize the proration timing between Sections 11.7.1 and 11.7.2 to ensure consistency. Consider modifying to read: 'For purposes of calculating prorations, Buyer shall be deemed to hold title to the Property and be entitled to the income therefrom and responsible for the expenses thereof commencing at 12:00 a.m. on the Closing Date, consistent with the proration cut-off time set forth in Section 11.7.1.'

risk_inventory.title: Conditional Utility Deposit Credit
risk_inventory.description: Seller's credit for utility deposits is conditioned on the deposits being 'transferred to Buyer.'
