If utility companies do not transfer deposits (which is common - they often refund to the original depositor), Seller may not receive credit at Closing but must wait for a refund from the utility company, creating cash flow timing issues and administrative burden.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller shall be entitled to a credit at the Closing for any utility deposits which it or its predecessors have made prior to the Closing Date, to the extent the same are transferred to Buyer
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Guarantee Seller credit for all utility deposits regardless of transfer.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Modify the utility deposit credit provision to ensure Seller receives credit at Closing regardless of whether deposits are actually transferred. Replace the conditional language with: 'Seller shall be entitled to a credit at the Closing for any utility deposits which it or its predecessors have made prior to the Closing Date. To the extent such deposits are not transferred to Buyer and are instead refunded directly to Seller by the utility provider, Buyer shall have no claim to such refunds.'

risk_inventory.title: 60-Day Post-Closing Proration Window
risk_inventory.description: If utility accounts are not set up in Buyer's name on the Closing Date, charges are prorated 'within 60 days after the Closing Date.' This creates a 60-day window where Seller may need to continue paying utility bills and then seek reimbursement, with potential collection risk if Buyer disputes amounts.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: If accounts are not set up in Buyer's name on the Closing Date, all charges for such utilities shall be prorated outside of escrow within 60 days after the Closing Date.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require escrow holdback or immediate reimbursement mechanism for utilities.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Strengthen the utility proration mechanism to protect Seller. Add the following at the end of the utility proration sentence: 'If accounts are not set up in Buyer's name on the Closing Date, all charges for such utilities shall be prorated outside of escrow within 60 days after the Closing Date, and Buyer shall reimburse Seller within ten (10) Business Days after Seller's delivery of applicable invoices. Buyer shall indemnify Seller for any utility charges accruing from and after the Closing Date that are billed to or paid by Seller.'

risk_inventory.title: Unlimited Closing Extension for Statement Disputes
risk_inventory.description: Either party may extend the Closing Date if they cannot agree on the Closing Statement, with the extension continuing until '2 Business Days after the date on which the parties reach agreement.' This provision has no outer limit, meaning a disagreement over prorations could indefinitely delay Closing, giving Buyer leverage to extend Closing or renegotiate terms under the guise of a Closing Statement dispute.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: either party by written notice to the other party may elect to extend the Closing Date to such date that is 2 Business Days after the date on which the parties reach agreement upon the Closing Statement
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Cap extension period and add dispute resolution mechanism.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add a limitation on the Closing Statement extension right to prevent indefinite delays. Modify to read: 'either party by written notice to the other party may elect to extend the Closing Date to such date that is 2 Business Days after the date on which the parties reach agreement upon the Closing Statement; provided, however, that (i) no such extension shall exceed ten (10) Business Days beyond the original Closing Date, and (ii) if the parties cannot agree on the Closing Statement within such period, the parties shall close based on the preliminary closing statement prepared by Escrow Agent, with final reconciliation to occur pursuant to Section 11.9.'

risk_inventory.title: 90-Day Reconciliation Window
risk_inventory.description: The 90-day post-closing reconciliation period allows Buyer to claim adjustments for proration errors for three months after Closing. While this is not unusual, it creates a window where Seller may owe additional funds to Buyer. The provision does not cap the amount of potential adjustments, and places the burden on Seller to maintain records and respond to adjustment requests.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: provided, however, that any adjustment shall be made, if at all, within 90 days after the Closing Date
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider reducing to 60 days and adding de minimis threshold.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Modify the reconciliation provision to reduce Seller's exposure: 'provided, however, that any adjustment shall be made, if at all, within sixty (60) days after the Closing Date, and no adjustment shall be required if the net amount owed by one party to the other is less than Five Thousand Dollars ($5,000.00) in the aggregate.' This reduces the reconciliation window and adds a de minimis threshold to avoid disputes over minor amounts.

risk_inventory.title: Open-Ended Records Access Obligation
risk_inventory.description: Seller must afford Buyer and its 'representatives and auditors' reasonable access to Seller's books and records 'until final reconciliation.' Combined with the 90-day reconciliation period and potential for disputed items, this could require Seller to maintain and provide access to records for an extended period post-Closing, creating administrative burden.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Until final reconciliation under this Section, Buyer and its representatives and auditors shall be afforded reasonable access during normal business hours to Seller's books and records with respect to the Property to confirm the accuracy of the Closing Statement.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Limit scope and duration of records access obligation.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Modify the records access provision to limit Seller's burden: 'Until final reconciliation under this Section (but in no event longer than ninety (90) days after the Closing Date), Buyer and its representatives and auditors shall be afforded reasonable access during normal business hours, upon at least five (5) Business Days' prior written notice, to Seller's books and records with respect to the Property solely to confirm the accuracy of the items set forth in the Closing Statement. Seller shall have no obligation to retain such records beyond one (1) year after the Closing Date.'

risk_inventory.title: Escrow Agent Liability Limited to Gross Negligence
risk_inventory.description: The escrow agent's liability is limited to 'willful misconduct or gross negligence,' which is a very high standard that effectively insulates the escrow agent from most claims of ordinary negligence. If the escrow agent makes errors in handling the earnest money deposit or closing funds that don't rise to the level of gross negligence, neither party (including Seller) would have meaningful recourse. While this is somewhat standard, it leaves Seller exposed if funds are mishandled.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Escrow Agent shall have no liability except for its own willful misconduct or gross negligence
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider adding liability for ordinary negligence in fund handling.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Modify the liability standard to include ordinary negligence for fund handling matters. Replace 'Escrow Agent shall have no liability except for its own willful misconduct or gross negligence' with 'Escrow Agent shall have no liability except for its own negligence, willful misconduct or gross negligence with respect to the handling, investment, or disbursement of escrowed funds.'

risk_inventory.title: Escrow Agent Has Sole Discretion on Interpleader
risk_inventory.description: The provision grants the escrow agent discretion to interplead disputed funds 'at its own discretion.' This means the escrow agent can file an interpleader action even when Seller believes it has a clear right to the earnest money deposit (e.g., in a Buyer default situation). Interpleader actions delay resolution, increase costs, and create uncertainty for Seller who may be entitled to liquidated damages.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Escrow Agent shall be entitled, at its own discretion, to deliver such amount to an appropriate court of law pending resolution of the dispute
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require written demand and cure period before interpleader is permitted.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add procedural requirements before interpleader can be initiated. Replace 'If a dispute arises between the parties with respect to the disposition of the Earnest Money Deposit or any other amounts held in escrow, Escrow Agent shall be entitled, at its own discretion, to deliver such amount to an appropriate court of law pending resolution of the dispute' with 'If a dispute arises between the parties with respect to the disposition of the Earnest Money Deposit or any other amounts held in escrow, Escrow Agent shall provide written notice to both parties of its intent to interplead such funds and shall not commence any interpleader action until at least fifteen (15) Business Days after delivery of such notice, during which time the parties may attempt to resolve the dispute or provide Escrow Agent with joint written instructions. If joint written instructions are received within such period, Escrow Agent shall disburse in accordance therewith. If no joint instructions are received, Escrow Agent may thereafter deliver such amount to an appropriate court of law pending resolution of the dispute.'

risk_inventory.title: Investment Standard Lacks Specificity
risk_inventory.description: The investment requirement states funds shall be invested in accounts 'reasonably satisfactory to Seller and Buyer,' which could create disputes about what investments are acceptable. Additionally, there is no requirement that interest earnings be allocated to a specific party or prorated at closing, potentially creating ambiguity.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Escrow Agent shall invest the amount in escrow in accounts which are federally insured, which invest solely in government securities, or which are reasonably satisfactory to Seller and Buyer
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Specify that interest follows the principal and clarify investment priority.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add clarity regarding interest allocation and investment hierarchy. After 'and shall be applied in accordance with the terms of this Agreement' add: 'Any interest earned on escrowed funds shall be considered part of the escrowed funds and shall be disbursed to the party entitled to receive the principal amount. In the event of any dispute regarding acceptable investments, federally insured accounts or accounts investing solely in U.S. government securities shall be deemed acceptable without further approval.'

risk_inventory.title: Supplementary Escrow Instructions May Create Obligations
risk_inventory.description: While the provision states this Agreement controls over supplementary escrow instructions, Seller is still obligated to execute 'reasonable additional and supplementary escrow instructions.' The term 'reasonable' is subjective and could require Seller to execute documents that impose additional obligations or processes not contemplated in this Agreement, even if they don't technically 'conflict' with it.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller and Buyer agree to execute such reasonable additional and supplementary escrow instructions as may be appropriate to enable the Escrow Agent to comply with the terms of this Agreement
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add that supplementary instructions shall not expand Seller's obligations.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Modify the sentence to limit the scope of supplementary instructions. Replace 'Seller and Buyer agree to execute such reasonable additional and supplementary escrow instructions as may be appropriate to enable the Escrow Agent to comply with the terms of this Agreement' with 'Seller and Buyer agree to execute such reasonable additional and supplementary escrow instructions as may be appropriate to enable the Escrow Agent to comply with the terms of this Agreement; provided that such supplementary escrow instructions shall not expand the obligations, liabilities, or duties of either party beyond those expressly set forth in this Agreement.'

risk_inventory.title: No Fallback if Escrow Agent Refuses Reporting Role
risk_inventory.description: If the Escrow Agent refuses to act as Reporting Person, the parties must 'agree to appoint another third party.' This creates potential for deadlock if the parties cannot agree on an alternative, and there is no mechanism to break such an impasse. Additionally, costs of such alternative reporting person are not allocated.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: If Escrow Agent refuses to execute a counterpart of this Agreement pursuant to which it agrees to be the Reporting Person, Seller and Buyer shall agree to appoint another third party as the Reporting Person
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add fallback mechanism and cost allocation for alternative Reporting Person.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add a deadlock breaker and cost allocation provision. Replace 'If Escrow Agent refuses to execute a counterpart of this Agreement pursuant to which it agrees to be the Reporting Person, Seller and Buyer shall agree to appoint another third party as the Reporting Person' with 'If Escrow Agent refuses to execute a counterpart of this Agreement pursuant to which it agrees to be the Reporting Person, Seller and Buyer shall agree to appoint another third party as the Reporting Person within five (5) Business Days after notice of such refusal. If the parties are unable to agree on an alternative Reporting Person within such period, the Title Company shall serve as the Reporting Person. The costs of any third-party Reporting Person (other than Escrow Agent) shall be shared equally by Seller and Buyer.'

risk_inventory.title: Four-Year Document Retention Obligation
risk_inventory.description: Seller is required to retain this Agreement for not less than 4 years from the end of the calendar year in which Closing occurred and must produce it upon IRS request. While this is a standard tax compliance requirement, it creates a post-closing administrative obligation that Seller should be aware of. Failure to comply could result in IRS penalties.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: retain this Agreement for not less than 4 years from the end of the calendar year in which the Closing occurred, and to produce it to the Internal Revenue Service upon a valid request therefor
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure internal procedures exist for document retention compliance.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: No modification recommended to contract language. This is a standard IRS compliance requirement under Section 6045(e). Flag for Seller's internal compliance team to ensure proper document retention procedures are in place.

risk_inventory.title: Low Threshold for Minor Loss Classification
risk_inventory.description: The $500,000 threshold for classifying damage as 'minor' (requiring Buyer to proceed) may be too low for a significant commercial property transaction. This means Buyer is obligated to close even with substantial damage up to $500,000, limiting Seller's exposure but potentially creating disputes about repair adequacy or property condition at closing.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: the insured cost to repair any such damage or destruction, or the diminution in the value of the remaining Property as a result of a partial condemnation, equals $500,000 or less
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider increasing threshold to $750,000-$1,000,000 if appropriate for property value.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Consider whether the $500,000 threshold is appropriate relative to the Purchase Price. If the Purchase Price is substantial (e.g., $50M+), this threshold may be acceptable. However, if Seller wants more flexibility, consider increasing to a higher fixed amount or a percentage of Purchase Price (e.g., 'the lesser of $1,000,000 or 2% of the Purchase Price'). This protects Seller by ensuring Buyer must close despite more significant damage levels.

risk_inventory.title: Seller Bears Repair Cost Deductions
risk_inventory.description: The credit against Purchase Price includes insurance proceeds collected, plus deductibles not recoverable under Leases, less Seller's restoration expenses. While Seller can deduct repair costs, this structure may result in disputes over what constitutes reasonable repair expenditures, and Seller bears the risk of unrecoverable deductibles.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: plus the amount of any insurance deductible not recoverable under the Leases, less any sums expended by Seller toward the restoration or repair of the Property
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure insurance deductibles are recoverable under tenant leases where possible.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: This provision is generally balanced. To strengthen Seller's position, consider adding language clarifying that Seller has sole discretion over repair decisions prior to Closing, and that all reasonable repair costs (including professional fees for assessing damage) are deductible. Also consider adding 'and any reasonable costs incurred in connection with assessing the damage or destruction' to the list of deductible expenses.

risk_inventory.title: Buyer Termination Right for Major Loss
risk_inventory.description: Buyer has the unilateral right to terminate the Agreement if damage exceeds $500,000 or is uninsured or impairs access. While this is market-standard, it creates transaction risk for Seller who may have taken the property off market and incurred costs. The 10 Business Day election period also delays certainty for Seller.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: then Buyer may at its option, to be exercised by written notice to Seller within 10 Business Days after Seller's notice to Buyer of the occurrence of the damage or destruction or the commencement of condemnation proceedings, terminate this Agreement
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider shortening election period to 5 Business Days to reduce uncertainty.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: To strengthen Seller's position, consider: (1) shortening the election period from 10 Business Days to 5 Business Days to reduce Seller's uncertainty period; (2) adding language that if Buyer fails to respond, Buyer is deemed to have elected to proceed (which is already included - confirm this is retained); (3) consider adding a Seller termination right if Buyer terminates under this section and the damage is subsequently found to be less than the threshold. Modify to read: 'within 5 Business Days after Seller's notice to Buyer'.

risk_inventory.title: Seller Credit for Uninsured Loss
risk_inventory.description: If Buyer elects to proceed after major loss, Seller must credit the 'amount of any uninsured loss' against the Purchase Price. This is a potentially unlimited exposure for Seller if insurance coverage is inadequate, the loss exceeds policy limits, or coverage is denied. Seller bears the full risk of insurance gaps.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: there shall be a credit against the Purchase Price due hereunder equal to the amount of any uninsured loss
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Cap uninsured loss credit or require Buyer to terminate if loss exceeds insured amount.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: This creates significant exposure for Seller. Consider modifying to cap Seller's exposure for uninsured losses. Options include: (1) 'the amount of any uninsured loss, not to exceed $[cap amount]'; (2) adding language that if uninsured loss exceeds a threshold, Seller may elect to terminate rather than provide unlimited credit; (3) requiring Buyer to accept assignment of any claims Seller may have against insurers in lieu of credit for disputed coverage. Alternative language: 'equal to the amount of any uninsured loss (provided that Seller's credit obligation for uninsured losses shall not exceed $_____), insurance proceeds or condemnation awards...'

risk_inventory.title: Unlimited Damages for Intentional Default
risk_inventory.description: While Seller's liability is generally capped at the Seller Breakage Fee, there is a carve-out for 'intentional or willful' defaults that allows Buyer to recover 'any and all damages.' This creates unlimited liability exposure for Seller, and the terms 'intentional' and 'willful' are subjective and could be broadly interpreted by courts.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: plus to the extent the default or breach by Seller was intentional or willful, recover any and all damages arising out of such intentional or willful default
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Delete intentional/willful carve-out or cap damages even for intentional breach.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: This carve-out significantly undermines the liquidated damages protection. To protect Seller, consider: (1) deleting this carve-out entirely so all pre-closing defaults are subject to the liquidated damages cap; (2) if deletion is not acceptable, narrow the carve-out to 'fraud' only rather than 'intentional or willful' breach; (3) alternatively, cap even intentional breach damages at a multiple of the Earnest Money Deposit (e.g., '2x the Earnest Money Deposit'). Recommended deletion: remove ', plus to the extent the default or breach by Seller was intentional or willful, recover any and all damages arising out of such intentional or willful default'.

risk_inventory.title: Broad Categories of Recoverable Breakage Costs
risk_inventory.description: The Seller Breakage Fee includes very broad damage categories such as 'costs of foregoing other business opportunities' which are inherently speculative and difficult to verify. While capped at the Earnest Money Deposit amount, this language invites disputes and claims for consequential damages that are typically excluded in commercial transactions.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: costs incurred in connection with this Agreement, including Due Diligence costs, costs, losses and damages incurred to obtain financing, costs incurred pursuing joint ventures, costs of foregoing other business opportunities, and attorneys' fees
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Narrow recoverable costs to documented out-of-pocket expenses only.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: The broad language describing components of the Seller Breakage Fee creates litigation risk even though the total is capped. Consider narrowing to objectively verifiable costs: 'an amount to compensate Buyer for its reasonable, documented out-of-pocket costs actually incurred in connection with this Agreement, including third-party Due Diligence costs, loan application fees, and reasonable attorneys' fees, in an aggregate amount not to exceed the Earnest Money Deposit.' Delete references to 'costs of foregoing other business opportunities' and 'costs incurred pursuing joint ventures' as these are speculative and consequential in nature.

risk_inventory.title: Short Cure Period for Seller Default
risk_inventory.description: Seller only has 5 Business Days to cure a default before Buyer can exercise remedies. For complex commercial transactions, some defaults (such as title issues or third-party consents) may require more time to cure. This short period may be insufficient for Seller to remedy curable issues.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: which is not cured within 5 Business Days after notice from Buyer
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Extend cure period to 10-15 Business Days for non-monetary defaults.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Consider extending the cure period, particularly for non-monetary defaults that may take longer to remedy. Suggested revision: 'which is not cured within 5 Business Days after notice from Buyer (or 15 Business Days for non-monetary defaults that cannot reasonably be cured within 5 Business Days, provided Seller has commenced cure efforts within the initial 5 Business Day period and is diligently pursuing such cure)'. This provides Seller reasonable time to cure while maintaining Buyer's protections.

risk_inventory.title: Unlimited Post-Closing Liability Preserved
risk_inventory.description: The final sentence explicitly preserves all of Buyer's rights and remedies for breaches discovered after Closing, without any cap or limitation. This undermines the negotiated limitations in Section 5.4 and could expose Seller to unlimited post-closing claims.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: The foregoing in no way limits Buyer's rights and remedies if Buyer first discovers after Closing a breach or default by Seller under this Agreement.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Delete this sentence or cross-reference Section 5.4 survival and cap limitations.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: This sentence creates ambiguity about whether the carefully negotiated limitations in Section 5.4 (survival periods and liability caps) apply to post-closing claims. Modify to read: 'The foregoing in no way limits Buyer's rights and remedies under Section 5.4 if Buyer first discovers after Closing a breach of Seller's representations and warranties, subject to the limitations, survival periods, and caps set forth in Section 5.4.' This ensures the negotiated protections in Section 5.4 are not undermined by this general statement.

risk_inventory.title: Asymmetric Default Remedies Favor Buyer
risk_inventory.description: Comparing Sections 13.1 and 13.2, there is a significant asymmetry: Buyer gets specific performance OR liquidated damages plus a Breakage Fee (up to 2x Earnest Money) plus unlimited damages for willful breach, while Seller is limited to retaining only the Earnest Money Deposit with no right to specific performance or consequential damages. This asymmetry favors Buyer.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: then Seller shall be entitled, as its sole remedy, to retain the Earnest Money Deposit as liquidated damages
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider adding Seller specific performance right or increasing liquidated damages amount.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: The remedy structure strongly favors Buyer. To rebalance, consider: (1) adding a Seller right to specific performance: 'Seller shall be entitled, as its sole remedy, to either (a) enforce specific performance of this Agreement, or (b) retain the Earnest Money Deposit as liquidated damages'; (2) alternatively, increase Seller's liquidated damages amount to include a breakage fee similar to Buyer's remedy; (3) add a carve-out for Buyer's intentional breach similar to Section 13.1. Suggested revision to add specific performance right for parity with Buyer's remedies.

risk_inventory.title: Seller Waives Specific Performance and Damages
risk_inventory.description: Seller explicitly waives all rights to seek specific performance or damages beyond the Earnest Money Deposit. While this provides certainty, it may leave Seller without adequate remedy if Buyer defaults on a property that has declined in value or is difficult to re-market.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: SELLER WAIVES ITS RIGHT TO RECOVER DAMAGES OR SEEK SPECIFIC PERFORMANCE AGAINST BUYER
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider retaining specific performance right as alternative remedy.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: This waiver is significant and may not be in Seller's best interest in all market conditions. If the property value declines between contract and closing, Seller's damages could exceed the Earnest Money Deposit. Consider revising to: 'SELLER WAIVES ITS RIGHT TO RECOVER DAMAGES AGAINST BUYER, PROVIDED HOWEVER THAT SELLER SHALL RETAIN THE RIGHT TO SEEK SPECIFIC PERFORMANCE IF SELLER ELECTS TO DO SO BY WRITTEN NOTICE TO BUYER WITHIN 30 DAYS AFTER BUYER'S DEFAULT.' Alternatively, if waiver is retained, ensure the Earnest Money Deposit amount is substantial enough to adequately compensate Seller.

risk_inventory.title: Mutual Confidentiality May Limit Seller Marketing
risk_inventory.description: The broad definition of Confidential Information includes 'the existence or pendency of this transaction' and 'material economic terms.' While mutual, this could limit Seller's ability to market the property to backup buyers or discuss the failed transaction with future prospects if the deal terminates.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: (b) the existence or pendency of this transaction, (c) the material economic terms of this transaction
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add carve-out allowing Seller to discuss with backup buyers if transaction terminates.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Consider adding a Seller-specific carve-out for post-termination marketing. Add at the end of the exceptions: '(aa) following any termination of this Agreement, Seller may disclose to prospective purchasers that a prior transaction did not close and may share the material economic terms of this Agreement to the extent reasonably necessary in connection with marketing the Property for sale, provided Seller shall not disclose Buyer's identity without Buyer's consent.' This preserves Seller's ability to efficiently re-market the property.

risk_inventory.title: Subjective Confidentiality Standard
risk_inventory.description: The catch-all provision includes information 'that...would otherwise be reasonably considered to be confidential.' This subjective standard could lead to disputes about what information is covered, potentially exposing Seller to claims of breach for disclosures Seller considered appropriate.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: that either a party or its agents has expressly designated as confidential or would otherwise be reasonably considered to be confidential
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Limit to expressly designated information or provide clearer objective criteria.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: The 'reasonably considered to be confidential' standard is subjective and could create disputes. Consider narrowing to: 'that either a party or its agents has expressly designated as confidential in writing at the time of disclosure.' Alternatively, if the broader standard is retained, add clarifying language: 'For the avoidance of doubt, general market information about property values, capitalization rates, and comparable transactions shall not be considered Confidential Information.'

risk_inventory.title: Subjective confidentiality standard
risk_inventory.description: The confidentiality obligation is tied to 'the same degree of care and confidentiality that such party exercises in protecting and preserving its own confidential information.' This subjective standard means if Buyer has lax internal practices for protecting its own information, it could argue it met the contractual standard despite inadequate protection of Seller's Confidential Information. A more objective standard (e.g., 'commercially reasonable care' or 'reasonable care under the circumstances') would provide better protection.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: the same degree of care and confidentiality that such party exercises in protecting and preserving its own confidential information
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Replace with objective 'commercially reasonable' standard.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Replace 'the same degree of care and confidentiality that such party exercises in protecting and preserving its own confidential information' with 'at least the same degree of care as it uses to protect its own confidential information, but in no event less than commercially reasonable care'. This establishes both a subjective and objective floor for the confidentiality standard.

risk_inventory.title: Broad Permitted Recipients disclosure exception
risk_inventory.description: The definition of Permitted Recipients is expansive, including 'existing or potential investors, joint venture partners or lenders' and their respective 'officers, employees, attorneys, advisors, consultants or Affiliates.' This creates a very wide circle of potential disclosure with minimal accountability. The only requirement is making recipients 'aware' of confidentiality and having them 'acknowledge their responsibility'—there is no requirement for written confidentiality agreements or that Buyer be liable for breaches by these recipients.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: each party may disclose the Confidential Information to existing or potential investors, joint venture partners or lenders, as well as to the officers, employees, attorneys, advisors, consultants or Affiliates of Seller or Buyer, as the case may be, or of any of the foregoing parties (collectively, "Permitted Recipients"); provided that the disclosing party first makes those Permitted Recipients aware of the confidential nature of the Confidential Information and such Permitted Recipients acknowledge their responsibility to preserve the confidentiality of the Confidential Information
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require written confidentiality agreements and hold disclosing party liable for breaches.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Modify the Permitted Recipients proviso to read: 'provided that (i) the disclosing party first obtains from each such Permitted Recipient a written agreement to maintain the confidentiality of the Confidential Information on terms no less restrictive than those set forth herein, and (ii) the disclosing party shall be responsible for any breach of this Section 14.2 by any such Permitted Recipient as if such breach were committed by the disclosing party itself.'

risk_inventory.title: No specified survival period for confidentiality
risk_inventory.description: The confidentiality provision does not specify how long the obligations survive after closing or termination of the Agreement. This ambiguity could allow Buyer to argue confidentiality obligations terminate at closing, potentially exposing sensitive Seller information post-transaction.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Each party shall treat the Confidential Information with the same degree of care and confidentiality
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add explicit survival period (e.g., 2-3 years post-closing or termination).
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add a new sentence at the end of Section 14.2: 'The obligations of confidentiality set forth in this Section 14 shall survive the Closing or any earlier termination of this Agreement for a period of two (2) years.'

risk_inventory.title: Uncapped broker indemnification obligation
risk_inventory.description: Seller's indemnification obligation to Buyer for broker claims arising from Seller's contacts is uncapped and unlimited. While this is mutual, the indemnification exposure is open-ended. This is somewhat mitigated by the fact that Seller controls its own broker relationships, but surprise claims from third-party finders could arise.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: then Seller shall defend Buyer from such claim, and shall indemnify Buyer and hold Buyer harmless from any and all costs, damages, claims, liabilities or expenses (including reasonable attorneys' fees and disbursements) incurred by Buyer with respect to the claim
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider adding a cap or ensuring comprehensive broker disclosure.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: This is a mutual provision and market-standard in structure. If Seller wants to limit exposure, add after 'with respect to the claim': '; provided, however, that Seller's aggregate liability under this indemnification shall not exceed the Purchase Price.' Alternatively, ensure Section 1.15 and related broker disclosures are comprehensive to minimize undisclosed broker risk.

risk_inventory.title: No explicit survival for broker indemnity
risk_inventory.description: The broker indemnification obligations do not specify a survival period. While indemnification provisions typically survive closing by implication, the lack of explicit survival language creates ambiguity about how long Seller remains exposed to claims arising from Buyer's broker contacts that surface post-closing.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: If any person brings a claim against Seller for a commission or finder's fee based upon any contact, dealings or communication with Buyer
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add explicit survival period consistent with statute of limitations.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add at the end of the paragraph: 'The indemnification obligations set forth in this Section 15 shall survive the Closing for a period of two (2) years, or if longer, until the expiration of the applicable statute of limitations for such claims.'

risk_inventory.title: Notice provision incomplete without addresses
risk_inventory.description: The notice provision references addresses to follow but without the complete information, it's impossible to assess whether proper notice addresses are established for Seller. Proper notice provisions are critical for receiving timely communication of claims, defaults, and other material matters.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: shall be delivered to the parties at the following addresses
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure Seller's complete notice address information is included.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Verify that complete notice information for Seller is provided in the subsequent paragraphs, including physical address, attention line, and email address. Consider adding backup notice recipients (e.g., counsel) to ensure Seller receives all critical communications.

risk_inventory.title: Blank party identification
risk_inventory.description: The party name field is blank, shown only as underscores. While this may simply be a template placeholder, Seller should ensure proper legal entity name is inserted to avoid any ambiguity about the contracting party.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Insert Seller's complete legal entity name.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Replace '_________________________' with Seller's complete legal entity name as it appears in the preamble and signature blocks of the Agreement.

risk_inventory.title: Blank attention and email fields
risk_inventory.description: The attention line and email address fields are blank. Proper completion is essential to ensure notices reach the appropriate person at Seller and that email notice (if permitted) is properly directed.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Insert appropriate contact name and email address.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Replace 'Attn:	_______________' with the appropriate contact person's name and title, and replace 'Email:  _______________' with the appropriate email address for receiving contractual notices. Consider using a general department email (e.g., legal@company.com) rather than individual email to ensure continuity.

risk_inventory.title: Blank Notice Information for Counterparty
risk_inventory.description: The notice provision contains blank fields for the Buyer's contact information (Attn: _____________________). While this appears to be a template placeholder, if this is not properly completed before execution, Seller may face difficulties providing valid notice to Buyer. Invalid or incomplete notice addresses could lead to disputes about whether notices were properly delivered, potentially affecting Seller's ability to enforce deadlines, exercise rights, or trigger default provisions.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure all blank notice fields are completed prior to execution.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: This is a placeholder that must be completed with the Buyer's specific contact person name before execution. Flag this for completion during contract finalization. Do not execute the Agreement until this field contains a specific named individual or position title.

risk_inventory.title: Change of Address Requires Actual Receipt
risk_inventory.description: The provision states that no change of address notice is effective until 'actual receipt.' This creates a potential issue where if Buyer changes their address but Seller's notice of change is delayed or lost, Seller might continue sending notices to an old address in good faith, only to have those notices deemed ineffective. This asymmetric risk could affect Seller's ability to provide timely notices if Buyer claims non-receipt of an address change notification.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: no notice of a change of address shall be effective until actual receipt of such notice
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider adding deemed receipt provisions for address change notices.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Consider modifying to provide that address change notices shall be effective upon deemed delivery using the same delivery methods specified in Section 16.1 (certified mail, overnight courier, or email), rather than requiring 'actual receipt.' Alternative language: 'provided that any notice of a change of address shall be effective upon delivery in accordance with the notice provisions of this Section 16.1.'

risk_inventory.title: Email Notice Deemed Immediate Upon Transmission
risk_inventory.description: Email notices are deemed delivered upon transmission without requiring any confirmation of receipt, read receipt, or acknowledgment. This is generally favorable to Seller as it provides a quick and efficient notice method. However, Seller should be aware that Buyer can also use this method, meaning Buyer could send last-minute notices (such as termination notices during due diligence) at 4:59 PM Pacific Time on a deadline date and have them deemed effective.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: email transmission, in which case notice shall be deemed delivered upon transmission if the transmission is made on a Business Day on or before 5:00 p.m. Pacific Time
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Acceptable provision; monitor email for time-sensitive Buyer notices.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: This provision is market-standard and generally acceptable. No revision required, but Seller should ensure robust email monitoring procedures are in place, particularly around deadline dates such as the Due Diligence Deadline, Title Objection Date, and Estoppel Deadline, as Buyer can provide effective notice up until 5:00 PM Pacific Time on such dates.

risk_inventory.title: Blanket Time is of Essence Provision
risk_inventory.description: The 'time is of the essence' provision applies universally to 'all obligations under this Agreement.' While this is standard language that benefits both parties, it means Seller must strictly comply with all deadlines including the Due Diligence Items Delivery Date, Title Commitment Delivery Date, Estoppel Deadline, and various closing deliverables. Any delay by Seller, even minor, could be treated as a material breach. This cuts both ways but requires Seller to carefully track all deadlines.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Time is of the essence in the performance of all obligations under this Agreement.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure calendar tracking of all Seller deadlines; consider cure period.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: This is a standard provision. However, to protect Seller, consider whether any specific Seller obligations should have explicit cure periods or should be carved out from the strict time-is-of-essence standard. Review Sections 3.3 (Due Diligence Materials delivery), 4.1 (Title Commitment), 7.1 (Estoppel delivery), and 11.4 (Closing deliverables) to ensure Seller can meet all deadlines. Consider adding language such as: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, Seller shall have a 2 Business Day cure period for any administrative or ministerial delivery obligations.'

risk_inventory.title: Broad Affiliate Definition Favors Buyer
risk_inventory.description: The definition of 'Affiliate' is specifically tailored to Buyer's corporate structure (Unico Investment Group LLC) and includes entities where Unico holds as little as 2.5-5% of membership or partnership interests. This extremely low ownership threshold means Buyer could assign the Agreement to entities where Buyer has minimal economic interest or control, potentially allowing assignment to parties Seller would not have approved. Combined with Section 16.6's permitted assignment to Affiliates without Seller consent, this creates significant transfer risk.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: any limited liability company or partnership in which Unico Investment Group LLC either (i) directly or indirectly serves as a manager[, operating as managing member] or general partner, and/or (ii) directly or indirectly holds at least [2.5]5% of the total membership or partnership interests shall constitute an Affiliate of Buyer
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Increase minimum ownership threshold to 50% or require majority control.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise the Affiliate definition to require a minimum 50% direct or indirect ownership interest for the ownership-based prong. Delete the bracketed '[2.5]' option and replace '5%' with '50%'. Consider also requiring that Unico maintain actual management authority, not merely serve as a manager in name. Suggested revision: 'directly or indirectly holds at least 50% of the total membership or partnership interests and exercises actual management control shall constitute an Affiliate of Buyer.'

risk_inventory.title: Buyer Can Assign Without Seller Consent
risk_inventory.description: While Seller has general consent rights over assignment, the carve-out allowing Buyer to assign without consent to Affiliates and to third parties under a TIC structure significantly undermines Seller's control. Given the broad Affiliate definition (entities with as low as 2.5-5% ownership), Buyer could effectively assign to entities with minimal connection to the original Buyer. The TIC structure provision (subsection b) allows assignment to non-Affiliates ('third parties') as long as an Affiliate manages the property, which provides almost no protection regarding the financial wherewithal of the actual purchasers.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer may, without consent from Seller, partially or wholly assign this Agreement to (a) one or more Affiliates of Buyer, and (b) one or more Affiliates of Buyer and/or third parties under a tenancy in common structure, provided an Affiliate of Buyer will be the property manager of the Property
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require Seller consent for TIC assignments or require creditworthy co-tenants.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise subsection (b) to either: (1) delete the TIC carve-out entirely and require Seller consent for any TIC structure, or (2) add financial qualification requirements for any third-party TIC co-tenants, such as: 'provided that (i) each third-party tenant in common shall have a net worth of at least $[X] million and liquid assets of at least $[Y] million, evidenced by financial statements delivered to Seller at least 10 Business Days prior to Closing, (ii) the TIC agreement shall be in form reasonably acceptable to Seller, and (iii) such third parties shall assume joint and several liability under this Agreement.' Also consider adding: 'Buyer's Affiliate assignees shall have net worth reasonably satisfactory to Seller.'

risk_inventory.title: Minimal Assignment Notice Period
risk_inventory.description: Seller receives only 2 Business Days' notice before Closing of a proposed assignment to Buyer's Affiliate. This extremely short timeframe provides Seller virtually no opportunity to review the assignee's qualifications, verify Affiliate status, or raise objections before the transaction closes. Seller could find itself conveying the Property to an unknown entity with minimal advance notice.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Notice of any proposed assignment to Buyer's Affiliate, which notice shall include the full legal name and signature block for the proposed assignee, must be given to Seller at least 2 Business Days before Closing.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Extend notice period to at least 10 Business Days before Closing.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Replace '2 Business Days' with '10 Business Days' and expand the required notice contents to include: 'full legal name, signature block, organizational documents evidencing Affiliate status, evidence of good standing, and such financial information as Seller may reasonably request to verify the assignee's ability to perform under this Agreement.' Add: 'Seller shall have 5 Business Days to confirm assignee's Affiliate status and may object to any assignment that does not comply with Section 16.6, in which case the assignment shall be void.'

risk_inventory.title: Buyer Remains Liable After Assignment
risk_inventory.description: The provision states that no assignment releases Buyer from liability. While this is protective of Seller, Seller should verify this protection is meaningful by confirming Buyer has sufficient creditworthiness to stand behind its obligations post-Closing, particularly representations and warranties that survive Closing.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: No assignment by Buyer shall release it from any liability hereunder.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm Buyer's creditworthiness; consider requiring guaranty.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: This provision is favorable to Seller. Consider strengthening by adding: 'Additionally, any assignee shall execute an assumption agreement in form reasonably acceptable to Seller assuming all of Buyer's obligations under this Agreement, and Buyer shall remain jointly and severally liable with any assignee for all obligations arising under this Agreement.' If Buyer is a single-purpose entity, consider requiring a creditworthy guarantor for post-Closing obligations.

risk_inventory.title: Undefined 1031 Exchange Cooperation Scope
risk_inventory.description: While the provision includes good protections (no additional liability, no financial obligations, no date changes for Seller), the scope of required 'cooperation' is undefined. Seller should ensure this cannot be interpreted to require Seller to take on any exchange-related documentation obligations, hold funds, or deal with exchange intermediaries in ways that create administrative burden or risk.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Each party agrees to cooperate with the other in effecting such an exchange
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Define cooperation scope; limit to executing reasonably required documents.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add clarifying language after 'effecting such an exchange': 'Such cooperation shall be limited to (i) executing such documents and instruments as may be reasonably required to effect the exchange, provided such documents do not alter the economic terms of this Agreement or impose any additional liability on the cooperating party, and (ii) consenting to the assignment of this Agreement to a qualified intermediary. The cooperating party shall not be required to (a) take title to any property other than as contemplated by this Agreement, (b) hold or receive exchange funds, (c) incur any out-of-pocket expense (unless reimbursed by the exchanging party), or (d) execute any indemnity or assumption of liability in connection with the exchange.'

risk_inventory.title: Venue Limited to Property Location
risk_inventory.description: Venue is limited to courts where the Property is located. If Seller is based in a different state, this could increase litigation costs if disputes arise. However, this is generally market-standard for real estate transactions and may be acceptable depending on Seller's location.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Venue for any action arising out of this Agreement shall be in the state courts in the state and county in which the Property is located, or in U.S. Federal District Court for the applicable district in which the Property is located.
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Acceptable if Seller has presence in Property jurisdiction; otherwise negotiate.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: If Seller is located in a different jurisdiction and would prefer alternative venue options, revise to: 'Venue for any action arising out of this Agreement shall be, at the election of the party initiating such action, in (i) the state courts in the state and county in which the Property is located, (ii) U.S. Federal District Court for the applicable district in which the Property is located, or (iii) the state or federal courts located in [Seller's preferred jurisdiction].' Alternatively, if current language is acceptable, no change needed.

risk_inventory.title: Undefined 'Prevailing Party' Standard
risk_inventory.description: The attorneys' fees provision awards fees to the 'prevailing party' but does not define what constitutes 'prevailing.' In complex litigation where each party may win on some issues and lose on others, this ambiguity can lead to satellite litigation over fee entitlement. Without a clear definition (e.g., party recovering net monetary judgment, or party achieving primary objective), both parties may claim prevailing party status, potentially resulting in neither recovering fees or additional litigation costs to resolve the issue.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: the prevailing party will be entitled to reasonable attorneys' fees
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Define 'prevailing party' or specify criteria for determination.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to add a definition of 'prevailing party.' Consider language such as: 'For purposes of this Section, the "prevailing party" shall mean the party who obtains a final, non-appealable judgment substantially in its favor on the principal claims in dispute, as determined by the court in its discretion. If each party prevails on some claims, the court shall determine which party prevailed on the more substantial portion of the dispute and shall award fees proportionately.'

risk_inventory.title: Unlimited Attorney Fee Recovery
risk_inventory.description: The provision allows for recovery of 'reasonable attorneys' fees and costs' without any cap or limitation. While fee-shifting provisions are standard and this is mutual, Seller should be aware that if Buyer prevails in any enforcement action, Seller could face substantial fee exposure in addition to any damages, particularly in complex disputes involving multiple issues or appeals.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: reasonable attorneys' fees and costs incurred in connection with such action prior to and at trial and on any appeal therefrom
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider whether fee recovery should be capped or limited.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: This is informational for client awareness. If Seller desires to limit exposure, consider adding: 'provided, however, that the total attorneys' fees recoverable by any party shall not exceed [$ amount or percentage of Purchase Price].' However, note that this would also limit Seller's recovery, so this may not be advisable depending on client's risk tolerance and negotiating posture.

risk_inventory.title: No Minimum Net Worth or Capital Requirement
risk_inventory.description: The limited liability provision correctly shields individual members and managers of both parties from personal liability. However, it states that all parties 'shall look solely to the assets of Seller for the payment of any claim' without requiring Buyer to maintain any minimum net worth or capital to satisfy its obligations. If Buyer is a thinly-capitalized SPE (common in real estate transactions), Seller's remedies for Buyer default beyond the Earnest Money Deposit may be illusory. While Seller's remedy is already limited to liquidated damages under Section 13.2, any claims outside that provision could be unrecoverable.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: all parties hereto shall look solely to the assets of Seller for the payment of any claim or the performance of any obligation by Seller
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider requiring Buyer guaranty or proof of adequate capitalization.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Consider negotiating for one or more of the following protections: (1) Add a representation from Buyer that it has adequate capital or assets to satisfy its obligations under this Agreement; (2) Require a guaranty from Buyer's parent entity or principals for Buyer's obligations; (3) Add language: 'Buyer represents that it has, and shall maintain through Closing, sufficient net assets to satisfy its obligations hereunder beyond the Earnest Money Deposit.' The appropriate level of protection depends on Buyer's creditworthiness and the transaction economics.

risk_inventory.title: Mutual Liability Shield is Appropriate
risk_inventory.description: The limited liability provision protects both Seller's and Buyer's individual members, managers, shareholders, officers, directors, partners, employees and agents from personal liability. This mutual structure is appropriate and market-standard for entity-to-entity transactions. This is informational only to confirm the provision is balanced.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Neither the members, managers, employees or agents of Seller, nor the shareholders, officers, directors, employees or agents of any of them, shall be liable under this Agreement
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: No change needed - mutual protection is appropriate.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: No changes recommended. This provision appropriately provides mutual protection to the principals of both parties, which is standard in commercial real estate transactions where both Buyer and Seller are typically special purpose entities.

risk_inventory.title: Supersedes Prior Confidentiality Agreements
risk_inventory.description: The entire agreement clause explicitly supersedes 'non-disclosure or confidentiality agreements' previously executed between the parties. If Seller had more protective confidentiality terms in a prior NDA (such as longer survival periods, broader definitions of confidential information, or stricter use restrictions), those protections are now replaced by Section 14's confidentiality provisions, which may be less favorable to Seller. Additionally, if the prior NDA contained provisions beneficial to Seller that are not replicated in this Agreement (such as non-solicitation of employees or return/destruction of materials), those protections are lost.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: including, without limitation, any previously executed letters of intent, early access agreements and/or non-disclosure or confidentiality agreements
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Review prior NDA terms and preserve beneficial provisions.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add carve-out language to preserve specific protections from prior agreements that benefit Seller. Consider adding: 'provided, however, that the confidentiality and non-disclosure obligations of any prior confidentiality agreement shall survive to the extent such obligations are more protective of the disclosing party's Confidential Information than Section 14 hereof.' Alternatively, if there are specific provisions from the prior NDA that Seller wishes to preserve (such as non-solicitation, return of materials, or injunctive relief provisions), incorporate those provisions directly into Section 14 of this Agreement.

risk_inventory.title: Supersedes Prior Early Access Agreements
risk_inventory.description: The entire agreement clause supersedes prior early access agreements. Seller should verify that all indemnification obligations, insurance requirements, and restoration obligations that Buyer may have incurred under any prior early access agreement are either (a) fully satisfied before this Agreement's effective date, or (b) expressly preserved and incorporated into this Agreement. Section 3.4.6 references prior early access agreements but should be reviewed to ensure alignment.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: early access agreements
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm prior early access obligations are satisfied or preserved.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Review Section 3.4.6 to ensure it adequately preserves any outstanding obligations from prior early access agreements. Consider adding language such as: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, any indemnification obligations, insurance requirements, or restoration obligations of Buyer arising from activities conducted under any prior early access agreement shall survive and remain in full force and effect.' Coordinate with p_42 (Section 3.4.6) to ensure consistent treatment.

risk_inventory.title: Survival Subject to Section 5.4 Limitations
risk_inventory.description: The no-merger provision is expressly made 'subject to the limitations set forth in Section 5.4,' which contains significant limitations on Seller's representations and warranties including: (1) a survival period that likely expires relatively quickly post-closing, (2) potential deductible/basket requirements, and (3) potential caps on liability. By making the entire no-merger provision subject to Section 5.4, this language reinforces that Seller's exposure on representations is strictly limited. While this benefits Seller, you should verify Section 5.4 contains all intended protections.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Subject to the limitations set forth in Section 5.4 and Section 14
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify Section 5.4 contains all intended survival limitations.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: This provision is favorable to Seller as drafted because it reinforces the limitations in Section 5.4. Review Section 5.4 (p_78) to ensure it contains: (1) a survival period of 9-12 months maximum for general representations, (2) a meaningful deductible/basket before Buyer can make claims, (3) a cap on Seller's liability (typically 1-3% of purchase price for general reps), and (4) exclusions for consequential, punitive, and speculative damages. If Section 5.4 does not contain these protections, consider adding them. The cross-reference to Section 14 regarding confidentiality survival should also be verified.

risk_inventory.title: Standard Severability - Potential Reformation
risk_inventory.description: The severability clause is standard but permits courts to sever invalid provisions while keeping the remainder of the Agreement in effect. In rare cases, this could result in the removal of provisions favorable to Seller (such as liability caps, damage limitations, or exculpatory clauses) if a court deems them unenforceable, while keeping Buyer-favorable provisions intact. This is a standard risk in most commercial contracts.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Any term or provision of this Agreement that is invalid or unenforceable in any jurisdiction will, as to such jurisdiction, be ineffective to the extent of such invalidity or unenforceability without rendering invalid or unenforceable the remaining terms and provisions
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider adding reformation language to preserve intent.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Consider adding protective language such as: 'If any provision of this Agreement is held to be invalid, illegal, or unenforceable, such provision shall be reformed and construed so that it is valid, legal, and enforceable to the maximum extent possible consistent with the original intent of the parties. In no event shall the invalidity or unenforceability of any limitation on liability, damage cap, or exculpatory provision be deemed to increase Seller's liability beyond what would have existed had such provision been valid and enforceable.'

risk_inventory.title: Unlimited Further Acts Obligation
risk_inventory.description: This provision requires Seller to execute additional documents and perform additional acts 'as may be reasonably required' to accomplish the purposes of the Agreement. While qualified by 'reasonably,' this creates an open-ended post-closing obligation that could require Seller to take actions beyond what was contemplated at execution. The lack of any time limitation or scope restriction could expose Seller to indefinite requests for cooperation, potentially requiring execution of documents or taking actions that could have unintended consequences.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: shall execute, acknowledge or have notarized (if appropriate) and deliver in a timely manner such additional documents, and do such other additional acts, also in a timely manner, as may be reasonably required
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add time limit, cost cap, and scope limitations on further acts obligation.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise Section 16.20 to include protective limitations for Seller: (1) add a time limitation such as 'for a period of 90 days following Closing'; (2) add language that Seller's obligations shall be 'at no cost or liability to Seller' or that Buyer shall reimburse Seller's reasonable costs; (3) clarify that such additional documents shall not 'expand Seller's obligations, liabilities, or representations beyond those expressly set forth in this Agreement'; and (4) add that any such requests must be related to 'ministerial or administrative matters' necessary to effectuate the Closing.

risk_inventory.title: Undefined 'Timely Manner' Standard
risk_inventory.description: The phrase 'in a timely manner' appears twice but is not defined, creating ambiguity about when Seller must perform these additional acts. This vague standard could lead to disputes about whether Seller has complied with its obligations and potentially expose Seller to claims of breach for failing to act quickly enough under Buyer's interpretation.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: in a timely manner
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Define 'timely manner' with specific timeframe (e.g., 10 Business Days).
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Replace both instances of 'in a timely manner' with a specific timeframe such as 'within ten (10) Business Days after written request' to provide certainty and prevent disputes over timing compliance.

risk_inventory.title: Binding Without All Party Signatures
risk_inventory.description: The language 'whether or not all parties execute each counterpart' could create ambiguity about when the Agreement becomes binding. While standard counterpart language, combined with the electronic signature provision, this could theoretically allow a party to claim the Agreement is binding even if signature pages are incomplete or if there are questions about which version was signed.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: whether or not all parties execute each counterpart
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider clarifying that both parties must sign for Agreement to be binding.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: For clarity, consider adding after 'whether or not all parties execute each counterpart' the following clarifying language: '; provided, however, that this Agreement shall not be binding unless and until executed by both Buyer and Seller.' This reinforces the protection in Section 16.21 and eliminates any ambiguity.

p_3.title: Ambiguous Effective Date Determination
p_3.description: The Effective Date is defined as 'the date of mutual execution' established by dates shown below signatures. If Buyer and Seller sign on different dates, it creates ambiguity about which date controls. This could affect calculation of all subsequent deadlines (Due Diligence, Title Objection, Closing) and create disputes about timing obligations. As Seller, unclear timeline could delay your ability to enforce deadlines or claim Buyer default.
p_3.problematic_text: "Effective Date" means the date of mutual execution of this Agreement established by the dates shown below each of the signatures of Seller and Buyer
p_3.user_recommendation: Clarify Effective Date as the later of the two signature dates.
p_3.model_instructions: Revise the Effective Date definition to eliminate ambiguity. Replace with: '"Effective Date" means the later of the dates shown below the signatures of Seller and Buyer, such that mutual execution has occurred.' Alternatively, specify that Effective Date shall be the date this Agreement is fully executed by both parties, as evidenced by the later of the signature dates.

p_8.title: Excessive Closing Date Extension Provisions
p_8.description: The Closing Date is subject to extensions under at least eight different sections (4.4, 5.3, 7.2, 11.2.1, 11.2.2, 11.8, 13.1, and 13.2). This creates significant uncertainty for Seller regarding when closing will actually occur and extends Seller's exposure period. Multiple extension mechanisms favor Buyer by allowing delays while Seller remains bound. Seller cannot market the property to other buyers during extended periods and bears ongoing carrying costs.
p_8.problematic_text: The Closing Date is subject to possible extensions as provided in Sections 4.4, 5.3, 7.2, 11.2.1, 11.2.2, 11.8, 13.1 and 13.2 below
p_8.user_recommendation: Cap total extensions and add Seller termination right after maximum period.
p_8.model_instructions: Add a limitation on cumulative extensions: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing extension rights, in no event shall the Closing Date be extended more than sixty (60) days beyond April 30, 2026, unless Seller agrees in writing. If Closing has not occurred by such outside date, Seller may terminate this Agreement upon written notice to Buyer and retain the Earnest Money Deposit as liquidated damages.' Review each referenced section to ensure Seller has appropriate protections and consider whether all extension rights are necessary.

p_8.title: No Seller Right to Accelerate Closing
p_8.description: The provision allows for earlier closing only if agreed by both parties. Seller has no unilateral right to accelerate closing even if Buyer's conditions are satisfied early. This limits Seller's flexibility to close quickly if circumstances warrant (e.g., favorable market conditions, Seller's business needs).
p_8.problematic_text: or such earlier date as may be agreed to by Buyer and Seller in writing
p_8.user_recommendation: Consider adding Seller acceleration right with reasonable notice.
p_8.model_instructions: Consider adding language allowing Seller to accelerate closing with adequate notice: 'Seller may accelerate the Closing Date to any date not less than ten (10) Business Days after written notice to Buyer, provided all conditions to Buyer's obligation to close have been satisfied or waived.' Alternatively, leave as-is if Seller prefers the certainty of the fixed date.

p_9.title: Due Diligence Deadline Subject to Expansion
p_9.description: The Due Diligence Deadline can be extended by operation of Sections 3.3 and 4.1. Extended due diligence periods keep Seller bound while Buyer can terminate with deposit return, increasing Seller's market exposure and opportunity cost. The cross-references create uncertainty about the actual deadline Seller must plan for.
p_9.problematic_text: as may be adjusted by operation of Section 3.3 and/or Section 4.1
p_9.user_recommendation: Cap maximum due diligence extensions with outside date.
p_9.model_instructions: Add a cap on extensions: 'as may be adjusted by operation of Section 3.3 and/or Section 4.1; provided, however, that in no event shall the Due Diligence Deadline be extended beyond March 31, 2026.' Review Sections 3.3 and 4.1 to ensure the extension triggers are reasonable and not subject to Buyer manipulation. Consider requiring Buyer to pay additional consideration for any extended due diligence period.

p_10.title: Very Short Due Diligence Delivery Window
p_10.description: Seller has only 3 Business Days from Effective Date to deliver all due diligence materials. This is an extremely tight deadline that may be difficult to meet, especially if closing teams need to coordinate, compile documents from multiple sources, or if the Effective Date falls near a holiday period. Failure to deliver on time could trigger extension of the Due Diligence Deadline per Section 3.3, further delaying the transaction at Seller's expense.
p_10.problematic_text: the date that is 3 Business Days after the Effective Date
p_10.user_recommendation: Extend to 5-7 Business Days or use commercially reasonable efforts standard.
p_10.model_instructions: Revise to provide more reasonable time: '"Due Diligence Items Delivery Date" means 5:00 p.m., on the date that is five (5) Business Days after the Effective Date.' Alternatively, add a qualifier: 'Seller shall use commercially reasonable efforts to deliver the Due Diligence Items by such date, and any delay in delivery shall not constitute a default hereunder but may extend the Due Diligence Deadline as provided in Section 3.3.' Review Section 3.3 to understand the penalty for late delivery and ensure it is proportionate.

p_11.title: Title Objection Date Tied to Buyer Receipt
p_11.description: The Title Objection Date is triggered by Buyer's receipt of Title Commitment and Title Documents, not by Seller's delivery or a date certain. This creates uncertainty for Seller because: (1) Buyer could claim late or incomplete receipt to extend the objection period; (2) there is no mechanism to confirm receipt date; (3) Seller cannot predict when title objections will come. This floating deadline makes transaction timing unpredictable and could delay closing.
p_11.problematic_text: 10 Business Days after the later of (a) Buyer's receipt of the Title Commitment and Title Documents
p_11.user_recommendation: Tie deadline to delivery date with deemed receipt provision.
p_11.model_instructions: Revise to create certainty: '"Title Objection Date" means 10 Business Days after the later of (a) Seller's delivery of the Title Commitment and Title Documents to Buyer (which delivery shall be deemed to have occurred on the Title Commitment Delivery Date if Seller has caused the Title Company to make such items available to Buyer by such date), or (b) the Effective Date.' Add a deemed receipt provision: 'Buyer shall be deemed to have received any documents made available through the Title Company's online portal on the date of such availability.'

p_12.title: Fixed Title Commitment Delivery Date
p_12.description: The Title Commitment Delivery Date is a fixed date (January 25, 2026) with no provision for extension. If Seller or the Title Company fails to deliver by this date due to circumstances beyond Seller's control, this could create complications or potential breach claims, even though Seller may not be responsible for Title Company delays.
p_12.user_recommendation: Add language permitting reasonable extension if Title Company causes delay.
p_12.model_instructions: Revise the definition to include flexibility for Seller: '"Title Commitment Delivery Date" means January 25, 2026, or such later date as may result from delays by the Title Company that are not caused by Seller, provided Seller uses commercially reasonable efforts to cause the Title Company to deliver the Title Commitment by such date.' Alternatively, add a separate provision stating that Seller shall not be in default for delays caused solely by the Title Company.

p_13.title: Estoppel Deadline Extension Favors Buyer
p_13.description: The Estoppel Deadline can be extended 'by operation of Section 7.1,' which typically contains provisions that allow extension when Seller is unable to obtain estoppels. This creates an open-ended potential extension that could delay closing and keep Seller bound to the contract indefinitely while Buyer retains optionality.
p_13.problematic_text: as may be extended by operation of Section 7.1
p_13.user_recommendation: Review Section 7.1 to confirm extension limits and add a cap on extensions.
p_13.model_instructions: Review Section 7.1 (p_87) to understand the scope of potential extensions. Consider adding language to cap extensions: 'as may be extended by operation of Section 7.1, provided that in no event shall such deadline be extended more than [30] days beyond April 15, 2026.' This protects Seller from indefinite delays while still allowing reasonable accommodation for estoppel collection.

p_14.title: Fixed Major Tenant List May Become Outdated
p_14.description: The definition of 'Major Tenants' lists three specific tenants by name. If any of these tenants assigns their lease, changes their name, or if new significant tenants are added before closing, this definition will not automatically update. This could create issues with estoppel requirements if a named Major Tenant is no longer in the building or has been replaced by a larger tenant.
p_14.problematic_text: "Major Tenants" means (i) Northwest Technology Partners, (ii) Cascade Financial Services and (iii) Pacific Law Group LLP
p_14.user_recommendation: Consider whether definition should include successor/assign language.
p_14.model_instructions: Consider revising to address potential changes: '"Major Tenants" means (i) Northwest Technology Partners (or any successor or assign thereof under its Lease), (ii) Cascade Financial Services (or any successor or assign thereof under its Lease) and (iii) Pacific Law Group LLP (or any successor or assign thereof under its Lease), provided that if any such tenant has vacated or been released from its Lease prior to Closing, such tenant shall no longer be deemed a Major Tenant.' This ensures the definition remains functional even if tenant circumstances change.

p_15.title: Broad Property Definition Includes Uncertain Items
p_15.description: The Property definition is extremely broad, potentially including items Seller may not own or intend to convey. Phrases like 'all rights, privileges, interests' and 'whether existing or after acquired' could sweep in assets Seller did not intend to sell. The inclusion of 'all minerals, oil, gas and other hydrocarbon substances' may not reflect prior severances, and 'all rights of Seller, if any, in any property lying in the bed of any street' may include valuable rights Seller wishes to retain.
p_15.problematic_text: all rights, privileges, interests, licenses, claims, easements, benefits, covenants, conditions and servitudes of any type or nature which are appurtenant to or otherwise benefiting the Land or Improvements, whether existing or after acquired, including all minerals, oil, gas and other hydrocarbon substances on the Land or Improvements
p_15.user_recommendation: Confirm mineral rights ownership and consider limiting 'after acquired' language.
p_15.model_instructions: Review and potentially narrow the definition: (1) For minerals, add qualifier: 'including all minerals, oil, gas and other hydrocarbon substances on the Land or Improvements to the extent owned by Seller and not previously severed or reserved'; (2) Consider removing or limiting 'whether existing or after acquired' to 'as of the Effective Date' to avoid conveying rights Seller may acquire between signing and closing; (3) Ensure Seller has confirmed ownership of all listed categories before agreeing to this broad definition. Add explicit carve-outs for any assets Seller intends to retain.

p_15.title: Assignability Qualifiers Create Potential Gaps
p_15.description: Several categories of Property are qualified by 'to the extent assignable' or 'to the extent owned by Seller.' While these qualifications are appropriate, Buyer may later claim Seller failed to convey items that Seller believed were non-assignable.
