Seller makes no representation or warranty regarding the accuracy or completeness of third-party reports, tenant-provided information, or other documents not prepared by Seller that are included in the Due Diligence Materials.'

p_72.title: No Omissions Representation Creates Expansive Duty
p_72.description: The representation that Due Diligence Materials 'do not omit any fact or circumstance necessary to make the statements contained therein not misleading' imposes a securities-law-type disclosure standard that is extremely broad for real estate transactions. This could be interpreted as requiring disclosure of every potentially material fact.
p_72.problematic_text: do not omit any fact or circumstance necessary to make the statements contained therein not misleading
p_72.user_recommendation: Delete or narrow the no-omissions language.
p_72.model_instructions: Delete the phrase 'and do not omit any fact or circumstance necessary to make the statements contained therein not misleading' entirely. The no fraudulent concealment language in the first sentence already addresses intentional withholding, which is appropriate. The broader no-omissions language creates an unmanageable disclosure standard.

p_75.title: Knowledge Definition Appropriately Limited
p_75.description: The knowledge definition is favorable to Seller as it limits knowledge to only two named individuals (Robert Martinez and Jennifer Williams) with no duty of inquiry and no imputation of knowledge. This is a protective provision for Seller. However, Seller should verify that these are indeed the correct individuals with primary responsibility for property matters, as naming individuals who lack actual knowledge could create issues if a Buyer later claims the wrong people were named.
p_75.problematic_text: without duty of inquiry or imputation of knowledge
p_75.user_recommendation: Confirm named individuals are correct and have property knowledge.
p_75.model_instructions: This provision is favorable to Seller. No changes needed unless client wishes to add additional knowledge parties or confirm the named individuals are appropriate. If modifying, ensure any additions maintain the 'no duty of inquiry' and 'no imputation' protections.

p_77.title: Affirmative Duty to Disclose Changes
p_77.description: This provision creates an affirmative obligation on Seller to give notice to Buyer of any change in condition or any changed condition that would make representations inaccurate. This duty to disclose could be interpreted broadly and creates ongoing monitoring obligations for Seller between signing and closing. Failure to provide such notice could be characterized as a default or breach.
p_77.problematic_text: Unless Seller gives notice to Buyer of any change in the condition of the Property subsequent to the Effective Date or of any other changed condition that would make any of the representations or warranties in Section 5.1 inaccurate, incomplete or misleading
p_77.user_recommendation: Consider adding 'material' qualifier to notice obligation.
p_77.model_instructions: Revise the notice obligation to apply only to 'material' changes: 'Unless Seller gives notice to Buyer of any material change in the condition of the Property subsequent to the Effective Date or of any other material changed condition that would make any of the representations or warranties in Section 5.1 materially inaccurate, incomplete or misleading'. This prevents triggering notice obligations for immaterial or de minimis changes.

p_77.title: Buyer Termination Right for Rep Changes
p_77.description: This provision grants Buyer a termination right with full deposit return if any representation becomes inaccurate, even for changes outside Seller's control. This is a significant risk as it essentially creates a broad walk-away right for Buyer based on changed circumstances, market conditions, or third-party actions that affect representation accuracy. The 5-day window is short, but the right itself is very broad.
p_77.problematic_text: Buyer may elect to either (i) to terminate this Agreement and receive a full return of the Earnest Money Deposit by giving Seller written notice of such termination within 5 Business Days after Buyer received or delivered notice of such inaccuracy
p_77.user_recommendation: Limit termination right to material changes within Seller's control.
p_77.model_instructions: Revise to limit Buyer's termination right: 'In the event any of the foregoing Seller's representations and warranties become materially inaccurate due to circumstances within Seller's reasonable control, then Buyer may elect to either (i) terminate this Agreement and receive a full return of the Earnest Money Deposit by giving Seller written notice of such termination within 5 Business Days after Buyer received notice of such material inaccuracy (with the Closing Date extended to accommodate such 5 Business Days period), or (ii) proceed with the Closing with knowledge and acceptance of such facts. For changes outside Seller's control that render representations inaccurate, Buyer's sole remedy shall be to proceed to Closing or terminate without the return of the Earnest Money Deposit.'

p_77.title: Full Remedies for 'Within Control' Changes
p_77.description: The carve-out providing Buyer 'all rights and remedies for default' when changes are 'within Seller's control' is vague and could be interpreted broadly. What constitutes 'within Seller's control' is subjective and could lead to disputes. Additionally, granting 'all rights and remedies' could be interpreted to include specific performance or consequential damages beyond the caps in Section 5.4.
p_77.problematic_text: if such Seller's representations and warranties are no longer accurate due to reasons or causes within Seller's control, then, subject to the limitations set forth in Section 5.4 below, Buyer shall have available to it all of the rights and remedies for default and Seller's breach
p_77.user_recommendation: Define 'within Seller's control' and clarify remedy limitations apply.
p_77.model_instructions: Revise to clarify the scope: 'if such Seller's representations and warranties are no longer accurate due to Seller's intentional or grossly negligent acts (as opposed to market conditions, tenant actions, governmental actions, or other third-party conduct), then, subject to the limitations set forth in Section 5.4 and Section 13.1 below, Buyer shall have available to it the remedies set forth in Section 13.1 for Seller default.' This ties the remedy to the default provision and clarifies what 'control' means.

p_78.title: 12-Month Survival Period is Reasonable
p_78.description: The 12-month survival period for representations and warranties is relatively standard and favorable to Seller. Many buyers push for 18-24 months. This provision adequately protects Seller's interest in finality.
p_78.problematic_text: shall survive for a period of 12 months from the Closing Date
p_78.user_recommendation: Provision is favorable; no changes recommended.
p_78.model_instructions: No changes needed. This is a seller-favorable provision with a reasonable survival period.

p_78.title: Liability Cap Structure is Favorable
p_78.description: The $25,000 deductible/threshold and the cap of greater of $1,000,000 or 5% of Purchase Price are reasonable protections for Seller. These provisions effectively limit Seller's exposure to representation breaches.
p_78.problematic_text: under no circumstances shall Seller be liable to Buyer on account of any breach of any representation or warranty in the aggregate in excess of the amount equal to the greater of (i) $1,000,000 and (ii) 5% of the Purchase Price
p_78.user_recommendation: Provision is favorable; consider if cap should be lower.
p_78.model_instructions: No changes required. If client wishes to further limit exposure, consider reducing the cap to the lesser of $1,000,000 or 3% of Purchase Price, though this may face buyer resistance.

p_78.title: Attorney Fees Excluded from Cap
p_78.description: Both the deductible and the liability cap expressly exclude attorneys' fees. This means Seller could face uncapped liability for attorneys' fees in connection with representation breach claims, which could significantly exceed the stated cap in contentious litigation.
p_78.user_recommendation: Include attorneys' fees within the liability cap.
p_78.model_instructions: Remove the attorneys' fees exclusions to ensure the cap applies comprehensively: '(a) Buyer shall not make a claim against Seller for damages for breach or default of any representation or warranty, unless the amount of such claim is reasonably anticipated to exceed $25,000; and (b) under no circumstances shall Seller be liable to Buyer on account of any breach of any representation or warranty in the aggregate in excess of the amount equal to the greater of (i) $1,000,000 and (ii) 5% of the Purchase Price, inclusive of all attorneys' fees, costs, and expenses.'

p_79.title: Buyer Reps Lack Parallel Limitations
p_79.description: Section 6 introduces Buyer's representations but does not include parallel limitations to those protecting Seller in Sections 5.3 and 5.4 (such as survival periods, deductibles, and caps). This creates an asymmetry where Seller's claims against Buyer for representation breaches may be unlimited while Buyer's claims against Seller are capped.
p_79.problematic_text: 6.	BUYER'S REPRESENTATIONS AND WARRANTIES.  Buyer represents and warrants to Seller, as of the Effective Date and as of Closing, the following:
p_79.user_recommendation: Confirm Buyer's reps have unlimited survival or add parallel caps.
p_79.model_instructions: Add a new subsection after Section 6.6 (or at the end of Buyer's representations): '6.7 Survival and Limitations. Buyer's representations and warranties shall survive Closing without limitation as to time or amount. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the limitations set forth in Section 5.4 shall not apply to any breach by Buyer of its representations and warranties hereunder.' Alternatively, if symmetry is preferred, reference Section 5.4 mutually.

p_80.title: Buyer Delaware LLC Status
p_80.description: Buyer represents it is a Delaware LLC in good standing, but there is no requirement that Buyer qualify to do business in the state where the Property is located (Washington, based on context). If Buyer is not qualified in Washington, this could create enforcement issues or complications at closing.
p_80.problematic_text: Buyer is a limited liability company duly organized and validly existing and in good standing under the laws of the State of Delaware
p_80.user_recommendation: Add requirement for Buyer to be qualified in Property state.
p_80.model_instructions: Revise to include foreign qualification: 'Buyer is a limited liability company duly organized and validly existing and in good standing under the laws of the State of Delaware and is qualified to conduct business in the State of Washington (or will be so qualified prior to Closing).'

p_81.title: Buyer May Lack Closing Authorization
p_81.description: This provision explicitly acknowledges that Buyer may not yet have internal authorization to proceed to Closing at the time of contract execution. While Buyer represents it will obtain such authorization before issuing the Buyer Approval Notice, this creates significant risk for Seller. If Buyer fails to obtain internal approvals during due diligence, Buyer can simply decline to issue the Buyer Approval Notice and terminate the agreement, effectively using the due diligence period as a free option period while Seller's property is tied up. This is a one-sided arrangement that favors Buyer.
p_81.problematic_text: although Buyer is authorized to enter into this Agreement, Buyer may only be authorized to issue the Buyer Approval Notice and proceed to Closing if and when it receives additional internal authorizations during the Due Diligence Period
p_81.user_recommendation: Require Buyer to confirm full authorization at signing or provide shorter approval period.
p_81.model_instructions: Revise to require Buyer to have obtained all necessary internal authorizations prior to execution of this Agreement, or alternatively, add a specific shorter deadline (e.g., 10 Business Days) by which Buyer must confirm receipt of all internal authorizations, independent of the Due Diligence Period. Consider adding that failure to obtain such approvals by the specified date constitutes a Buyer default entitling Seller to the Earnest Money Deposit.

p_81.title: Undefined 'Internal Authorizations' Standard
p_81.description: The phrase 'additional internal authorizations' is undefined and entirely within Buyer's control. Buyer could claim it needs investment committee approval, board approval, partner consent, or any number of internal hurdles that Seller cannot verify or influence. This gives Buyer excessive discretion to terminate during the due diligence period based on purported failure to obtain unspecified internal approvals.
p_81.user_recommendation: Require Buyer to identify all required internal approvals in the Agreement.
p_81.model_instructions: Add a requirement that Buyer must identify in an exhibit or schedule all specific internal authorizations required to proceed to Closing, including the authorizing body, expected timeline, and criteria for approval. Add language stating that Seller shall have no liability and the Earnest Money Deposit shall be forfeited if Buyer fails to obtain internal approvals that were not disclosed at signing.

p_82.title: Reference to Non-Existent Section 6.1.2
p_82.description: This section references 'Section 6.1.2 above' for an exception to the consent representation, but the Buyer's Representations section appears to start at 6.1 (Status) without a subsection 6.1.2. This creates ambiguity about what consents may actually be required and could allow Buyer to claim undisclosed consent requirements exist as an exception.
p_82.problematic_text: Except as noted in Section 6.1.2 above
p_82.user_recommendation: Verify correct cross-reference or delete the exception entirely.
p_82.model_instructions: Confirm whether Section 6.1.2 exists in the final document. If not, either (a) delete the phrase 'Except as noted in Section 6.1.2 above' so that Buyer's representation is unqualified, or (b) insert the correct section reference. If the reference relates to Buyer's authorization contingency in Section 6.2, consider whether this exception undermines the consent representation entirely.

p_82.title: Potential Undisclosed Consent Requirements
p_82.description: The reference to Section 6.1.2 suggests there may be consent requirements that Buyer has not yet obtained. Combined with the internal authorization language in Section 6.2, this could mean Buyer has multiple outs from the transaction. Seller should understand exactly what consents remain outstanding.
p_82.problematic_text: Except as noted in Section 6.1.2 above
p_82.user_recommendation: Request Buyer to disclose all outstanding consent requirements.
p_82.model_instructions: Add a requirement that Buyer must disclose in writing all consents, waivers, approvals or authorizations that have not yet been obtained, including from any lenders, investors, partners, or internal governance bodies, and the expected timeline for obtaining each.

p_84.title: Broad OFAC Representation Covers Unknown Parties
p_84.description: The OFAC representation extends to 'any of their respective partners, members, shareholders or other equity owners' which may include passive investors or fund participants that Buyer cannot fully verify. While this representation is standard, Buyer may resist if it has complex ownership structures. This is generally favorable to Seller as drafted.
p_84.problematic_text: nor any of their respective partners, members, shareholders or other equity owners
p_84.user_recommendation: Confirm representation is acceptable; consider adding knowledge qualifier resistance.
p_84.model_instructions: This provision is generally favorable to Seller. If Buyer requests a knowledge qualifier, resist or limit any qualifier to only those equity holders owning more than a specified threshold (e.g., 10% or 25%). Ensure that the representation extends to the full ownership chain to the extent reasonably knowable by Buyer.

p_87.title: High Estoppel Threshold Burden
p_87.description: Seller must obtain Conforming Tenant Estoppels covering 80% of leased square footage plus ALL Major Tenants as a condition to Buyer's obligation to close. This is a high threshold that gives Buyer significant leverage and potential exit opportunities if any Major Tenant fails to return an estoppel or returns one with any inconsistency. Seller has no control over tenant cooperation, yet bears the risk of transaction failure.
p_87.problematic_text: Receipt of Conforming Tenant Estoppels (as defined below) from the Major Tenants (plus a sufficient number of other Tenants under Leases so that Buyer receives Conforming Tenant Estoppels for Leases covering at least 80% of the currently leased square footage
p_87.user_recommendation: Reduce threshold to 70% and allow Seller-executed estoppels for non-Major Tenants.
p_87.model_instructions: Revise to reduce the estoppel threshold from 80% to 70% of leased square footage. Add language permitting Seller to deliver a Seller-executed estoppel certificate in lieu of a tenant-executed certificate for non-Major Tenants if the tenant fails to respond, with Seller representing the accuracy of information therein. Consider adding a materiality threshold for what constitutes a 'Nonconforming' estoppel.

p_87.title: Buyer Termination Right for Estoppel Issues
p_87.description: Buyer has broad termination rights if Seller cannot cure estoppel inconsistencies. Combined with the low threshold for what constitutes a 'Nonconforming Tenant Estoppel' (any material matter inconsistent with Due Diligence Materials OR Seller's representations), this gives Buyer substantial ability to exit the transaction late in the process without penalty if market conditions change.
p_87.problematic_text: Buyer, as its sole remedy therefor, may elect to either: (i) postpone Closing one time for up to 14 days to allow Seller to attempt to accomplish such cure, (ii) terminate this Agreement, in which event the Earnest Money Deposit shall be returned to Buyer
p_87.user_recommendation: Add materiality threshold and limit termination to issues exceeding defined dollar thresholds.
p_87.model_instructions: Modify the definition of Nonconforming Tenant Estoppel to require that the inconsistency be 'materially adverse to Buyer's interest in the Property' and involve either (a) a rent reduction exceeding $X annually, (b) an unscheduled termination right, or (c) landlord obligations exceeding $X. Add language that minor or immaterial inconsistencies shall not give rise to termination rights and Buyer must accept such estoppels as Conforming.

p_87.title: No Price Reduction for Estoppel Issues
p_87.description: While Buyer can terminate for Nonconforming Estoppels, if Buyer elects to close despite the inconsistencies, there is no purchase price reduction. This seems protective of Seller but actually creates perverse incentives - Buyer is more likely to terminate rather than negotiate a resolution because closing means accepting the issue at full price.
p_87.problematic_text: close the transaction regardless of the inconsistent matter(s) disclosed in the Nonconforming Tenant Estoppel(s) (in which case they shall be treated as Conforming Tenant Estoppel(s)) without a reduction in the Purchase Price
p_87.user_recommendation: Consider allowing negotiated price adjustment as alternative to termination.
p_87.model_instructions: Add an option (iv) that allows Buyer and Seller to negotiate in good faith a purchase price reduction reflecting the economic impact of the inconsistent matter, with the adjustment amount to be mutually agreed or, if not agreed within 5 Business Days, either party may elect termination or proceed at the original Purchase Price.

p_87.title: Short Estoppel Draft Approval Period
p_87.description: Buyer has 10 Business Days to object to draft estoppel certificates or they are deemed approved. However, Seller must deliver drafts within 10 Business Days of Effective Date. This front-loaded timeline may not allow Buyer sufficient time to review all lease files and identify issues, potentially resulting in estoppels going out with errors that later become Seller's problem.
p_87.problematic_text: Buyer shall be deemed to have approved the draft estoppel certificates unless it objects to specific errors or omissions within 10 Business Days after receipt thereof
p_87.user_recommendation: Extend Buyer's review period to 15 Business Days for complex portfolios.
p_87.model_instructions: Consider extending the estoppel draft review period from 10 Business Days to 15 Business Days to ensure Buyer has adequate time to review all lease documents and provide comprehensive comments, reducing the risk of Nonconforming Estoppels arising from drafting oversights.

p_88.title: Immediate Correspondence Delivery Requirement
p_88.description: Seller must 'immediately' deliver copies of any tenant correspondence regarding claims, defaults, or non-routine communications. The term 'immediately' is vague and operationally burdensome. It could be interpreted strictly to mean same-day delivery, which may be impractical and could create technical defaults.
p_88.problematic_text: Seller shall immediately deliver to Buyer a copy of any correspondence received from any Tenant regarding any claims of default or requests for action by Seller or Seller's property manager or other non-routine communication
p_88.user_recommendation: Change 'immediately' to 'within 3 Business Days' for operational clarity.
p_88.model_instructions: Replace 'immediately' with 'within 3 Business Days after receipt' to provide a clear, reasonable timeframe that is operationally achievable while still keeping Buyer informed of material tenant communications.

p_88.title: Broad Lease Approval Requirement
p_88.description: Seller cannot enter into any new leases or amendments without Buyer's written consent. While consent cannot be unreasonably withheld, this restriction applies from Effective Date through Closing, which could be several months. If a valuable leasing opportunity arises and Buyer is slow to respond or raises unreasonable objections, Seller could lose the opportunity.
p_88.problematic_text: Seller shall not enter into any new leases or amendments to any current Lease nor waive performance of any Tenant's obligations under its Lease without Buyer's written consent, which consent shall not be unreasonably withheld, conditioned or delayed
p_88.user_recommendation: Add deemed approval after 5 Business Days of non-response to lease requests.
p_88.model_instructions: Add language stating: 'If Buyer fails to respond to a request for consent within the 5 Business Day period specified herein, Buyer shall be deemed to have approved such lease or modification.' Also consider adding specific criteria for what constitutes 'reasonable' grounds for disapproval to reduce disputes.

p_88.title: Short Lease Approval Response Period
p_88.description: Buyer has only 5 Business Days to disapprove a proposed lease or modification before deemed approval occurs. While this is protective of Seller's ability to conduct business, Seller should be aware that this deemed approval mechanism means Buyer may approve leases that later create complications at closing if they were not thoroughly reviewed.
p_88.problematic_text: Buyer shall notify Seller in writing of its disapproval with an explanation of its objections thereto set forth in reasonable detail within 5 Business Days of Buyer's receipt of a copy of the proposed lease or lease modification, or Buyer shall be deemed to have approved the same
p_88.user_recommendation: Current language is favorable; ensure tracking system for approval deadlines.
p_88.model_instructions: No change recommended - this deemed approval provision is favorable to Seller. However, Seller should implement internal procedures to track the 5 Business Day periods and document delivery of lease proposals to Buyer to preserve the deemed approval rights.

p_88.title: Buyer Bears All Leasing Costs on Amendments
p_88.description: The provision states Buyer shall bear all Leasing Costs related to amendments, modifications, extensions, expansions, options or renewals approved during the contract period. This is favorable to Seller, but Seller should ensure the Leasing Costs are clearly documented and credited at closing to avoid post-closing disputes.
p_88.problematic_text: If Closing occurs, Buyer shall bear all Leasing Costs related to any amendments, modifications, extensions, expansions, options or renewals of the Leases in accordance with Section 7.3
p_88.user_recommendation: Clarify documentation requirements for Leasing Cost credits at closing.
p_88.model_instructions: Add clarifying language: 'Seller shall provide Buyer with reasonable documentation of any Leasing Costs incurred in connection with such approved amendments, modifications, extensions, expansions, options or renewals no later than 5 Business Days prior to Closing, and the parties shall include appropriate credits and allocations on the closing statement.'

p_90.title: Broad Leasing Costs Definition
p_90.description: The definition of Leasing Costs is quite broad, including 'any out-of-pocket payments' that are 'in the nature of a tenant inducement' with a non-exhaustive list. This broad definition could potentially capture costs that Seller did not anticipate would be credited to Buyer, though the 'including specifically, but without limitation' language does provide some guidance on intended scope.
p_90.problematic_text: any out-of-pocket payments required under a Lease to be paid by the landlord thereunder to or for the benefit of the tenant thereunder which is in the nature of a tenant inducement, including specifically, but without limitation
p_90.user_recommendation: Consider adding exclusions for normal operating costs vs. true tenant inducements.
p_90.model_instructions: Consider adding clarifying language: 'Leasing Costs shall not include (a) normal operating expenses of the Property, (b) repairs or maintenance required under the Lease regardless of when the obligation arose, or (c) costs for which Seller is entitled to reimbursement from the tenant.' This prevents normal operating costs from being characterized as Leasing Costs.

p_91.title: Seller Representation on Existing Leasing Costs
p_91.description: Seller represents and warrants that Exhibit L sets forth ALL Leasing Costs still outstanding. This is an unqualified representation that could create liability if any Leasing Costs were inadvertently omitted from the exhibit. The representation should be knowledge-qualified to match the standard for other Seller representations.
p_91.problematic_text: Seller represents and warrants that Exhibit L attached hereto sets forth all Leasing Costs still outstanding under those Leases in effect as of the Effective Date
p_91.user_recommendation: Add 'to Seller's knowledge' qualifier to the Leasing Costs representation.
p_91.model_instructions: Modify to read: 'Seller represents and warrants that, to Seller's Knowledge, Exhibit L attached hereto sets forth all Leasing Costs still outstanding under those Leases in effect as of the Effective Date.' This aligns the representation with the knowledge standard used elsewhere in the Agreement and prevents strict liability for inadvertent omissions.

p_91.title: Late Documentation Deadline for Leasing Costs
p_91.description: Seller must deliver the statement of Existing Leasing Costs paid 'no later than 5 Business Days prior to the Closing Date.' This is a tight timeline that may create last-minute closing complications if there are discrepancies between the statement and Exhibit L, particularly for a complex property with multiple tenants.
p_91.problematic_text: No later than 5 Business Days prior to the Closing Date, Seller shall deliver to Buyer a statement, with reasonable supporting documentation, of the Existing Leasing Costs actually paid by Seller between the Effective Date and the date of delivery of such statement
p_91.user_recommendation: Consider extending to 10 Business Days to allow time to resolve discrepancies.
p_91.model_instructions: Consider changing 'No later than 5 Business Days' to 'No later than 10 Business Days' to provide adequate time for Buyer to review the documentation and for the parties to resolve any discrepancies before Closing without causing closing delays.

p_91.title: Buyer Assumption Limited to Credit Amount
p_91.description: Buyer only assumes responsibility for Existing Leasing Costs 'up to the amount of the credit that Buyer received at Closing.' This means if there are Existing Leasing Costs that were not on Exhibit L or that exceed the credit amount, Seller may remain liable. This provision should be cross-referenced with the representation above.
p_91.problematic_text: Buyer shall assume responsibility for paying the remaining Existing Leasing Costs up to the amount of the credit that Buyer received at Closing
p_91.user_recommendation: Ensure Exhibit L is comprehensive; consider uncapped assumption by Buyer.
p_91.model_instructions: Consider revising to: 'Buyer shall assume responsibility for paying all remaining Existing Leasing Costs as set forth on Exhibit L (as such exhibit may be updated by mutual agreement prior to Closing).' This removes the cap tied to the credit amount and ensures Buyer assumes all scheduled obligations. Alternatively, add language that any Existing Leasing Costs not listed on Exhibit L shall remain Seller's responsibility only if Seller had actual knowledge of such costs prior to Closing.

p_92.title: Due Diligence Deadline Reference for Leasing Costs
p_92.description: New Leasing Costs allocation uses the Due Diligence Deadline as the dividing line. This is appropriate, but Seller should be aware that leases entered into between Effective Date and Due Diligence Deadline (even if approved by Buyer) would have their Leasing Costs treated as Existing Leasing Costs under Section 7.3.2, requiring Seller credit.
p_92.problematic_text: Buyer shall be responsible for the payment of all Leasing Costs payable for (a) any new Leases entered into after the Due Diligence Deadline that have been approved (or deemed approved) by Buyer
p_92.user_recommendation: Clarify treatment of leases approved between Effective Date and DD Deadline.
p_92.model_instructions: Consider adding clarifying language: 'For the avoidance of doubt, Leasing Costs for any new Lease entered into between the Effective Date and the Due Diligence Deadline with Buyer's approval (or deemed approval) shall be treated as New Leasing Costs and shall be Buyer's responsibility.' This shifts the cost allocation to Buyer for any deals Buyer approved during due diligence.

p_93.title: Unfunded Ongoing Cooperation Obligation for Non-Transferable LOCs
p_93.description: For non-transferable letters of credit, Seller is obligated to provide 'reasonable cooperation' to Buyer and the tenant after Closing to facilitate reissuance of a new letter of credit. This creates an open-ended post-closing obligation for Seller with no time limit, no cap on the extent of cooperation required, and could involve ongoing administrative burden. While the parenthetical excludes expenditure of funds, the cooperation requirement itself could be time-consuming and extend indefinitely.
p_93.problematic_text: shall provide reasonable cooperation to Buyer and the applicable tenant (including after Closing, but without the need for expenditure of funds) to facilitate the reissuance of a new letter of credit
p_93.user_recommendation: Add time limit (e.g., 90 days post-closing) for cooperation obligation.
p_93.model_instructions: Revise the sentence to add a reasonable time limitation on Seller's post-closing cooperation obligation. Suggested revision: 'shall provide reasonable cooperation to Buyer and the applicable tenant for a period not to exceed ninety (90) days after Closing (but without the need for expenditure of funds or more than de minimis administrative effort) to facilitate the reissuance of a new letter of credit to replace the letter of credit previously held by Seller.'

p_94.title: Six-Month Billing Requirement Extends Seller's Dependence on Buyer
p_94.description: While Buyer has no duty to collect delinquent rents, Buyer is required to bill tenants for delinquent rents for 6 months after Closing. This creates a situation where Seller is dependent on Buyer's good faith performance of billing obligations to collect pre-closing arrears. There is no remedy specified if Buyer fails to bill properly or in a timely manner, potentially impairing Seller's ability to collect amounts owed.
p_94.problematic_text: shall be required to bill Tenants for delinquent rents in the ordinary course of business for 6 months after Closing
p_94.user_recommendation: Add remedy or recourse if Buyer fails to properly bill tenants.
p_94.model_instructions: Add language providing Seller with recourse if Buyer fails to bill tenants as required. Suggested addition after the first sentence: 'Buyer shall provide Seller with copies of all billing statements sent to Tenants for delinquent rents within ten (10) Business Days of sending. If Buyer fails to bill Tenants as required herein, Seller shall have the right, upon written notice to Buyer, to directly bill such Tenants and Buyer shall reasonably cooperate with Seller's collection efforts.'

p_94.title: Rent Payment Waterfall Subordinates Seller's Pre-Closing Claims
p_94.description: The payment application waterfall applies payments: (a) first to the month of Closing, (b) second to Buyer's period of ownership, and (c) third to Seller's period of ownership. This structure subordinates Seller's pre-closing delinquent rent claims to Buyer's post-closing claims. If a tenant is chronically delinquent, Seller may never receive payment for pre-closing arrears as new delinquencies will take priority.
p_94.problematic_text: (a) first toward the delinquent rent (or other tenant charge) for the actual month in which Closing occurred, (b) second toward the delinquent rent (or other tenant charge) owed to Buyer for its period of ownership and (c) third toward the delinquent rent (or other tenant charge) owed to Seller for its period of ownership
p_94.user_recommendation: Revise waterfall to prioritize oldest delinquencies first.
p_94.model_instructions: Revise the payment application waterfall to apply payments in chronological order, which would benefit Seller for pre-closing arrears. Suggested revision: 'such payments shall be applied (a) first toward the delinquent rent (or other tenant charge) for the actual month in which Closing occurred, (b) second toward the oldest outstanding delinquent rent (or other tenant charge) chronologically, allocating between Seller's and Buyer's respective periods of ownership accordingly, unless the Tenant designates the payment for a specific period.'

p_94.title: Seller Cannot Terminate Lease or Possession for Collection
p_94.description: Seller's reserved right to pursue remedies for delinquent rents is limited by the prohibition against terminating any Lease or Tenant's right to possession. While this is a reasonable protection for Buyer's asset, it limits Seller's collection leverage for pre-closing delinquencies and may make collection impractical for significant arrears.
p_94.problematic_text: but shall not be entitled to terminate any Lease or any Tenant's right to possession
p_94.user_recommendation: Consider whether this limitation is appropriate for your transaction.
p_94.model_instructions: This is a market-standard provision protecting Buyer's tenancies, but Seller should be aware of the limitation. If Seller has significant pre-closing delinquencies with particular tenants, consider negotiating a specific carve-out or addressing the delinquency as a Purchase Price adjustment at Closing rather than relying on post-closing collection rights.

p_95.title: Short Window for Rent Roll Delivery Before Closing
p_95.description: The updated rent roll must be delivered no sooner than 10 Business Days and no later than 5 Business Days prior to Closing. This creates a 5-Business-Day delivery window that could be operationally challenging if Closing is accelerated or if there are administrative delays in compiling accurate rent roll data.
p_95.problematic_text: No sooner than 10 Business Days prior to Closing and no later than 5 Business Days prior to Closing
p_95.user_recommendation: Ensure internal processes can meet this delivery window.
p_95.model_instructions: This is an informational risk for Seller's awareness. Ensure property management has processes in place to generate updated rent rolls within this window. If operationally challenging, consider negotiating a wider window: 'No sooner than 15 Business Days prior to Closing and no later than 3 Business Days prior to Closing.'

p_96.title: Unlimited Survival for Reconciliation Obligations
p_96.description: Seller retains responsibility for 2025 Reconciliation Statements, including responsibility for tenant overpayment refunds and audit costs, with an express survival provision but no time limit. Tenant audit rights often extend 2-3 years under leases, meaning Seller could face claims for reconciliation errors or audit costs years after Closing with no cap or limitation.
p_96.problematic_text: The provisions of this Section 7.7 shall survive the Closing.
p_96.user_recommendation: Add survival period limit aligned with tenant audit rights in leases.
p_96.model_instructions: Add a reasonable time limitation on the survival of these obligations. Suggested revision: 'The provisions of this Section 7.7 shall survive the Closing for a period of twenty-four (24) months or, if longer, until the expiration of any applicable Tenant audit rights under the Leases with respect to 2025 operating expenses, but in no event longer than thirty-six (36) months after Closing.'

p_96.title: No Cap on Seller's Reconciliation and Audit Cost Liability
p_96.description: Seller is obligated to pay tenant overpayments and audit costs related to 2025 reconciliations without any cap or limitation. In a multi-tenant property with significant operating expense pass-throughs, errors in the 2025 reconciliation could result in substantial refund obligations. Additionally, multiple tenant audits could generate significant costs with no aggregate limit.
p_96.problematic_text: Seller shall promptly remit such overpayment to the Tenant
p_96.user_recommendation: Consider capping reconciliation liability or tying to representation survival cap.
p_96.model_instructions: Add a cap on Seller's aggregate liability for reconciliation-related payments. Suggested addition: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, Seller's aggregate liability for overpayment refunds, underpayment credits against delinquent rent, and audit costs under this Section 7.7 shall not exceed [$ amount or percentage of Purchase Price], and any amounts in excess thereof shall be Buyer's responsibility.' Alternatively, tie this liability to the overall representation and warranty cap in Section 5.4.

p_99.title: Broad Contract Definition Includes Leasing and Brokerage Agreements
p_99.description: The definition of 'Contracts' includes 'leasing, brokerage' agreements. This overlaps with the separate treatment of leases in Article 7 and brokerage commissions in Section 7.3. The breadth of this definition could create ambiguity about which provisions govern lease-related agreements and could inadvertently capture agreements that should be addressed separately under the leasing provisions.
p_99.problematic_text: management, leasing, brokerage, maintenance, construction and service contracts and agreements relating to the Property
p_99.user_recommendation: Confirm Exhibit D accurately segregates contracts from lease-related agreements.
p_99.model_instructions: Review Exhibit D to ensure clear delineation between Contracts subject to Article 8 and lease-related agreements subject to Article 7. Consider adding clarifying language: 'As used herein, "Contracts" means all currently effective management, maintenance, construction and service contracts and agreements relating to the Property (but excluding the Leases and any leasing commission agreements listed on Exhibit M), including all amendments thereto, relating to the ownership, operation and maintenance of the Property, all of which are identified in Exhibit D attached hereto.'

p_100.title: Seller Bears Contract Termination Costs
p_100.description: Seller is obligated to terminate at its 'sole cost and expense' any Contracts that Buyer does not elect to assume. This creates significant financial exposure for Seller, as some contracts may have substantial early termination fees, penalties, or buyout provisions. Buyer has complete discretion to designate which contracts to assume (or none at all), leaving Seller exposed to potentially unlimited termination costs without any cap or limitation.
p_100.problematic_text: Seller, at Seller's sole cost and expense, shall terminate any Contracts that are not Assumed Contracts
p_100.user_recommendation: Add cap on termination costs or require Buyer to share expenses above threshold.
p_100.model_instructions: Revise the sentence to limit Seller's exposure by adding: (i) a cap on termination costs Seller must bear, (ii) a requirement that Buyer assume contracts with termination costs exceeding a specified threshold, or (iii) a sharing mechanism where Buyer pays termination costs above a certain amount. Consider language such as: 'Seller, at Seller's cost and expense (not to exceed $[AMOUNT] in the aggregate), shall terminate any Contracts that are not Assumed Contracts; provided, however, that if the aggregate termination costs exceed $[AMOUNT], Buyer shall either assume such Contracts or pay the excess termination costs.'

p_100.title: Buyer Has Unlimited Contract Selection Discretion
p_100.description: Buyer has unfettered discretion to elect which contracts to assume and may elect to assume none of the Contracts. This one-sided approach allows Buyer to cherry-pick favorable contracts while forcing Seller to bear termination costs and potential liability for all others, with no requirement that Buyer's decisions be reasonable or made in good faith.
p_100.problematic_text: Buyer shall designate on or before the Due Diligence Deadline which Contracts Buyer elects to assume at Closing
p_100.user_recommendation: Require Buyer to act reasonably or assume contracts terminable without penalty.
p_100.model_instructions: Consider adding a reasonableness standard to Buyer's contract selection process, or require Buyer to assume contracts that are (i) terminable without penalty within a specified period, (ii) market-standard for properties of this type, or (iii) necessary for ongoing property operations. Alternative language: 'Buyer shall designate on or before the Due Diligence Deadline which Contracts Buyer elects to assume at Closing; provided that Buyer shall be required to assume any Contracts that are terminable on thirty (30) days or less notice without penalty.'

p_101.title: Broad Buyer Consent Right Over Contract Amendments
p_101.description: Seller cannot amend any Assumed Contracts without Buyer's prior consent, even though the 'not unreasonably withheld' standard applies. This limits Seller's operational flexibility during the period between contract designation and Closing, potentially preventing necessary amendments for property operations. Buyer could delay consent, creating operational difficulties.
p_101.problematic_text: amend any of the Assumed Contracts without the prior consent of Buyer
p_101.user_recommendation: Add deemed approval mechanism for amendments and time limit for Buyer response.
p_101.model_instructions: Add a time-limited response requirement and deemed approval mechanism for amendments. Consider adding: 'Buyer shall respond to any such request within five (5) Business Days, failing which Buyer shall be deemed to have consented to such amendment. Notwithstanding the foregoing, Seller may amend any Assumed Contract without Buyer's consent if such amendment (i) does not increase the economic obligations under such Contract, (ii) does not extend the term beyond the existing term, and (iii) is reasonably necessary for the continued operation of the Property.'

p_101.title: Limited Exception for New Service Contracts
p_101.description: While the carve-out for new service contracts that are cancelable on 30 days' notice provides some operational flexibility, Seller must still pay all amounts owing under such contracts unless they become Assumed Contracts. This could create cash flow obligations during the interim period that Seller cannot recover.
p_101.problematic_text: as to which all amounts owing thereunder have been or shall be paid by Seller unless they become an Assumed Contract
p_101.user_recommendation: Clarify that interim contract costs are prorated at Closing if assumed.
p_101.model_instructions: Clarify the treatment of amounts paid by Seller under interim service contracts by adding: 'provided, further, that if any such service contract becomes an Assumed Contract, Seller shall receive a credit at Closing for any prepaid amounts applicable to periods after Closing, and Buyer shall reimburse Seller at Closing for any reasonable amounts paid by Seller under such contract during the period between execution thereof and Closing.'

p_103.title: Extensive Notice Obligations on Seller
p_103.description: Seller has broad obligations to notify Buyer 'promptly' of numerous categories of matters including tenant defaults, contract disputes, condemnation, environmental matters, zoning proceedings, violations, litigation, and claims. The 'promptly' standard is vague and creates risk that Seller could be found in breach for delayed notification even of minor matters. The scope is very broad and could be burdensome to administer.
p_103.problematic_text: Seller shall notify or shall cause its property manager to notify Buyer of any written notice received by Seller or its property manager of any of the following matters promptly after Seller or its property manager has knowledge of such matter
p_103.user_recommendation: Define 'promptly' as specific timeframe and add materiality qualifier.
p_103.model_instructions: Revise the notification provision to provide clarity and limit exposure: (i) define 'promptly' as a specific timeframe (e.g., 'within five (5) Business Days'), (ii) add a materiality threshold for required notifications, and (iii) limit the knowledge standard to actual knowledge of Seller's Designated Representatives. Consider: 'Seller shall notify Buyer within five (5) Business Days after any Designated Representative obtains actual knowledge of any material written notice received by Seller regarding the following matters...'

p_103.title: Insurance Maintenance Obligation Through Closing
p_103.description: Seller must maintain existing insurance coverage with premiums paid through Closing Date. While standard, this obligates Seller to continue paying insurance premiums even if Closing is delayed by Buyer-caused extensions, potentially increasing Seller's carrying costs without recourse.
p_103.problematic_text: Seller shall maintain in full force and effect its existing insurance coverage with premiums paid through the Closing Date
p_103.user_recommendation: Require Buyer to reimburse insurance costs for any Buyer-caused Closing delays.
p_103.model_instructions: Add a provision requiring Buyer to reimburse Seller for insurance premium costs attributable to any extension of the Closing Date requested or caused by Buyer. Consider adding: 'In the event the Closing Date is extended at Buyer's request or due to Buyer's failure to satisfy a condition to Closing within Buyer's control, Buyer shall reimburse Seller at Closing for the pro rata portion of insurance premiums paid by Seller attributable to the period of such extension.'

p_104.title: Buyer Consent Required for Material Alterations
p_104.description: Seller cannot make 'material alterations' to the Property without Buyer's prior written approval. The term 'material' is undefined, creating ambiguity about what alterations require consent. Additionally, there is no deemed approval mechanism if Buyer fails to respond, potentially allowing Buyer to delay necessary property improvements through inaction.
p_104.problematic_text: Seller shall not make any material alterations to the Property without Buyer's prior written approval
p_104.user_recommendation: Define 'material alterations' with dollar threshold and add deemed approval timeline.
p_104.model_instructions: Revise to provide certainty by: (i) defining 'material alterations' with a specific dollar threshold, (ii) adding a deemed approval mechanism, and (iii) carving out emergency repairs. Consider: 'Seller shall not make any alterations to the Property costing in excess of $[50,000] individually or $[150,000] in the aggregate ('Material Alterations') without Buyer's prior written approval (which approval shall not be unreasonably withheld, conditioned, or delayed and shall be deemed granted if Buyer fails to respond within five (5) Business Days after written request); provided, however, that Seller may make emergency repairs necessary to protect life, safety, or property without Buyer's prior consent.'

p_104.title: Missing Closing Parenthesis in Approval Standard
p_104.description: There is a typographical error in this provision - the parenthetical phrase regarding Buyer's approval standard is missing the closing parenthesis. While likely a minor drafting oversight, this could create ambiguity in interpretation.
p_104.problematic_text: (which approval shall not be unreasonably withheld, conditioned, or delayed.
p_104.model_instructions: Correct the typographical error by adding a closing parenthesis after 'delayed' so the sentence reads: '...without Buyer's prior written approval (which approval shall not be unreasonably withheld, conditioned, or delayed).'

p_105.title: Vague Cooperation Standard Creates Disputes
p_105.description: The phrase 'reasonably cooperate' is subjective and undefined, which could lead to disputes about whether Seller has fulfilled its obligations. Buyer could claim Seller's cooperation was insufficient even when Seller believes it acted reasonably. Additionally, the obligation to 'request financial information' from tenants is open-ended and could require ongoing efforts.
p_105.problematic_text: Seller shall reasonably cooperate with Buyer's efforts to obtain financing for its acquisition of the Property
p_105.user_recommendation: Define specific cooperation tasks with clear limits on duration and scope.
p_105.model_instructions: Replace 'reasonably cooperate' with a defined list of specific cooperation items Seller agrees to perform, with express limitations. Add language such as: 'Seller's cooperation obligations shall be limited to: (i) providing not more than [2] sets of financial information requests to tenants during the period prior to Closing; (ii) delivering estoppel certificate and SNDA request forms prepared by Buyer to tenants within [5] Business Days of receipt; and (iii) permitting not more than [2] lender inspections of the Property. Seller shall have no obligation to negotiate with tenants regarding the content of estoppels or SNDAs or to take any action beyond delivery of Buyer's requests.'

p_105.title: Ambiguous Lease Enforcement Obligation
p_105.description: Seller is required to 'enforce' estoppel and SNDA requirements in leases. While there is a carve-out for filing claims or incurring substantial costs, the term 'substantial' is undefined and subjective. This could create disputes about what level of enforcement is required and expose Seller to claims of breach if Buyer believes enforcement efforts were insufficient.
p_105.problematic_text: enforcing such requirements for estoppel certificates and SNDAs to the extent the same may be required under the Leases (but without any need to file claims or incur substantial costs)
p_105.user_recommendation: Define 'substantial costs' with a dollar threshold and limit enforcement to written requests only.
p_105.model_instructions: Revise the enforcement language to clearly limit Seller's obligations. Replace with: 'Seller's enforcement obligations shall be limited to delivering written notices to tenants requesting compliance with estoppel and SNDA requirements under the applicable Leases, but Seller shall have no obligation to (a) file any legal action, (b) incur costs in excess of $[500] in connection with such enforcement, (c) threaten or pursue lease termination or default remedies, or (d) negotiate estoppel or SNDA content with any tenant.'

p_107.title: Mandatory Cure Period for All Condition Failures
p_107.description: Seller is given only 5 Business Days to cure any condition failure before Buyer can terminate. While a cure period is protective, certain conditions (such as title matters or third-party estoppels) may be impossible to cure within 5 Business Days, yet Buyer cannot terminate until this period expires. This could also delay Seller's ability to remarket the property. More critically, this applies even to conditions outside Seller's control.
p_107.problematic_text: Buyer shall not terminate this Agreement without giving Seller notice of the failure of such condition and a period of 5 Business Days after delivery of such notice for Seller to cause such condition to be satisfied
p_107.user_recommendation: Limit cure period to conditions within Seller's reasonable control.
p_107.model_instructions: Modify the cure period provision to distinguish between conditions Seller can control and those it cannot. Add: 'provided, further, that the foregoing 5 Business Day cure period shall only apply to conditions that are within Seller's reasonable control to satisfy (such as Seller's performance of covenants under Section 10.1.1), and shall not apply to conditions dependent upon third parties or circumstances outside Seller's reasonable control (such as the conditions set forth in Sections 10.1.2, 10.1.3, and any loan assumption approval condition).'

p_107.title: Broad Buyer Termination Right with Deposit Return
p_107.description: Buyer can terminate and receive the Earnest Money Deposit back if ANY of the closing conditions are not satisfied, regardless of fault. This includes conditions that depend on third parties (Title Company, tenants for estoppels, lender for loan assumption) and are outside Seller's control. Seller bears the risk of deal failure for circumstances it cannot control, yet loses the benefit of the Earnest Money Deposit.
p_107.problematic_text: If any of the conditions described below are not satisfied (or waived in writing by Buyer) prior to the Closing, then Buyer shall be entitled to: (a) to terminate this Agreement and receive the Earnest Money Deposit
p_107.user_recommendation: Limit deposit return to conditions within Seller's control or caused by Seller's default.
p_107.model_instructions: Add qualification to the deposit return provision: 'Buyer shall be entitled to receive the Earnest Money Deposit upon termination under this Section 10.1 only if the failed condition is (i) within Seller's reasonable control to satisfy, (ii) results from Seller's default or material breach of this Agreement, or (iii) is expressly designated elsewhere in this Agreement as entitling Buyer to return of the Earnest Money Deposit. For conditions dependent on third parties or circumstances outside Seller's control, the parties shall share the risk and, upon termination, the Earnest Money Deposit shall be [split equally between Buyer and Seller / retained by Seller as compensation for taking the Property off the market].'

p_108.title: Representations Must Remain True Through Closing
p_108.description: Seller's representations must not only be true at signing but must 'remain true and correct in all material respects' through Closing. This creates ongoing exposure for matters that may change between signing and closing due to circumstances outside Seller's control (e.g., a new governmental notice, tenant bankruptcy). While the 'material respects' qualifier provides some protection, Seller bears risk for changed circumstances.
p_108.problematic_text: such representations and warranties shall have remained true and correct in all material respects
p_108.user_recommendation: Add knowledge qualifier and limit to matters within Seller's control.
p_108.model_instructions: Consider adding protective language: 'such representations and warranties shall have remained true and correct in all material respects as of Closing, except for changes (i) resulting from actions taken by Seller with Buyer's prior written consent, (ii) disclosed in writing to Buyer prior to Closing and accepted by Buyer, or (iii) arising from matters outside Seller's reasonable control that do not have a Material Adverse Effect on the Property.' Define Material Adverse Effect with a dollar threshold if desired.

p_109.title: Title Company Commitment as Buyer Condition
p_109.description: Buyer's obligation to close is conditioned on Title Company being 'irrevocably committed' to issue the Title Policy. This is a third-party condition outside Seller's control. If Title Company has issues (staffing, internal policy changes, disputes over coverage) that prevent it from being 'irrevocably committed,' Buyer can terminate and receive its deposit back even though Seller did nothing wrong.
p_109.problematic_text: The Title Company shall be irrevocably committed and ready, willing and able to issue the Title Policy
p_109.user_recommendation: Require Buyer to work in good faith to resolve Title Company issues before terminating.
p_109.model_instructions: Add protective language: 'The Title Company shall be irrevocably committed and ready, willing and able to issue the Title Policy; provided, however, that if the Title Company's failure to be so committed results from matters other than defects in Seller's title or Seller's failure to deliver required title clearance documents, Buyer shall use commercially reasonable efforts for a period of [10] Business Days to obtain such commitment from an alternative nationally-recognized title insurance company before exercising any termination right under this Section.'

p_110.title: Loan Assumption Approval as Buyer Condition
p_110.description: If this optional provision is included, Buyer's obligation to close is conditioned on obtaining the Existing Loan Assumption Approval. Lender approval is entirely outside Seller's control and depends on Buyer's creditworthiness and lender's discretion. Yet if approval is not obtained, Buyer can presumably terminate and receive its deposit back, leaving Seller with no deal and no compensation for taking the property off market.
p_110.problematic_text: The Existing Loan Assumption Approval has been obtained
p_110.user_recommendation: Make loan assumption Buyer's risk or require deposit going hard after diligence.
p_110.model_instructions: If this provision is included, add significant protections: 'The Existing Loan Assumption Approval has been obtained; provided, however, that (i) Buyer shall diligently pursue such approval in good faith, including promptly providing all information and documentation requested by Existing Lender, (ii) if such approval has not been obtained by [DATE] due to Buyer's failure to diligently pursue such approval or Buyer's failure to satisfy Existing Lender's underwriting requirements, Buyer shall not be entitled to terminate this Agreement or receive return of the Earnest Money Deposit, and (iii) Buyer's right to terminate under this condition shall expire on [DATE], after which Buyer shall be obligated to close or be in default.' Alternatively, consider making this a Buyer-only risk with no termination right.

p_112.title: Burdensome Estoppel Threshold for Closing
p_112.description: This condition requires Seller to obtain Conforming Tenant Estoppels from ALL Major Tenants plus additional tenants covering at least 80% of leased square footage. This is a high bar that gives Buyer significant leverage since Seller cannot control tenant responsiveness. If even one Major Tenant fails to provide a conforming estoppel, the condition fails regardless of the 80% threshold for other tenants. The conjunctive 'all of the Major Tenants plus' language creates a dual requirement that could allow Buyer to walk away from the deal even if substantially all tenants have provided estoppels.
p_112.problematic_text: all of the Major Tenants plus a sufficient number of other Tenants under Leases so that Buyer has received Conforming Tenant Estoppels for Leases covering at least 80%
p_112.user_recommendation: Reduce to Major Tenants OR 80% threshold, add Seller estoppel option
p_112.model_instructions: Revise this condition to be less burdensome on Seller by: (1) changing 'all of the Major Tenants plus' to 'Major Tenants representing at least [X]% of leased square footage and' making it an alternative rather than cumulative requirement; (2) reducing the 80% threshold to 70% or 75%; (3) adding language permitting Seller to provide a Seller estoppel certificate (with liability capped and limited survival) in lieu of any non-responsive tenant estoppels; and (4) adding a materiality qualifier such that minor deviations in tenant estoppels from lease terms do not render them non-conforming. Consider adding: 'provided, however, that if a tenant fails to deliver an estoppel despite Seller's commercially reasonable efforts, Seller may deliver a Seller's Estoppel Certificate with respect to such tenant's Lease, which shall satisfy this condition with respect to such tenant.'

p_112.title: Conforming Tenant Estoppels Undefined Here
p_112.description: The term 'Conforming Tenant Estoppels' is critical to this closing condition but is not defined in this section. If the definition elsewhere in the agreement is broad or allows Buyer significant discretion in determining what 'conforms,' Seller faces risk that estoppels may be rejected on technical grounds, potentially allowing Buyer to avoid closing even when tenants have substantially confirmed lease terms.
p_112.user_recommendation: Verify definition of Conforming Tenant Estoppels limits Buyer discretion
p_112.model_instructions: Review the definition of 'Conforming Tenant Estoppels' in Section 7.1 or elsewhere in the Agreement to ensure it includes objective standards and does not grant Buyer subjective discretion to reject estoppels. If the definition allows Buyer to reject estoppels for immaterial discrepancies or contains 'Buyer's satisfaction' language, recommend revising to include objective standards with materiality thresholds. Consider adding language that deviations are only non-conforming if they reveal a material adverse difference from the rent roll or could materially impact the value or operation of the Property.

p_114.title: Seller Has Shorter Practical Cure Rights Than Buyer
p_114.description: While Section 10.2 provides Seller with a 5 Business Day notice and cure period before terminating for Buyer's failure of conditions, this is a relatively short period for Buyer to cure certain failures. However, reviewing the Buyer's conditions in Section 10.1, there appears to be no reciprocal notice and cure period for Seller before Buyer can terminate. This asymmetry favors Buyer and should be addressed by either reducing Seller's obligation to provide cure notice or ensuring Buyer has a similar obligation to notify Seller of condition failures with a cure period.
p_114.problematic_text: Seller shall not terminate this Agreement without giving Buyer notice of the failure of such condition, and a period of 5 Business Days after delivery of such notice for Buyer to cause such condition to be satisfied
p_114.user_recommendation: Add reciprocal notice and cure requirement for Buyer's termination rights
p_114.model_instructions: This cure period provision benefits Buyer but creates asymmetry. Either: (1) remove this cure period requirement to put parties on equal footing, or (2) add parallel language to Section 10.1 requiring Buyer to give Seller notice of any failed Buyer's condition and a cure period of at least 5 Business Days (or preferably 10 Business Days for conditions within Seller's control like document delivery or estoppels) before Buyer may terminate. Also consider whether the 5 Business Day cure period is sufficient for Buyer to cure performance defaults and whether a shorter period would be more protective of Seller's interests.

p_115.title: Material Respects Qualifier May Be Subjective
p_115.description: The 'in all material respects' qualifier for Buyer's covenant performance provides appropriate flexibility but could be subject to interpretation disputes. While this is generally a balanced standard, Seller should ensure the Agreement does not elsewhere define 'material' in a way that is overly favorable to Buyer or that Buyer's key obligations (such as funding at Closing) are not subject to this materiality qualifier.
p_115.user_recommendation: Acceptable standard; verify key payment obligations not subject to materiality
p_115.model_instructions: This is a market-standard formulation that is generally acceptable for Seller. However, verify that Buyer's core obligations—particularly the obligation to deliver the Purchase Price at Closing under Section 11.5.1—are not subject to this materiality qualifier. Payment obligations should be absolute. No changes required to this specific provision unless Buyer seeks to weaken it further.

p_116.title: Double Materiality Standard is Favorable
p_116.description: This provision contains both 'no material breach' and 'true and correct in all material respects' qualifiers, which is protective of Buyer by providing a double layer of materiality requirements. From Seller's perspective, this is favorable as it requires symmetry—Seller should verify that Seller's equivalent condition in Section 10.1 contains similar materiality qualifiers for Seller's representations. This ensures Buyer cannot terminate for immaterial breaches of Seller's representations while Seller must tolerate material breaches of Buyer's representations.
p_116.problematic_text: no material breach of any representations and warranties made by Buyer in Article 6 above, and such representations, warranties or covenants shall have remained true and correct in all material respects
p_116.user_recommendation: Confirm equivalent materiality protection exists for Seller's reps in 10.1
p_116.model_instructions: This provision is favorable to Seller in that it requires materiality for both breach and accuracy of Buyer's representations. Verify that Buyer's closing condition regarding Seller's representations (likely in Section 10.1 or incorporated by reference) contains equivalent materiality qualifiers. If Buyer's condition regarding Seller's representations does not include materiality qualifiers, recommend adding them to achieve symmetry. The current formulation for Buyer's reps is market-standard and protective of Seller.

p_119.title: Closing Condition Tied to Buyer Deliveries
p_119.description: This seller closing condition simply requires Buyer to deliver specified items per Section 11.5. While this is appropriate, Seller should verify that Section 11.5 contains all necessary buyer deliverables and that there are no gaps in required documentation that could create closing complications or leave Seller without necessary protections.
p_119.problematic_text: Buyer's delivery to escrow of the funds, documents and items specified in Section 11.5 below
p_119.user_recommendation: Verify Section 11.5 contains all required Buyer deliverables.
p_119.model_instructions: Review Section 11.5 (p_137 through p_143) to confirm all necessary buyer deliverables are included. Consider whether Seller needs any additional documents not currently listed, such as: (1) evidence of Buyer's entity authorization/good standing, (2) assignment and assumption agreements for any assumed obligations, (3) required consents or approvals Buyer is responsible for obtaining, (4) Buyer's representations certificate at closing. If gaps exist, add the required items to Section 11.5 and ensure this cross-reference captures them.

p_123.title: Mutual Extension Right is Balanced
p_123.description: This provision grants both parties equal one-business-day extension rights with a nominal $5,000 payment. While facially balanced, Seller should be aware this gives Buyer an additional day to close beyond the scheduled date, which could delay Seller's receipt of proceeds and create uncertainty. The provision does appropriately require the payment to be funded (for Buyer) in advance.
p_123.problematic_text: Each of Buyer and Seller shall have the right to extend the Closing Date one time by 1 Business Day
p_123.user_recommendation: Consider whether $5,000 adequately compensates for one-day delay.
p_123.model_instructions: The mutual one-business-day extension is relatively standard but consider whether the $5,000 payment adequately compensates Seller for a closing delay. For a significant transaction, Seller may want to increase this amount or require Buyer to provide evidence of readiness to close before exercising this right. If modification is desired, revise to state: 'Each of Buyer and Seller shall have the right to extend the Closing Date one time by 1 Business Day by delivering notice on or before the Closing Date of such extension to the other party and authorizing (and in the case of Buyer additionally funding) a $10,000 payment to the other party at Closing through escrow; provided, however, Buyer may only exercise such right if Buyer demonstrates to Seller's reasonable satisfaction that Buyer is ready, willing and able to close except for administrative matters requiring the additional day.'

p_124.title: Buyer Has 20-Day Unilateral Extension
p_124.description: This provision grants Buyer a unilateral right to extend closing by up to 20 Business Days (approximately one month of calendar time) with only a 50% additional deposit requirement. This is a significant risk to Seller as it creates substantial uncertainty about closing timing, ties up the Property for an extended period, delays Seller's receipt of proceeds, and may cause Seller to miss other opportunities or incur holding costs. The 'diligent and good faith effort' standard is subjective and difficult to enforce.
p_124.problematic_text: Buyer shall have the right to extend the Closing Date one time for up to 20 Business Days
p_124.user_recommendation: Reduce extension period, increase deposit, or add objective conditions.
p_124.model_instructions: This buyer-favorable extension right should be significantly modified to protect Seller. Consider the following revisions: (1) Reduce the extension period from 20 Business Days to 10 Business Days maximum; (2) Increase the additional deposit from 50% to 100% of the original Earnest Money; (3) Make the additional deposit non-refundable to Seller if Buyer fails to close during the extension; (4) Replace the subjective 'diligent and good faith effort' standard with objective conditions such as requiring Buyer to demonstrate that financing commitment is in place and only administrative/ministerial matters remain; (5) Require Buyer to identify the specific reason for the extension. Suggested revision: '11.2.2 Additional Buyer's Extension Option. If Buyer has obtained a binding financing commitment and is otherwise ready, willing and able to close but requires additional time solely to complete administrative closing mechanics, Buyer shall have the right to extend the Closing Date one time for up to 10 Business Days by delivering notice on or before the Closing Date identifying the specific reason for extension and, within 2 Business Days after delivering such notice, depositing with Escrow Agent in cash an amount equal to 100% of the original Earnest Money Deposit (the "Extension Deposit"). If Buyer fails to close during the extension period for any reason other than Seller default, the Extension Deposit shall be released to Seller as additional liquidated damages.'

p_124.title: Subjective Good Faith Effort Standard
p_124.description: The condition that Buyer must have made 'diligent and good faith effort to close' before exercising the extension option is subjective and difficult for Seller to verify or challenge. Buyer could claim good faith efforts while actually delaying intentionally, and Seller would bear the burden of proving otherwise. This creates uncertainty and potential for disputes.
p_124.problematic_text: despite Buyer's diligent and good faith effort to close on the scheduled Closing Date
p_124.user_recommendation: Replace subjective standard with objective closing readiness requirements.
p_124.model_instructions: Replace the vague 'diligent and good faith effort' language with objective, verifiable conditions. Revised language: 'If Buyer (a) has obtained all necessary internal approvals and financing commitments, (b) has deposited all required funds with Escrow Agent, (c) has delivered or is prepared to deliver all documents required under Section 11.5, and (d) requires additional time solely due to circumstances beyond Buyer's reasonable control (which Buyer shall identify in writing), Buyer shall have the right to extend the Closing Date...' This provides Seller with clear, objective criteria to evaluate whether Buyer is entitled to the extension.

p_124.title: Extension Deposit Becomes Refundable Earnest Money
p_124.description: The additional deposit required for the extension becomes part of the Earnest Money Deposit, meaning it would be refundable to Buyer in circumstances where the original Earnest Money is refundable. Seller takes on extended closing risk without additional protection. The extension deposit should be non-refundable or at least harder-earned to adequately compensate Seller for the delay.
p_124.problematic_text: which amount the Escrow Agent will deposit and hold in the same interest bearing account as the Earnest Money Deposit and shall, upon being deposited, constitute part of the Earnest Money Deposit
p_124.user_recommendation: Make extension deposit non-refundable or independent of Earnest Money.
p_124.model_instructions: Modify the treatment of the extension deposit to provide Seller with meaningful compensation for agreeing to delay closing. Revised language: '...depositing with Escrow Agent, in cash an amount equal to 50% of the original Earnest Money Deposit (the "Extension Deposit"). The Extension Deposit shall be held by Escrow Agent separately from the Earnest Money Deposit. The Extension Deposit shall be non-refundable to Buyer and shall be released to Seller upon disbursement of funds at Closing as a credit against the Purchase Price; provided, however, if Buyer fails to close during the extension period for any reason other than Seller's default or the failure of a Buyer closing condition set forth in Section 10.1, the Extension Deposit shall be immediately released to Seller as additional consideration for granting the extension, independent of and in addition to any liquidated damages to which Seller may be entitled under Section 13.2.'

p_125.title: Recording Contingent on Both Parties' Deposits
p_125.description: The closing mechanics require both Seller's and Buyer's documents to be deposited before the Escrow Agent will record the deed. If Buyer fails to timely deposit required items, closing is delayed through no fault of Seller. While this is standard escrow practice, the provision should be paired with clear consequences for Buyer's failure to timely deposit, which should trigger default provisions.
p_125.problematic_text: Provided that all funds and documents required under Sections 11.4 and 11.5 below have been deposited into escrow
p_125.user_recommendation: Ensure Buyer's failure to deposit triggers default provisions.
p_125.model_instructions: Add language clarifying that Buyer's failure to timely deposit required funds and documents constitutes a default. After the existing sentence, add: 'Buyer's failure to deposit all funds and documents required under Section 11.5 by the Deposit Deadline shall constitute a default by Buyer under this Agreement, entitling Seller to the remedies set forth in Section 13.2. For the avoidance of doubt, if Seller has deposited all items required under Section 11.4 by the Deposit Deadline but Buyer has not deposited all items required under Section 11.5 by such time, Buyer shall be in default and Seller shall have no obligation to proceed with Closing.'

p_125.title: Placeholder for Local Time Zone
p_125.description: The provision contains a placeholder '***INSERT LOCAL TIME***' that must be completed before execution. Failure to specify the correct time zone could create ambiguity about the actual deadline, particularly if parties are in different time zones.
p_125.problematic_text: no later than 3:00 pm ***INSERT LOCAL TIME*** on the Closing Date
p_125.user_recommendation: Ensure time zone is specified before execution (e.g., Pacific Time).
p_125.model_instructions: Replace the placeholder with the specific time zone applicable to the Property location. Since the Property appears to be in Seattle, Washington based on the Escrow Agent address, the provision should read: 'no later than 3:00 pm Pacific Time on the Closing Date'. Ensure consistency with any other time references in the Agreement.

p_128.title: Special Warranty Deed Appropriate for Seller
p_128.description: The use of a Special Warranty Deed rather than a General Warranty Deed is favorable to Seller as it limits Seller's warranty of title to defects arising only during Seller's period of ownership. This is market-standard for commercial transactions and appropriately protects Seller from claims regarding title defects that predate Seller's ownership. No changes recommended.
p_128.user_recommendation: No action needed - Special Warranty Deed is appropriate for Seller.
p_128.model_instructions: No modifications required. The Special Warranty Deed form is favorable to Seller as it limits title warranties to the period of Seller's ownership only, which is the market-standard approach for commercial real estate transactions.

p_129.title: Lease Assignment Without Liability Release
p_129.description: The Assignment and Assumption of Leases assigns landlord obligations to Buyer, but the clause does not explicitly reference that Buyer assumes all obligations arising from and after Closing or that Seller is released from post-Closing obligations. Without clear release language in the assignment document (Exhibit F), Seller could remain liable to tenants for landlord obligations even after Closing. This risk depends on the specific language in Exhibit F, which should be reviewed.
p_129.problematic_text: Two counterparts of the Assignment and Assumption of Leases executed by Seller in the form attached hereto as Exhibit F
p_129.user_recommendation: Ensure Exhibit F includes express release of Seller from post-Closing landlord obligations.
