p_129.model_instructions: Review Exhibit F (Lease Assignment) to confirm it contains: (1) Buyer's express assumption of all landlord obligations arising from and after Closing; (2) Buyer's indemnification of Seller for all claims arising from Buyer's acts or omissions as landlord after Closing; and (3) if possible, language releasing Seller from all lease obligations accruing after Closing. If these protections are not in Exhibit F, add them or include a cross-reference here requiring such provisions.

p_130.title: Contract Assignment Without Liability Release
p_130.description: Similar to the Lease Assignment, the Assignment and Assumption of Contracts and Intangibles should include express assumption by Buyer of all obligations arising after Closing and an indemnification of Seller. The risk is that Seller could remain liable to vendors and service providers under assigned contracts if Buyer defaults on post-Closing obligations. The specific terms of Exhibit G should be reviewed to confirm adequate protection.
p_130.problematic_text: Two counterparts of the Assignment and Assumption of Contracts and Intangibles executed by Seller in the form attached hereto as Exhibit G
p_130.user_recommendation: Ensure Exhibit G includes Buyer's assumption and indemnification for post-Closing obligations.
p_130.model_instructions: Review Exhibit G (Contract Assignment) to confirm it contains: (1) Buyer's express assumption of all obligations under the assigned contracts arising from and after Closing; (2) Buyer's indemnification of Seller for all claims, liabilities, and costs arising from Buyer's failure to perform obligations under assigned contracts after Closing; and (3) clear delineation that Seller remains responsible only for obligations accruing prior to Closing. If these protections are not in Exhibit G, they should be added.

p_131.title: Bill of Sale Warranty Scope
p_131.description: The Bill of Sale conveys personal property. Seller should ensure that Exhibit H provides only limited warranties (such as 'AS-IS' or warranty of title only without warranty of condition) consistent with the AS-IS provisions in Section 2.2. If the Bill of Sale contains broader warranties regarding the condition of personal property, it could create inconsistency with the AS-IS framework and expose Seller to claims.
p_131.problematic_text: Two counterparts of the Bill of Sale for the Personal Property executed by Seller in the form attached hereto as Exhibit H
p_131.user_recommendation: Confirm Exhibit H Bill of Sale is consistent with AS-IS provisions.
p_131.model_instructions: Review Exhibit H (Bill of Sale) to confirm that: (1) personal property is conveyed 'AS-IS, WHERE-IS' without warranty of condition, consistent with Section 2.2; (2) Seller warrants only that it has title to the personal property and the right to convey it; and (3) there are no express or implied warranties of merchantability, fitness for a particular purpose, or condition. If the Bill of Sale contains broader warranties, revise to align with the AS-IS framework established in Section 2.2.

p_127.title: Deposit Timing Linked to Closing
p_127.description: The phrase 'On or before Closing' for Seller's delivery obligations is standard and appropriate. However, Seller should coordinate with Escrow Agent regarding actual timing of deposits to ensure closing mechanics in Section 11.3 are satisfied and there is no risk of Buyer claiming Seller failed to timely deposit required items.
p_127.problematic_text: On or before Closing, Seller shall deposit into escrow the following items
p_127.user_recommendation: Coordinate with Escrow Agent on delivery timing before scheduled Closing.
p_127.model_instructions: No substantive changes required to the contract language. The timing 'On or before Closing' is standard. Advise Seller to coordinate with Escrow Agent (First American Title) in advance of Closing to ensure all documents are deposited with sufficient time for review and to avoid any claim by Buyer that closing conditions were not timely satisfied. Consider establishing an internal deadline of 1-2 business days before Closing for delivery of all Seller documents.

p_133.title: Unlimited Title Company Document Requirements
p_133.description: This provision obligates Seller to provide not only the Owner's Title Affidavit but also 'such other documents as may be reasonably or customarily required by the Title Company or Escrow Agent.' This open-ended language gives the Title Company and Escrow Agent significant discretion to demand additional documents from Seller at closing, potentially creating unexpected obligations, delays, or liability exposure. While qualified by 'reasonably or customarily,' these standards are subjective and could be interpreted broadly by the Title Company.
p_133.problematic_text: such other documents as may be reasonably or customarily required by the Title Company or Escrow Agent to issue the Title Policy and close this transaction
p_133.user_recommendation: Add specificity or cap on additional document requirements.
p_133.model_instructions: Revise to limit the scope of additional documents Seller must provide. Consider language such as: 'such other documents as may be reasonably required by the Title Company or Escrow Agent to issue the Title Policy and close this transaction, provided that (i) such documents shall be limited to customary affidavits and certifications that do not expand Seller's liability beyond what is expressly set forth in this Agreement, (ii) Seller shall not be required to provide any documents that would impose additional representations, warranties, or indemnities beyond those contained herein, and (iii) Seller shall have reasonable opportunity to review and approve the form of any such documents prior to execution.'

p_134.title: Unlimited Lender Document Requirements for Assumption
p_134.description: This optional provision requires Seller to execute 'Existing Loan Assumption Documents that Existing Lender is requiring' without any limitation on scope, content, or liability. Lenders in assumption scenarios often require broad indemnities, representations, and ongoing obligations from sellers. This provision gives the Existing Lender carte blanche to impose whatever document requirements it wishes, potentially exposing Seller to significant post-closing liability, indemnification obligations, or other burdensome terms that are not contemplated elsewhere in this Agreement.
p_134.problematic_text: The Existing Loan Assumption Documents that Existing Lender is requiring Seller or other Seller-related parties to execute and deliver at Closing to carry out the assumption of the Existing Loan
p_134.user_recommendation: Add limitations on lender-required documents and Seller's obligations.
p_134.model_instructions: Revise to protect Seller from unlimited lender requirements. Suggested language: 'The Existing Loan Assumption Documents that Existing Lender is requiring Seller or other Seller-related parties to execute and deliver at Closing to carry out the assumption of the Existing Loan; provided, however, that (i) Seller shall not be required to execute any documents that impose indemnification obligations, representations, warranties, or covenants that survive Closing other than as expressly set forth in this Agreement, (ii) Seller shall not be required to execute any guaranty or remain liable for any obligations under the Existing Loan following Closing, (iii) any documents requiring Seller's execution shall be in form reasonably acceptable to Seller, and (iv) Buyer shall indemnify and hold Seller harmless from any claims arising from the Existing Loan from and after Closing, except to the extent arising from Seller's fraud or intentional misrepresentation.'

p_135.title: Broad Post-Closing Document Delivery Obligation
p_135.description: This provision requires Seller to deliver 'all keys,' 'originals' of Leases, Estoppels, Contracts, and 'other Due Diligence Materials' to Buyer. The phrase 'other Due Diligence Materials' is very broad and undefined, potentially encompassing a wide range of documents. Additionally, requiring delivery of 'all' keys and 'originals' creates an absolute standard that may be difficult to fully satisfy, potentially giving Buyer grounds to claim non-performance even for minor oversights.
p_135.problematic_text: all keys to the Property and originals to the extent in Seller's possession and otherwise copies of all Leases, Conforming Tenant Estoppels, Assumed Contracts and other Due Diligence Materials
p_135.model_instructions: Revise to add appropriate qualifiers and specificity: 'Upon Closing, Seller shall deliver to Buyer outside of escrow, to the extent in Seller's actual possession and control, (i) keys to the Property that are in Seller's or Seller's property manager's possession, (ii) originals (or copies if originals are not in Seller's possession) of the Leases, Conforming Tenant Estoppels, and Assumed Contracts, and (iii) copies of any other Due Diligence Materials previously identified by Buyer in writing prior to Closing that are in Seller's possession. Seller makes no representation that it possesses all keys to the Property or all originals of the foregoing documents, and Seller's inadvertent failure to deliver any such items shall not constitute a default hereunder or give rise to any liability.'

p_135.title: No Time Limit for Post-Closing Delivery
p_135.description: The provision states delivery occurs 'Upon Closing' but does not specify a deadline for items delivered 'outside of escrow.' This creates ambiguity about when Seller must complete delivery and potentially leaves Seller exposed to claims for delayed delivery indefinitely after closing.
p_135.problematic_text: Upon Closing, Seller shall deliver to Buyer outside of escrow
p_135.user_recommendation: Add reasonable timeframe for post-closing deliveries.
p_135.model_instructions: Revise to add a specific timeframe: 'Within five (5) Business Days following Closing, Seller shall deliver to Buyer outside of escrow, to the extent in Seller's possession and control...' This provides clarity and a definite endpoint for Seller's delivery obligation.

p_138.title: Undefined 'Additional Funds' Requirement
p_138.description: The phrase 'such additional funds as are necessary to close this transaction' is vague and open-ended. While intended to cover closing costs and prorations, this language could theoretically be interpreted broadly by Buyer to limit amounts deposited or create disputes about what funds are 'necessary.' From Seller's perspective, this should be tied more specifically to the closing statement and defined obligations to ensure Buyer deposits all required amounts without dispute.
p_138.problematic_text: such additional funds as are necessary to close this transaction
p_138.user_recommendation: Specify that funds must match the closing statement calculations.
p_138.model_instructions: Revise the clause to read: 'The balance of the Purchase Price and such additional funds as are reflected on the Closing Statement prepared pursuant to Section 11.8 hereof, including without limitation all closing costs, prorations, and other amounts payable by Buyer pursuant to this Agreement.' This ties the obligation to the specific closing statement mechanism and clarifies Buyer's complete funding obligation.

p_138.title: No Wire Deadline Specified
p_138.description: The clause requires deposit of funds but does not specify a deadline within the closing day for when funds must be wired. Late-day wire transfers could delay closing or push recording to the following day, creating title gap exposure for Seller. While Section 11.3 addresses closing mechanics generally, a specific wire deadline for Buyer's funds would strengthen Seller's position.
p_138.problematic_text: On or before Closing, Buyer shall deposit into escrow the following items
p_138.user_recommendation: Consider adding a specific wire deadline (e.g., 12:00 PM on Closing Date).
p_138.model_instructions: Add timing language to the lead-in to Section 11.5 (found in p_137) or to this specific subsection: 'Buyer shall cause all funds required under this Section 11.5.1 to be deposited with Escrow Agent in immediately available funds no later than 12:00 p.m. Pacific Time on the Closing Date, or such earlier time as required by Escrow Agent to ensure same-day recording and disbursement.' This protects Seller from late-day funding issues.

p_139.title: No Cure Period for Document Delivery Failure
p_139.description: If Buyer fails to deliver the executed Lease Assignment by closing, there is no express cure period before Seller can declare default. While this is generally favorable to Seller as it creates strict compliance requirements, Seller should be aware this cuts both ways under Section 11.4 obligations. The provision is adequately protective of Seller's interests.
p_139.problematic_text: Two counterparts of the Lease Assignment executed by Buyer
p_139.user_recommendation: No change needed - strict compliance requirement benefits Seller.
p_139.model_instructions: No modification required. The absence of a cure period for document delivery is appropriate and protects Seller by ensuring Buyer must have all documents ready at closing without additional time allowances.

p_142.title: Open-Ended Loan Assumption Document Obligations
p_142.description: This optional clause requires Buyer to execute whatever documents 'Existing Lender is requiring' without any limitation or reasonableness standard. While the obligation appropriately falls on Buyer, the lack of any qualifier could create closing delays if Buyer objects to lender-required documents as unreasonable. From Seller's perspective, this should be strengthened to clearly obligate Buyer to execute all lender-required documents without objection.
p_142.problematic_text: The Existing Loan Assumption Documents that Existing Lender is requiring Buyer or other Buyer-related parties to execute and deliver
p_142.user_recommendation: Add language requiring Buyer to execute all lender documents without objection.
p_142.model_instructions: Strengthen the clause to read: 'The Existing Loan Assumption Documents that Existing Lender is requiring Buyer or other Buyer-related parties to execute and deliver at Closing to carry out the assumption of the Existing Loan, which documents Buyer agrees to execute without objection so long as such documents are consistent with the terms of the Existing Loan and do not impose material obligations on Seller beyond those contemplated by this Agreement.' This clarifies Buyer's obligation while providing reasonable protection.

p_142.title: Existing Loan Assumption Documents Not Defined
p_142.description: The term 'Existing Loan Assumption Documents' is used but does not appear to be defined in the definitions section. This creates ambiguity about exactly what documents Buyer must execute. For Seller's protection, a clear definition should be added to ensure Buyer cannot dispute document requirements at closing.
p_142.user_recommendation: Add definition of 'Existing Loan Assumption Documents' to Article 1.
p_142.model_instructions: Add a definition to Article 1: '"Existing Loan Assumption Documents" means all documents, instruments, and agreements required by Existing Lender in connection with Buyer's assumption of the Existing Loan, including without limitation assumption agreements, loan modification agreements, legal opinions, organizational documents, guaranties (if required), environmental indemnities, and any other documents customarily required by lenders in connection with commercial mortgage loan assumptions.' This provides clarity and prevents closing disputes.

p_143.title: Undefined Buyer Document Obligations
p_143.description: This catch-all provision requires Buyer to deliver 'such other documents as may be reasonably or customarily required' by the Title Company or Escrow Agent. While limited by 'reasonably,' this creates potential for last-minute document demands that could delay closing or impose unexpected burdens. More critically from Seller's perspective, this open-ended language could give Buyer an argument to object to closing if they disagree about what documents are 'reasonable' or 'customary,' potentially creating a manufactured condition to closing.
p_143.problematic_text: Such other documents as may be reasonably or customarily required by the Title Company or Escrow Agent
p_143.user_recommendation: Add time limit and clarify disputes don't delay closing.
p_143.model_instructions: Revise to add: (i) a requirement that any such document requests be made at least 5 Business Days prior to Closing; (ii) language stating that Buyer's good faith disagreement about whether a requested document is reasonable or customary shall not constitute a failure of a closing condition or excuse Buyer's obligation to close; and (iii) clarify that such documents shall be limited to standard affidavits, certifications, or similar documents that do not impose material additional liability on Buyer.

p_146.title: Unlimited Customary Seller Costs
p_146.description: Subsection (e) obligates Seller to pay 'any additional costs and charges customarily charged to sellers in accordance with common escrow practices.' This open-ended language creates significant exposure for Seller as 'customary' practices may vary, evolve, or be interpreted broadly. Unlike the specific enumerated costs in (a)-(d), this catch-all has no cap and could result in unexpected closing costs being imposed on Seller based on Title Company or Escrow Agent assertions about local 'custom.'
p_146.problematic_text: any additional costs and charges customarily charged to sellers in accordance with common escrow practices in the state and county in which the Property is located
p_146.user_recommendation: Delete catch-all or cap at specific dollar amount.
p_146.model_instructions: Either delete subsection (e) entirely, or replace it with: '(e) any additional costs and charges customarily charged to sellers in accordance with common escrow practices in the state and county in which the Property is located, provided that any such additional costs under this subsection (e) shall not exceed $5,000 in the aggregate without Seller's prior written consent.' Alternatively, require that any claimed 'customary' costs be documented in writing and agreed to by Seller at least 10 Business Days prior to Closing.

p_146.title: Recording Costs Beyond Deed Unclear
p_146.description: Seller is obligated to pay 'the cost of recording the Deed' but the agreement does not address who pays for recording other documents that may be required at closing (releases, termination statements, memoranda, etc.). This ambiguity could be resolved against Seller under the catch-all 'customary' provision or lead to closing disputes.
p_146.problematic_text: the cost of recording the Deed
p_146.user_recommendation: Clarify Buyer pays for all other recording costs.
p_146.model_instructions: Modify subsection (c) to read: '(c) the cost of recording the Deed and any documents necessary to release liens or encumbrances that Seller is obligated to remove under this Agreement;' and add to Section 11.6.3: 'Buyer shall pay for the recording of all other documents, including any memoranda, financing documents, or other instruments Buyer elects to record.'

p_147.title: Buyer Due Diligence Costs Confirmed
p_147.description: The final sentence confirms Buyer is solely responsible for due diligence investigation costs, which is favorable to Seller. This is noted for completeness as it reinforces Seller's position, but Seller should ensure this is consistent with any due diligence materials delivery obligations in Section 3.3 that may require Seller to bear costs of producing existing reports.
p_147.problematic_text: Buyer shall be solely responsible for any costs incurred in connection with Buyer's Due Diligence investigations of the Property, including Inspections and Surveys
p_147.model_instructions: Review Section 3.3 (Due Diligence Materials) to ensure there is no inconsistency. Consider adding clarifying language: 'For avoidance of doubt, Seller's obligation to deliver existing Due Diligence Materials under Section 3.3 shall not be deemed to make Seller responsible for any costs associated with Buyer's independent investigations, inspections, or due diligence activities.'

p_148.title: Each Party Bears Own Legal Costs
p_148.description: This provision requires each party to pay its own counsel costs, which is market-standard but worth noting. Seller should be aware this may not apply in default situations where Section 16.10 (Attorneys' Fees) provides the prevailing party may recover fees. Ensure this provision does not inadvertently limit Seller's fee recovery rights under the default provisions.
p_148.problematic_text: Each party shall pay for the costs of their respective counsel in connection with Closing and this transaction
p_148.user_recommendation: Confirm this doesn't limit fee recovery in disputes.
p_148.model_instructions: Add clarifying language at the end of Section 11.6.4: 'The foregoing allocation of legal costs is without prejudice to either party's right to recover attorneys' fees and costs as the prevailing party in any action or proceeding pursuant to Section 16.10 or any other provision of this Agreement.'

p_150.title: Unlimited Survival for Tax Adjustments
p_150.description: The proration provision for real estate taxes and assessments includes a surviving obligation for post-closing adjustments and refunds 'which obligation will survive the Closing' without any time limitation. This creates an open-ended liability for Seller to potentially owe Buyer money for tax-related adjustments that could arise years after Closing, with no cap on duration or amount.
p_150.problematic_text: including any adjustments to real estate taxes and assessments and refunds of any payments thereof that are made following the Closing but relate to periods of time prior to Closing, which obligation will survive the Closing
p_150.user_recommendation: Add time limit (e.g., 12-18 months) for tax adjustment survival.
p_150.model_instructions: Modify the surviving obligation language to include a time limitation. Replace 'which obligation will survive the Closing' with 'which obligation will survive the Closing for a period of eighteen (18) months following the Closing Date, after which neither party shall have any further obligation with respect thereto'. This aligns the tax proration survival with the general reconciliation period concepts while providing reasonable finality for Seller.

p_151.title: Buyer Credited Full Closing Day
p_151.description: The proration method deems Buyer to hold title and be entitled to income for the 'entire day upon which the Closing occurs.' This is inconsistent with Section 11.7.1 which prorates items 'as of 11:59 pm on the day immediately preceding the Closing Date.' This means Seller is charged through 11:59 pm the day before Closing, but Buyer is credited the entire Closing day - resulting in Seller losing one day of income attribution.
p_151.problematic_text: Buyer shall be deemed to hold title to the Property and be entitled to the income therefrom and responsible for the expenses thereof for the entire day upon which the Closing occurs
p_151.user_recommendation: Confirm proration cut-off is consistent between sections.
p_151.model_instructions: Review and harmonize the proration timing between Sections 11.7.1 and 11.7.2 to ensure consistency. Consider modifying to read: 'For purposes of calculating prorations, Buyer shall be deemed to hold title to the Property and be entitled to the income therefrom and responsible for the expenses thereof commencing at 12:00 a.m. on the Closing Date, consistent with the proration cut-off time set forth in Section 11.7.1.'

p_152.title: Conditional Utility Deposit Credit
p_152.description: Seller's credit for utility deposits is conditioned on the deposits being 'transferred to Buyer.' If utility companies do not transfer deposits (which is common - they often refund to the original depositor), Seller may not receive credit at Closing but must wait for a refund from the utility company, creating cash flow timing issues and administrative burden.
p_152.problematic_text: Seller shall be entitled to a credit at the Closing for any utility deposits which it or its predecessors have made prior to the Closing Date, to the extent the same are transferred to Buyer
p_152.user_recommendation: Guarantee Seller credit for all utility deposits regardless of transfer.
p_152.model_instructions: Modify the utility deposit credit provision to ensure Seller receives credit at Closing regardless of whether deposits are actually transferred. Replace the conditional language with: 'Seller shall be entitled to a credit at the Closing for any utility deposits which it or its predecessors have made prior to the Closing Date. To the extent such deposits are not transferred to Buyer and are instead refunded directly to Seller by the utility provider, Buyer shall have no claim to such refunds.'

p_152.title: 60-Day Post-Closing Proration Window
p_152.description: If utility accounts are not set up in Buyer's name on the Closing Date, charges are prorated 'within 60 days after the Closing Date.' This creates a 60-day window where Seller may need to continue paying utility bills and then seek reimbursement, with potential collection risk if Buyer disputes amounts.
p_152.problematic_text: If accounts are not set up in Buyer's name on the Closing Date, all charges for such utilities shall be prorated outside of escrow within 60 days after the Closing Date.
p_152.user_recommendation: Require escrow holdback or immediate reimbursement mechanism for utilities.
p_152.model_instructions: Strengthen the utility proration mechanism to protect Seller. Add the following at the end of the utility proration sentence: 'If accounts are not set up in Buyer's name on the Closing Date, all charges for such utilities shall be prorated outside of escrow within 60 days after the Closing Date, and Buyer shall reimburse Seller within ten (10) Business Days after Seller's delivery of applicable invoices. Buyer shall indemnify Seller for any utility charges accruing from and after the Closing Date that are billed to or paid by Seller.'

p_153.title: Unlimited Closing Extension for Statement Disputes
p_153.description: Either party may extend the Closing Date if they cannot agree on the Closing Statement, with the extension continuing until '2 Business Days after the date on which the parties reach agreement.' This provision has no outer limit, meaning a disagreement over prorations could indefinitely delay Closing, giving Buyer leverage to extend Closing or renegotiate terms under the guise of a Closing Statement dispute.
p_153.problematic_text: either party by written notice to the other party may elect to extend the Closing Date to such date that is 2 Business Days after the date on which the parties reach agreement upon the Closing Statement
p_153.user_recommendation: Cap extension period and add dispute resolution mechanism.
p_153.model_instructions: Add a limitation on the Closing Statement extension right to prevent indefinite delays. Modify to read: 'either party by written notice to the other party may elect to extend the Closing Date to such date that is 2 Business Days after the date on which the parties reach agreement upon the Closing Statement; provided, however, that (i) no such extension shall exceed ten (10) Business Days beyond the original Closing Date, and (ii) if the parties cannot agree on the Closing Statement within such period, the parties shall close based on the preliminary closing statement prepared by Escrow Agent, with final reconciliation to occur pursuant to Section 11.9.'

p_154.title: 90-Day Reconciliation Window
p_154.description: The 90-day post-closing reconciliation period allows Buyer to claim adjustments for proration errors for three months after Closing. While this is not unusual, it creates a window where Seller may owe additional funds to Buyer. The provision does not cap the amount of potential adjustments, and places the burden on Seller to maintain records and respond to adjustment requests.
p_154.problematic_text: provided, however, that any adjustment shall be made, if at all, within 90 days after the Closing Date
p_154.user_recommendation: Consider reducing to 60 days and adding de minimis threshold.
p_154.model_instructions: Modify the reconciliation provision to reduce Seller's exposure: 'provided, however, that any adjustment shall be made, if at all, within sixty (60) days after the Closing Date, and no adjustment shall be required if the net amount owed by one party to the other is less than Five Thousand Dollars ($5,000.00) in the aggregate.' This reduces the reconciliation window and adds a de minimis threshold to avoid disputes over minor amounts.

p_154.title: Open-Ended Records Access Obligation
p_154.description: Seller must afford Buyer and its 'representatives and auditors' reasonable access to Seller's books and records 'until final reconciliation.' Combined with the 90-day reconciliation period and potential for disputed items, this could require Seller to maintain and provide access to records for an extended period post-Closing, creating administrative burden.
p_154.problematic_text: Until final reconciliation under this Section, Buyer and its representatives and auditors shall be afforded reasonable access during normal business hours to Seller's books and records with respect to the Property to confirm the accuracy of the Closing Statement.
p_154.user_recommendation: Limit scope and duration of records access obligation.
p_154.model_instructions: Modify the records access provision to limit Seller's burden: 'Until final reconciliation under this Section (but in no event longer than ninety (90) days after the Closing Date), Buyer and its representatives and auditors shall be afforded reasonable access during normal business hours, upon at least five (5) Business Days' prior written notice, to Seller's books and records with respect to the Property solely to confirm the accuracy of the items set forth in the Closing Statement. Seller shall have no obligation to retain such records beyond one (1) year after the Closing Date.'

p_155.title: Escrow Agent Liability Limited to Gross Negligence
p_155.description: The escrow agent's liability is limited to 'willful misconduct or gross negligence,' which is a very high standard that effectively insulates the escrow agent from most claims of ordinary negligence. If the escrow agent makes errors in handling the earnest money deposit or closing funds that don't rise to the level of gross negligence, neither party (including Seller) would have meaningful recourse. While this is somewhat standard, it leaves Seller exposed if funds are mishandled.
p_155.problematic_text: Escrow Agent shall have no liability except for its own willful misconduct or gross negligence
p_155.user_recommendation: Consider adding liability for ordinary negligence in fund handling.
p_155.model_instructions: Modify the liability standard to include ordinary negligence for fund handling matters. Replace 'Escrow Agent shall have no liability except for its own willful misconduct or gross negligence' with 'Escrow Agent shall have no liability except for its own negligence, willful misconduct or gross negligence with respect to the handling, investment, or disbursement of escrowed funds.'

p_155.title: Escrow Agent Has Sole Discretion on Interpleader
p_155.description: The provision grants the escrow agent discretion to interplead disputed funds 'at its own discretion.' This means the escrow agent can file an interpleader action even when Seller believes it has a clear right to the earnest money deposit (e.g., in a Buyer default situation). Interpleader actions delay resolution, increase costs, and create uncertainty for Seller who may be entitled to liquidated damages.
p_155.problematic_text: Escrow Agent shall be entitled, at its own discretion, to deliver such amount to an appropriate court of law pending resolution of the dispute
p_155.user_recommendation: Require written demand and cure period before interpleader is permitted.
p_155.model_instructions: Add procedural requirements before interpleader can be initiated. Replace 'If a dispute arises between the parties with respect to the disposition of the Earnest Money Deposit or any other amounts held in escrow, Escrow Agent shall be entitled, at its own discretion, to deliver such amount to an appropriate court of law pending resolution of the dispute' with 'If a dispute arises between the parties with respect to the disposition of the Earnest Money Deposit or any other amounts held in escrow, Escrow Agent shall provide written notice to both parties of its intent to interplead such funds and shall not commence any interpleader action until at least fifteen (15) Business Days after delivery of such notice, during which time the parties may attempt to resolve the dispute or provide Escrow Agent with joint written instructions. If joint written instructions are received within such period, Escrow Agent shall disburse in accordance therewith. If no joint instructions are received, Escrow Agent may thereafter deliver such amount to an appropriate court of law pending resolution of the dispute.'

p_155.title: Investment Standard Lacks Specificity
p_155.description: The investment requirement states funds shall be invested in accounts 'reasonably satisfactory to Seller and Buyer,' which could create disputes about what investments are acceptable. Additionally, there is no requirement that interest earnings be allocated to a specific party or prorated at closing, potentially creating ambiguity.
p_155.problematic_text: Escrow Agent shall invest the amount in escrow in accounts which are federally insured, which invest solely in government securities, or which are reasonably satisfactory to Seller and Buyer
p_155.user_recommendation: Specify that interest follows the principal and clarify investment priority.
p_155.model_instructions: Add clarity regarding interest allocation and investment hierarchy. After 'and shall be applied in accordance with the terms of this Agreement' add: 'Any interest earned on escrowed funds shall be considered part of the escrowed funds and shall be disbursed to the party entitled to receive the principal amount. In the event of any dispute regarding acceptable investments, federally insured accounts or accounts investing solely in U.S. government securities shall be deemed acceptable without further approval.'

p_156.title: Supplementary Escrow Instructions May Create Obligations
p_156.description: While the provision states this Agreement controls over supplementary escrow instructions, Seller is still obligated to execute 'reasonable additional and supplementary escrow instructions.' The term 'reasonable' is subjective and could require Seller to execute documents that impose additional obligations or processes not contemplated in this Agreement, even if they don't technically 'conflict' with it.
p_156.problematic_text: Seller and Buyer agree to execute such reasonable additional and supplementary escrow instructions as may be appropriate to enable the Escrow Agent to comply with the terms of this Agreement
p_156.user_recommendation: Add that supplementary instructions shall not expand Seller's obligations.
p_156.model_instructions: Modify the sentence to limit the scope of supplementary instructions. Replace 'Seller and Buyer agree to execute such reasonable additional and supplementary escrow instructions as may be appropriate to enable the Escrow Agent to comply with the terms of this Agreement' with 'Seller and Buyer agree to execute such reasonable additional and supplementary escrow instructions as may be appropriate to enable the Escrow Agent to comply with the terms of this Agreement; provided that such supplementary escrow instructions shall not expand the obligations, liabilities, or duties of either party beyond those expressly set forth in this Agreement.'

p_158.title: No Fallback if Escrow Agent Refuses Reporting Role
p_158.description: If the Escrow Agent refuses to act as Reporting Person, the parties must 'agree to appoint another third party.' This creates potential for deadlock if the parties cannot agree on an alternative, and there is no mechanism to break such an impasse. Additionally, costs of such alternative reporting person are not allocated.
p_158.problematic_text: If Escrow Agent refuses to execute a counterpart of this Agreement pursuant to which it agrees to be the Reporting Person, Seller and Buyer shall agree to appoint another third party as the Reporting Person
p_158.user_recommendation: Add fallback mechanism and cost allocation for alternative Reporting Person.
p_158.model_instructions: Add a deadlock breaker and cost allocation provision. Replace 'If Escrow Agent refuses to execute a counterpart of this Agreement pursuant to which it agrees to be the Reporting Person, Seller and Buyer shall agree to appoint another third party as the Reporting Person' with 'If Escrow Agent refuses to execute a counterpart of this Agreement pursuant to which it agrees to be the Reporting Person, Seller and Buyer shall agree to appoint another third party as the Reporting Person within five (5) Business Days after notice of such refusal. If the parties are unable to agree on an alternative Reporting Person within such period, the Title Company shall serve as the Reporting Person. The costs of any third-party Reporting Person (other than Escrow Agent) shall be shared equally by Seller and Buyer.'

p_159.title: Four-Year Document Retention Obligation
p_159.description: Seller is required to retain this Agreement for not less than 4 years from the end of the calendar year in which Closing occurred and must produce it upon IRS request. While this is a standard tax compliance requirement, it creates a post-closing administrative obligation that Seller should be aware of. Failure to comply could result in IRS penalties.
p_159.problematic_text: retain this Agreement for not less than 4 years from the end of the calendar year in which the Closing occurred, and to produce it to the Internal Revenue Service upon a valid request therefor
p_159.user_recommendation: Ensure internal procedures exist for document retention compliance.
p_159.model_instructions: No modification recommended to contract language. This is a standard IRS compliance requirement under Section 6045(e). Flag for Seller's internal compliance team to ensure proper document retention procedures are in place.

p_161.title: Low Threshold for Minor Loss Classification
p_161.description: The $500,000 threshold for classifying damage as 'minor' (requiring Buyer to proceed) may be too low for a significant commercial property transaction. This means Buyer is obligated to close even with substantial damage up to $500,000, limiting Seller's exposure but potentially creating disputes about repair adequacy or property condition at closing.
p_161.problematic_text: the insured cost to repair any such damage or destruction, or the diminution in the value of the remaining Property as a result of a partial condemnation, equals $500,000 or less
p_161.user_recommendation: Consider increasing threshold to $750,000-$1,000,000 if appropriate for property value.
p_161.model_instructions: Consider whether the $500,000 threshold is appropriate relative to the Purchase Price. If the Purchase Price is substantial (e.g., $50M+), this threshold may be acceptable. However, if Seller wants more flexibility, consider increasing to a higher fixed amount or a percentage of Purchase Price (e.g., 'the lesser of $1,000,000 or 2% of the Purchase Price'). This protects Seller by ensuring Buyer must close despite more significant damage levels.

p_161.title: Seller Bears Repair Cost Deductions
p_161.description: The credit against Purchase Price includes insurance proceeds collected, plus deductibles not recoverable under Leases, less Seller's restoration expenses. While Seller can deduct repair costs, this structure may result in disputes over what constitutes reasonable repair expenditures, and Seller bears the risk of unrecoverable deductibles.
p_161.problematic_text: plus the amount of any insurance deductible not recoverable under the Leases, less any sums expended by Seller toward the restoration or repair of the Property
p_161.user_recommendation: Ensure insurance deductibles are recoverable under tenant leases where possible.
p_161.model_instructions: This provision is generally balanced. To strengthen Seller's position, consider adding language clarifying that Seller has sole discretion over repair decisions prior to Closing, and that all reasonable repair costs (including professional fees for assessing damage) are deductible. Also consider adding 'and any reasonable costs incurred in connection with assessing the damage or destruction' to the list of deductible expenses.

p_162.title: Buyer Termination Right for Major Loss
p_162.description: Buyer has the unilateral right to terminate the Agreement if damage exceeds $500,000 or is uninsured or impairs access. While this is market-standard, it creates transaction risk for Seller who may have taken the property off market and incurred costs. The 10 Business Day election period also delays certainty for Seller.
p_162.problematic_text: then Buyer may at its option, to be exercised by written notice to Seller within 10 Business Days after Seller's notice to Buyer of the occurrence of the damage or destruction or the commencement of condemnation proceedings, terminate this Agreement
p_162.user_recommendation: Consider shortening election period to 5 Business Days to reduce uncertainty.
p_162.model_instructions: To strengthen Seller's position, consider: (1) shortening the election period from 10 Business Days to 5 Business Days to reduce Seller's uncertainty period; (2) adding language that if Buyer fails to respond, Buyer is deemed to have elected to proceed (which is already included - confirm this is retained); (3) consider adding a Seller termination right if Buyer terminates under this section and the damage is subsequently found to be less than the threshold. Modify to read: 'within 5 Business Days after Seller's notice to Buyer'.

p_162.title: Seller Credit for Uninsured Loss
p_162.description: If Buyer elects to proceed after major loss, Seller must credit the 'amount of any uninsured loss' against the Purchase Price. This is a potentially unlimited exposure for Seller if insurance coverage is inadequate, the loss exceeds policy limits, or coverage is denied. Seller bears the full risk of insurance gaps.
p_162.problematic_text: there shall be a credit against the Purchase Price due hereunder equal to the amount of any uninsured loss
p_162.user_recommendation: Cap uninsured loss credit or require Buyer to terminate if loss exceeds insured amount.
p_162.model_instructions: This creates significant exposure for Seller. Consider modifying to cap Seller's exposure for uninsured losses. Options include: (1) 'the amount of any uninsured loss, not to exceed $[cap amount]'; (2) adding language that if uninsured loss exceeds a threshold, Seller may elect to terminate rather than provide unlimited credit; (3) requiring Buyer to accept assignment of any claims Seller may have against insurers in lieu of credit for disputed coverage. Alternative language: 'equal to the amount of any uninsured loss (provided that Seller's credit obligation for uninsured losses shall not exceed $_____), insurance proceeds or condemnation awards...'

p_164.title: Unlimited Damages for Intentional Default
p_164.description: While Seller's liability is generally capped at the Seller Breakage Fee, there is a carve-out for 'intentional or willful' defaults that allows Buyer to recover 'any and all damages.' This creates unlimited liability exposure for Seller, and the terms 'intentional' and 'willful' are subjective and could be broadly interpreted by courts.
p_164.problematic_text: plus to the extent the default or breach by Seller was intentional or willful, recover any and all damages arising out of such intentional or willful default
p_164.user_recommendation: Delete intentional/willful carve-out or cap damages even for intentional breach.
p_164.model_instructions: This carve-out significantly undermines the liquidated damages protection. To protect Seller, consider: (1) deleting this carve-out entirely so all pre-closing defaults are subject to the liquidated damages cap; (2) if deletion is not acceptable, narrow the carve-out to 'fraud' only rather than 'intentional or willful' breach; (3) alternatively, cap even intentional breach damages at a multiple of the Earnest Money Deposit (e.g., '2x the Earnest Money Deposit'). Recommended deletion: remove ', plus to the extent the default or breach by Seller was intentional or willful, recover any and all damages arising out of such intentional or willful default'.

p_164.title: Broad Categories of Recoverable Breakage Costs
p_164.description: The Seller Breakage Fee includes very broad damage categories such as 'costs of foregoing other business opportunities' which are inherently speculative and difficult to verify. While capped at the Earnest Money Deposit amount, this language invites disputes and claims for consequential damages that are typically excluded in commercial transactions.
p_164.problematic_text: costs incurred in connection with this Agreement, including Due Diligence costs, costs, losses and damages incurred to obtain financing, costs incurred pursuing joint ventures, costs of foregoing other business opportunities, and attorneys' fees
p_164.user_recommendation: Narrow recoverable costs to documented out-of-pocket expenses only.
p_164.model_instructions: The broad language describing components of the Seller Breakage Fee creates litigation risk even though the total is capped. Consider narrowing to objectively verifiable costs: 'an amount to compensate Buyer for its reasonable, documented out-of-pocket costs actually incurred in connection with this Agreement, including third-party Due Diligence costs, loan application fees, and reasonable attorneys' fees, in an aggregate amount not to exceed the Earnest Money Deposit.' Delete references to 'costs of foregoing other business opportunities' and 'costs incurred pursuing joint ventures' as these are speculative and consequential in nature.

p_164.title: Short Cure Period for Seller Default
p_164.description: Seller only has 5 Business Days to cure a default before Buyer can exercise remedies. For complex commercial transactions, some defaults (such as title issues or third-party consents) may require more time to cure. This short period may be insufficient for Seller to remedy curable issues.
p_164.problematic_text: which is not cured within 5 Business Days after notice from Buyer
p_164.user_recommendation: Extend cure period to 10-15 Business Days for non-monetary defaults.
p_164.model_instructions: Consider extending the cure period, particularly for non-monetary defaults that may take longer to remedy. Suggested revision: 'which is not cured within 5 Business Days after notice from Buyer (or 15 Business Days for non-monetary defaults that cannot reasonably be cured within 5 Business Days, provided Seller has commenced cure efforts within the initial 5 Business Day period and is diligently pursuing such cure)'. This provides Seller reasonable time to cure while maintaining Buyer's protections.

p_164.title: Unlimited Post-Closing Liability Preserved
p_164.description: The final sentence explicitly preserves all of Buyer's rights and remedies for breaches discovered after Closing, without any cap or limitation. This undermines the negotiated limitations in Section 5.4 and could expose Seller to unlimited post-closing claims.
p_164.problematic_text: The foregoing in no way limits Buyer's rights and remedies if Buyer first discovers after Closing a breach or default by Seller under this Agreement.
p_164.user_recommendation: Delete this sentence or cross-reference Section 5.4 survival and cap limitations.
p_164.model_instructions: This sentence creates ambiguity about whether the carefully negotiated limitations in Section 5.4 (survival periods and liability caps) apply to post-closing claims. Modify to read: 'The foregoing in no way limits Buyer's rights and remedies under Section 5.4 if Buyer first discovers after Closing a breach of Seller's representations and warranties, subject to the limitations, survival periods, and caps set forth in Section 5.4.' This ensures the negotiated protections in Section 5.4 are not undermined by this general statement.

p_165.title: Asymmetric Default Remedies Favor Buyer
p_165.description: Comparing Sections 13.1 and 13.2, there is a significant asymmetry: Buyer gets specific performance OR liquidated damages plus a Breakage Fee (up to 2x Earnest Money) plus unlimited damages for willful breach, while Seller is limited to retaining only the Earnest Money Deposit with no right to specific performance or consequential damages. This asymmetry favors Buyer.
p_165.problematic_text: then Seller shall be entitled, as its sole remedy, to retain the Earnest Money Deposit as liquidated damages
p_165.user_recommendation: Consider adding Seller specific performance right or increasing liquidated damages amount.
p_165.model_instructions: The remedy structure strongly favors Buyer. To rebalance, consider: (1) adding a Seller right to specific performance: 'Seller shall be entitled, as its sole remedy, to either (a) enforce specific performance of this Agreement, or (b) retain the Earnest Money Deposit as liquidated damages'; (2) alternatively, increase Seller's liquidated damages amount to include a breakage fee similar to Buyer's remedy; (3) add a carve-out for Buyer's intentional breach similar to Section 13.1. Suggested revision to add specific performance right for parity with Buyer's remedies.

p_165.title: Seller Waives Specific Performance and Damages
p_165.description: Seller explicitly waives all rights to seek specific performance or damages beyond the Earnest Money Deposit. While this provides certainty, it may leave Seller without adequate remedy if Buyer defaults on a property that has declined in value or is difficult to re-market.
p_165.problematic_text: SELLER WAIVES ITS RIGHT TO RECOVER DAMAGES OR SEEK SPECIFIC PERFORMANCE AGAINST BUYER
p_165.user_recommendation: Consider retaining specific performance right as alternative remedy.
p_165.model_instructions: This waiver is significant and may not be in Seller's best interest in all market conditions. If the property value declines between contract and closing, Seller's damages could exceed the Earnest Money Deposit. Consider revising to: 'SELLER WAIVES ITS RIGHT TO RECOVER DAMAGES AGAINST BUYER, PROVIDED HOWEVER THAT SELLER SHALL RETAIN THE RIGHT TO SEEK SPECIFIC PERFORMANCE IF SELLER ELECTS TO DO SO BY WRITTEN NOTICE TO BUYER WITHIN 30 DAYS AFTER BUYER'S DEFAULT.' Alternatively, if waiver is retained, ensure the Earnest Money Deposit amount is substantial enough to adequately compensate Seller.

p_167.title: Mutual Confidentiality May Limit Seller Marketing
p_167.description: The broad definition of Confidential Information includes 'the existence or pendency of this transaction' and 'material economic terms.' While mutual, this could limit Seller's ability to market the property to backup buyers or discuss the failed transaction with future prospects if the deal terminates.
p_167.problematic_text: (b) the existence or pendency of this transaction, (c) the material economic terms of this transaction
p_167.user_recommendation: Add carve-out allowing Seller to discuss with backup buyers if transaction terminates.
p_167.model_instructions: Consider adding a Seller-specific carve-out for post-termination marketing. Add at the end of the exceptions: '(aa) following any termination of this Agreement, Seller may disclose to prospective purchasers that a prior transaction did not close and may share the material economic terms of this Agreement to the extent reasonably necessary in connection with marketing the Property for sale, provided Seller shall not disclose Buyer's identity without Buyer's consent.' This preserves Seller's ability to efficiently re-market the property.

p_167.title: Subjective Confidentiality Standard
p_167.description: The catch-all provision includes information 'that...would otherwise be reasonably considered to be confidential.' This subjective standard could lead to disputes about what information is covered, potentially exposing Seller to claims of breach for disclosures Seller considered appropriate.
p_167.problematic_text: that either a party or its agents has expressly designated as confidential or would otherwise be reasonably considered to be confidential
p_167.user_recommendation: Limit to expressly designated information or provide clearer objective criteria.
p_167.model_instructions: The 'reasonably considered to be confidential' standard is subjective and could create disputes. Consider narrowing to: 'that either a party or its agents has expressly designated as confidential in writing at the time of disclosure.' Alternatively, if the broader standard is retained, add clarifying language: 'For the avoidance of doubt, general market information about property values, capitalization rates, and comparable transactions shall not be considered Confidential Information.'

p_168.title: Subjective confidentiality standard
p_168.description: The confidentiality obligation is tied to 'the same degree of care and confidentiality that such party exercises in protecting and preserving its own confidential information.' This subjective standard means if Buyer has lax internal practices for protecting its own information, it could argue it met the contractual standard despite inadequate protection of Seller's Confidential Information. A more objective standard (e.g., 'commercially reasonable care' or 'reasonable care under the circumstances') would provide better protection.
p_168.problematic_text: the same degree of care and confidentiality that such party exercises in protecting and preserving its own confidential information
p_168.model_instructions: Replace 'the same degree of care and confidentiality that such party exercises in protecting and preserving its own confidential information' with 'at least the same degree of care as it uses to protect its own confidential information, but in no event less than commercially reasonable care'. This establishes both a subjective and objective floor for the confidentiality standard.

p_168.title: Broad Permitted Recipients disclosure exception
p_168.description: The definition of Permitted Recipients is expansive, including 'existing or potential investors, joint venture partners or lenders' and their respective 'officers, employees, attorneys, advisors, consultants or Affiliates.' This creates a very wide circle of potential disclosure with minimal accountability. The only requirement is making recipients 'aware' of confidentiality and having them 'acknowledge their responsibility'—there is no requirement for written confidentiality agreements or that Buyer be liable for breaches by these recipients.
p_168.problematic_text: each party may disclose the Confidential Information to existing or potential investors, joint venture partners or lenders, as well as to the officers, employees, attorneys, advisors, consultants or Affiliates of Seller or Buyer, as the case may be, or of any of the foregoing parties (collectively, "Permitted Recipients"); provided that the disclosing party first makes those Permitted Recipients aware of the confidential nature of the Confidential Information and such Permitted Recipients acknowledge their responsibility to preserve the confidentiality of the Confidential Information
p_168.user_recommendation: Require written confidentiality agreements and hold disclosing party liable for breaches.
p_168.model_instructions: Modify the Permitted Recipients proviso to read: 'provided that (i) the disclosing party first obtains from each such Permitted Recipient a written agreement to maintain the confidentiality of the Confidential Information on terms no less restrictive than those set forth herein, and (ii) the disclosing party shall be responsible for any breach of this Section 14.2 by any such Permitted Recipient as if such breach were committed by the disclosing party itself.'

p_168.title: No specified survival period for confidentiality
p_168.description: The confidentiality provision does not specify how long the obligations survive after closing or termination of the Agreement. This ambiguity could allow Buyer to argue confidentiality obligations terminate at closing, potentially exposing sensitive Seller information post-transaction.
p_168.problematic_text: Each party shall treat the Confidential Information with the same degree of care and confidentiality
p_168.user_recommendation: Add explicit survival period (e.g., 2-3 years post-closing or termination).
p_168.model_instructions: Add a new sentence at the end of Section 14.2: 'The obligations of confidentiality set forth in this Section 14 shall survive the Closing or any earlier termination of this Agreement for a period of two (2) years.'

p_170.title: Uncapped broker indemnification obligation
p_170.description: Seller's indemnification obligation to Buyer for broker claims arising from Seller's contacts is uncapped and unlimited. While this is mutual, the indemnification exposure is open-ended. This is somewhat mitigated by the fact that Seller controls its own broker relationships, but surprise claims from third-party finders could arise.
p_170.problematic_text: then Seller shall defend Buyer from such claim, and shall indemnify Buyer and hold Buyer harmless from any and all costs, damages, claims, liabilities or expenses (including reasonable attorneys' fees and disbursements) incurred by Buyer with respect to the claim
p_170.user_recommendation: Consider adding a cap or ensuring comprehensive broker disclosure.
p_170.model_instructions: This is a mutual provision and market-standard in structure. If Seller wants to limit exposure, add after 'with respect to the claim': '; provided, however, that Seller's aggregate liability under this indemnification shall not exceed the Purchase Price.' Alternatively, ensure Section 1.15 and related broker disclosures are comprehensive to minimize undisclosed broker risk.

p_170.title: No explicit survival for broker indemnity
p_170.description: The broker indemnification obligations do not specify a survival period. While indemnification provisions typically survive closing by implication, the lack of explicit survival language creates ambiguity about how long Seller remains exposed to claims arising from Buyer's broker contacts that surface post-closing.
p_170.problematic_text: If any person brings a claim against Seller for a commission or finder's fee based upon any contact, dealings or communication with Buyer
p_170.user_recommendation: Add explicit survival period consistent with statute of limitations.
p_170.model_instructions: Add at the end of the paragraph: 'The indemnification obligations set forth in this Section 15 shall survive the Closing for a period of two (2) years, or if longer, until the expiration of the applicable statute of limitations for such claims.'

p_172.title: Notice provision incomplete without addresses
p_172.description: The notice provision references addresses to follow but without the complete information, it's impossible to assess whether proper notice addresses are established for Seller. Proper notice provisions are critical for receiving timely communication of claims, defaults, and other material matters.
p_172.problematic_text: shall be delivered to the parties at the following addresses
p_172.user_recommendation: Ensure Seller's complete notice address information is included.
p_172.model_instructions: Verify that complete notice information for Seller is provided in the subsequent paragraphs, including physical address, attention line, and email address. Consider adding backup notice recipients (e.g., counsel) to ensure Seller receives all critical communications.

p_174.title: Blank party identification
p_174.description: The party name field is blank, shown only as underscores. While this may simply be a template placeholder, Seller should ensure proper legal entity name is inserted to avoid any ambiguity about the contracting party.
p_174.user_recommendation: Insert Seller's complete legal entity name.
p_174.model_instructions: Replace '_________________________' with Seller's complete legal entity name as it appears in the preamble and signature blocks of the Agreement.

p_175.title: Blank attention and email fields
p_175.description: The attention line and email address fields are blank. Proper completion is essential to ensure notices reach the appropriate person at Seller and that email notice (if permitted) is properly directed.
p_175.user_recommendation: Insert appropriate contact name and email address.
p_175.model_instructions: Replace 'Attn:	_______________' with the appropriate contact person's name and title, and replace 'Email:  _______________' with the appropriate email address for receiving contractual notices. Consider using a general department email (e.g., legal@company.com) rather than individual email to ensure continuity.

p_180.title: Blank Notice Information for Counterparty
p_180.description: The notice provision contains blank fields for the Buyer's contact information (Attn: _____________________). While this appears to be a template placeholder, if this is not properly completed before execution, Seller may face difficulties providing valid notice to Buyer. Invalid or incomplete notice addresses could lead to disputes about whether notices were properly delivered, potentially affecting Seller's ability to enforce deadlines, exercise rights, or trigger default provisions.
p_180.user_recommendation: Ensure all blank notice fields are completed prior to execution.
p_180.model_instructions: This is a placeholder that must be completed with the Buyer's specific contact person name before execution. Flag this for completion during contract finalization. Do not execute the Agreement until this field contains a specific named individual or position title.

p_209.title: Change of Address Requires Actual Receipt
p_209.description: The provision states that no change of address notice is effective until 'actual receipt.' This creates a potential issue where if Buyer changes their address but Seller's notice of change is delayed or lost, Seller might continue sending notices to an old address in good faith, only to have those notices deemed ineffective. This asymmetric risk could affect Seller's ability to provide timely notices if Buyer claims non-receipt of an address change notification.
p_209.problematic_text: no notice of a change of address shall be effective until actual receipt of such notice
p_209.user_recommendation: Consider adding deemed receipt provisions for address change notices.
p_209.model_instructions: Consider modifying to provide that address change notices shall be effective upon deemed delivery using the same delivery methods specified in Section 16.1 (certified mail, overnight courier, or email), rather than requiring 'actual receipt.' Alternative language: 'provided that any notice of a change of address shall be effective upon delivery in accordance with the notice provisions of this Section 16.1.'

p_210.title: Email Notice Deemed Immediate Upon Transmission
p_210.description: Email notices are deemed delivered upon transmission without requiring any confirmation of receipt, read receipt, or acknowledgment. This is generally favorable to Seller as it provides a quick and efficient notice method. However, Seller should be aware that Buyer can also use this method, meaning Buyer could send last-minute notices (such as termination notices during due diligence) at 4:59 PM Pacific Time on a deadline date and have them deemed effective.
p_210.problematic_text: email transmission, in which case notice shall be deemed delivered upon transmission if the transmission is made on a Business Day on or before 5:00 p.m. Pacific Time
p_210.user_recommendation: Acceptable provision; monitor email for time-sensitive Buyer notices.
p_210.model_instructions: This provision is market-standard and generally acceptable. No revision required, but Seller should ensure robust email monitoring procedures are in place, particularly around deadline dates such as the Due Diligence Deadline, Title Objection Date, and Estoppel Deadline, as Buyer can provide effective notice up until 5:00 PM Pacific Time on such dates.

p_211.title: Blanket Time is of Essence Provision
p_211.description: The 'time is of the essence' provision applies universally to 'all obligations under this Agreement.' While this is standard language that benefits both parties, it means Seller must strictly comply with all deadlines including the Due Diligence Items Delivery Date, Title Commitment Delivery Date, Estoppel Deadline, and various closing deliverables. Any delay by Seller, even minor, could be treated as a material breach. This cuts both ways but requires Seller to carefully track all deadlines.
p_211.problematic_text: Time is of the essence in the performance of all obligations under this Agreement.
p_211.user_recommendation: Ensure calendar tracking of all Seller deadlines; consider cure period.
p_211.model_instructions: This is a standard provision. However, to protect Seller, consider whether any specific Seller obligations should have explicit cure periods or should be carved out from the strict time-is-of-essence standard. Review Sections 3.3 (Due Diligence Materials delivery), 4.1 (Title Commitment), 7.1 (Estoppel delivery), and 11.4 (Closing deliverables) to ensure Seller can meet all deadlines. Consider adding language such as: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, Seller shall have a 2 Business Day cure period for any administrative or ministerial delivery obligations.'

p_213.title: Broad Affiliate Definition Favors Buyer
p_213.description: The definition of 'Affiliate' is specifically tailored to Buyer's corporate structure (Unico Investment Group LLC) and includes entities where Unico holds as little as 2.5-5% of membership or partnership interests. This extremely low ownership threshold means Buyer could assign the Agreement to entities where Buyer has minimal economic interest or control, potentially allowing assignment to parties Seller would not have approved. Combined with Section 16.6's permitted assignment to Affiliates without Seller consent, this creates significant transfer risk.
p_213.problematic_text: any limited liability company or partnership in which Unico Investment Group LLC either (i) directly or indirectly serves as a manager[, operating as managing member] or general partner, and/or (ii) directly or indirectly holds at least [2.5]5% of the total membership or partnership interests shall constitute an Affiliate of Buyer
p_213.user_recommendation: Increase minimum ownership threshold to 50% or require majority control.
p_213.model_instructions: Revise the Affiliate definition to require a minimum 50% direct or indirect ownership interest for the ownership-based prong. Delete the bracketed '[2.5]' option and replace '5%' with '50%'. Consider also requiring that Unico maintain actual management authority, not merely serve as a manager in name. Suggested revision: 'directly or indirectly holds at least 50% of the total membership or partnership interests and exercises actual management control shall constitute an Affiliate of Buyer.'

p_215.title: Buyer Can Assign Without Seller Consent
p_215.description: While Seller has general consent rights over assignment, the carve-out allowing Buyer to assign without consent to Affiliates and to third parties under a TIC structure significantly undermines Seller's control. Given the broad Affiliate definition (entities with as low as 2.5-5% ownership), Buyer could effectively assign to entities with minimal connection to the original Buyer. The TIC structure provision (subsection b) allows assignment to non-Affiliates ('third parties') as long as an Affiliate manages the property, which provides almost no protection regarding the financial wherewithal of the actual purchasers.
p_215.problematic_text: Buyer may, without consent from Seller, partially or wholly assign this Agreement to (a) one or more Affiliates of Buyer, and (b) one or more Affiliates of Buyer and/or third parties under a tenancy in common structure, provided an Affiliate of Buyer will be the property manager of the Property
p_215.user_recommendation: Require Seller consent for TIC assignments or require creditworthy co-tenants.
p_215.model_instructions: Revise subsection (b) to either: (1) delete the TIC carve-out entirely and require Seller consent for any TIC structure, or (2) add financial qualification requirements for any third-party TIC co-tenants, such as: 'provided that (i) each third-party tenant in common shall have a net worth of at least $[X] million and liquid assets of at least $[Y] million, evidenced by financial statements delivered to Seller at least 10 Business Days prior to Closing, (ii) the TIC agreement shall be in form reasonably acceptable to Seller, and (iii) such third parties shall assume joint and several liability under this Agreement.' Also consider adding: 'Buyer's Affiliate assignees shall have net worth reasonably satisfactory to Seller.'

p_215.title: Minimal Assignment Notice Period
p_215.description: Seller receives only 2 Business Days' notice before Closing of a proposed assignment to Buyer's Affiliate. This extremely short timeframe provides Seller virtually no opportunity to review the assignee's qualifications, verify Affiliate status, or raise objections before the transaction closes. Seller could find itself conveying the Property to an unknown entity with minimal advance notice.
p_215.problematic_text: Notice of any proposed assignment to Buyer's Affiliate, which notice shall include the full legal name and signature block for the proposed assignee, must be given to Seller at least 2 Business Days before Closing.
p_215.user_recommendation: Extend notice period to at least 10 Business Days before Closing.
p_215.model_instructions: Replace '2 Business Days' with '10 Business Days' and expand the required notice contents to include: 'full legal name, signature block, organizational documents evidencing Affiliate status, evidence of good standing, and such financial information as Seller may reasonably request to verify the assignee's ability to perform under this Agreement.' Add: 'Seller shall have 5 Business Days to confirm assignee's Affiliate status and may object to any assignment that does not comply with Section 16.6, in which case the assignment shall be void.'

p_215.title: Buyer Remains Liable After Assignment
p_215.description: The provision states that no assignment releases Buyer from liability. While this is protective of Seller, Seller should verify this protection is meaningful by confirming Buyer has sufficient creditworthiness to stand behind its obligations post-Closing, particularly representations and warranties that survive Closing.
p_215.problematic_text: No assignment by Buyer shall release it from any liability hereunder.
p_215.user_recommendation: Confirm Buyer's creditworthiness; consider requiring guaranty.
p_215.model_instructions: This provision is favorable to Seller. Consider strengthening by adding: 'Additionally, any assignee shall execute an assumption agreement in form reasonably acceptable to Seller assuming all of Buyer's obligations under this Agreement, and Buyer shall remain jointly and severally liable with any assignee for all obligations arising under this Agreement.' If Buyer is a single-purpose entity, consider requiring a creditworthy guarantor for post-Closing obligations.

p_216.title: Undefined 1031 Exchange Cooperation Scope
p_216.description: While the provision includes good protections (no additional liability, no financial obligations, no date changes for Seller), the scope of required 'cooperation' is undefined. Seller should ensure this cannot be interpreted to require Seller to take on any exchange-related documentation obligations, hold funds, or deal with exchange intermediaries in ways that create administrative burden or risk.
p_216.problematic_text: Each party agrees to cooperate with the other in effecting such an exchange
p_216.user_recommendation: Define cooperation scope; limit to executing reasonably required documents.
p_216.model_instructions: Add clarifying language after 'effecting such an exchange': 'Such cooperation shall be limited to (i) executing such documents and instruments as may be reasonably required to effect the exchange, provided such documents do not alter the economic terms of this Agreement or impose any additional liability on the cooperating party, and (ii) consenting to the assignment of this Agreement to a qualified intermediary. The cooperating party shall not be required to (a) take title to any property other than as contemplated by this Agreement, (b) hold or receive exchange funds, (c) incur any out-of-pocket expense (unless reimbursed by the exchanging party), or (d) execute any indemnity or assumption of liability in connection with the exchange.'

p_217.title: Venue Limited to Property Location
p_217.description: Venue is limited to courts where the Property is located. If Seller is based in a different state, this could increase litigation costs if disputes arise. However, this is generally market-standard for real estate transactions and may be acceptable depending on Seller's location.
p_217.problematic_text: Venue for any action arising out of this Agreement shall be in the state courts in the state and county in which the Property is located, or in U.S. Federal District Court for the applicable district in which the Property is located.
p_217.user_recommendation: Acceptable if Seller has presence in Property jurisdiction; otherwise negotiate.
p_217.model_instructions: If Seller is located in a different jurisdiction and would prefer alternative venue options, revise to: 'Venue for any action arising out of this Agreement shall be, at the election of the party initiating such action, in (i) the state courts in the state and county in which the Property is located, (ii) U.S. Federal District Court for the applicable district in which the Property is located, or (iii) the state or federal courts located in [Seller's preferred jurisdiction].' Alternatively, if current language is acceptable, no change needed.

p_219.title: Undefined 'Prevailing Party' Standard
p_219.description: The attorneys' fees provision awards fees to the 'prevailing party' but does not define what constitutes 'prevailing.' In complex litigation where each party may win on some issues and lose on others, this ambiguity can lead to satellite litigation over fee entitlement. Without a clear definition (e.g., party recovering net monetary judgment, or party achieving primary objective), both parties may claim prevailing party status, potentially resulting in neither recovering fees or additional litigation costs to resolve the issue.
p_219.problematic_text: the prevailing party will be entitled to reasonable attorneys' fees
p_219.user_recommendation: Define 'prevailing party' or specify criteria for determination.
p_219.model_instructions: Revise to add a definition of 'prevailing party.' Consider language such as: 'For purposes of this Section, the "prevailing party" shall mean the party who obtains a final, non-appealable judgment substantially in its favor on the principal claims in dispute, as determined by the court in its discretion. If each party prevails on some claims, the court shall determine which party prevailed on the more substantial portion of the dispute and shall award fees proportionately.'

p_219.title: Unlimited Attorney Fee Recovery
p_219.description: The provision allows for recovery of 'reasonable attorneys' fees and costs' without any cap or limitation. While fee-shifting provisions are standard and this is mutual, Seller should be aware that if Buyer prevails in any enforcement action, Seller could face substantial fee exposure in addition to any damages, particularly in complex disputes involving multiple issues or appeals.
p_219.problematic_text: reasonable attorneys' fees and costs incurred in connection with such action prior to and at trial and on any appeal therefrom
p_219.user_recommendation: Consider whether fee recovery should be capped or limited.
p_219.model_instructions: This is informational for client awareness. If Seller desires to limit exposure, consider adding: 'provided, however, that the total attorneys' fees recoverable by any party shall not exceed [$ amount or percentage of Purchase Price].' However, note that this would also limit Seller's recovery, so this may not be advisable depending on client's risk tolerance and negotiating posture.

p_221.title: No Minimum Net Worth or Capital Requirement
p_221.description: The limited liability provision correctly shields individual members and managers of both parties from personal liability. However, it states that all parties 'shall look solely to the assets of Seller for the payment of any claim' without requiring Buyer to maintain any minimum net worth or capital to satisfy its obligations. If Buyer is a thinly-capitalized SPE (common in real estate transactions), Seller's remedies for Buyer default beyond the Earnest Money Deposit may be illusory. While Seller's remedy is already limited to liquidated damages under Section 13.2, any claims outside that provision could be unrecoverable.
p_221.problematic_text: all parties hereto shall look solely to the assets of Seller for the payment of any claim or the performance of any obligation by Seller
p_221.user_recommendation: Consider requiring Buyer guaranty or proof of adequate capitalization.
p_221.model_instructions: Consider negotiating for one or more of the following protections: (1) Add a representation from Buyer that it has adequate capital or assets to satisfy its obligations under this Agreement; (2) Require a guaranty from Buyer's parent entity or principals for Buyer's obligations; (3) Add language: 'Buyer represents that it has, and shall maintain through Closing, sufficient net assets to satisfy its obligations hereunder beyond the Earnest Money Deposit.' The appropriate level of protection depends on Buyer's creditworthiness and the transaction economics.

p_221.title: Mutual Liability Shield is Appropriate
p_221.description: The limited liability provision protects both Seller's and Buyer's individual members, managers, shareholders, officers, directors, partners, employees and agents from personal liability. This mutual structure is appropriate and market-standard for entity-to-entity transactions. This is informational only to confirm the provision is balanced.
p_221.problematic_text: Neither the members, managers, employees or agents of Seller, nor the shareholders, officers, directors, employees or agents of any of them, shall be liable under this Agreement
p_221.user_recommendation: No change needed - mutual protection is appropriate.
