p_221.model_instructions: No changes recommended. This provision appropriately provides mutual protection to the principals of both parties, which is standard in commercial real estate transactions where both Buyer and Seller are typically special purpose entities.

p_225.title: Supersedes Prior Confidentiality Agreements
p_225.description: The entire agreement clause explicitly supersedes 'non-disclosure or confidentiality agreements' previously executed between the parties. If Seller had more protective confidentiality terms in a prior NDA (such as longer survival periods, broader definitions of confidential information, or stricter use restrictions), those protections are now replaced by Section 14's confidentiality provisions, which may be less favorable to Seller. Additionally, if the prior NDA contained provisions beneficial to Seller that are not replicated in this Agreement (such as non-solicitation of employees or return/destruction of materials), those protections are lost.
p_225.problematic_text: including, without limitation, any previously executed letters of intent, early access agreements and/or non-disclosure or confidentiality agreements
p_225.user_recommendation: Review prior NDA terms and preserve beneficial provisions.
p_225.model_instructions: Add carve-out language to preserve specific protections from prior agreements that benefit Seller. Consider adding: 'provided, however, that the confidentiality and non-disclosure obligations of any prior confidentiality agreement shall survive to the extent such obligations are more protective of the disclosing party's Confidential Information than Section 14 hereof.' Alternatively, if there are specific provisions from the prior NDA that Seller wishes to preserve (such as non-solicitation, return of materials, or injunctive relief provisions), incorporate those provisions directly into Section 14 of this Agreement.

p_225.title: Supersedes Prior Early Access Agreements
p_225.description: The entire agreement clause supersedes prior early access agreements. Seller should verify that all indemnification obligations, insurance requirements, and restoration obligations that Buyer may have incurred under any prior early access agreement are either (a) fully satisfied before this Agreement's effective date, or (b) expressly preserved and incorporated into this Agreement. Section 3.4.6 references prior early access agreements but should be reviewed to ensure alignment.
p_225.user_recommendation: Confirm prior early access obligations are satisfied or preserved.
p_225.model_instructions: Review Section 3.4.6 to ensure it adequately preserves any outstanding obligations from prior early access agreements. Consider adding language such as: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, any indemnification obligations, insurance requirements, or restoration obligations of Buyer arising from activities conducted under any prior early access agreement shall survive and remain in full force and effect.' Coordinate with p_42 (Section 3.4.6) to ensure consistent treatment.

p_227.title: Survival Subject to Section 5.4 Limitations
p_227.description: The no-merger provision is expressly made 'subject to the limitations set forth in Section 5.4,' which contains significant limitations on Seller's representations and warranties including: (1) a survival period that likely expires relatively quickly post-closing, (2) potential deductible/basket requirements, and (3) potential caps on liability. By making the entire no-merger provision subject to Section 5.4, this language reinforces that Seller's exposure on representations is strictly limited. While this benefits Seller, you should verify Section 5.4 contains all intended protections.
p_227.problematic_text: Subject to the limitations set forth in Section 5.4 and Section 14
p_227.user_recommendation: Verify Section 5.4 contains all intended survival limitations.
p_227.model_instructions: This provision is favorable to Seller as drafted because it reinforces the limitations in Section 5.4. Review Section 5.4 (p_78) to ensure it contains: (1) a survival period of 9-12 months maximum for general representations, (2) a meaningful deductible/basket before Buyer can make claims, (3) a cap on Seller's liability (typically 1-3% of purchase price for general reps), and (4) exclusions for consequential, punitive, and speculative damages. If Section 5.4 does not contain these protections, consider adding them. The cross-reference to Section 14 regarding confidentiality survival should also be verified.

p_226.title: Standard Severability - Potential Reformation
p_226.description: The severability clause is standard but permits courts to sever invalid provisions while keeping the remainder of the Agreement in effect. In rare cases, this could result in the removal of provisions favorable to Seller (such as liability caps, damage limitations, or exculpatory clauses) if a court deems them unenforceable, while keeping Buyer-favorable provisions intact. This is a standard risk in most commercial contracts.
p_226.problematic_text: Any term or provision of this Agreement that is invalid or unenforceable in any jurisdiction will, as to such jurisdiction, be ineffective to the extent of such invalidity or unenforceability without rendering invalid or unenforceable the remaining terms and provisions
p_226.user_recommendation: Consider adding reformation language to preserve intent.
p_226.model_instructions: Consider adding protective language such as: 'If any provision of this Agreement is held to be invalid, illegal, or unenforceable, such provision shall be reformed and construed so that it is valid, legal, and enforceable to the maximum extent possible consistent with the original intent of the parties. In no event shall the invalidity or unenforceability of any limitation on liability, damage cap, or exculpatory provision be deemed to increase Seller's liability beyond what would have existed had such provision been valid and enforceable.'

p_229.title: Unlimited Further Acts Obligation
p_229.description: This provision requires Seller to execute additional documents and perform additional acts 'as may be reasonably required' to accomplish the purposes of the Agreement. While qualified by 'reasonably,' this creates an open-ended post-closing obligation that could require Seller to take actions beyond what was contemplated at execution. The lack of any time limitation or scope restriction could expose Seller to indefinite requests for cooperation, potentially requiring execution of documents or taking actions that could have unintended consequences.
p_229.problematic_text: shall execute, acknowledge or have notarized (if appropriate) and deliver in a timely manner such additional documents, and do such other additional acts, also in a timely manner, as may be reasonably required
p_229.user_recommendation: Add time limit, cost cap, and scope limitations on further acts obligation.
p_229.model_instructions: Revise Section 16.20 to include protective limitations for Seller: (1) add a time limitation such as 'for a period of 90 days following Closing'; (2) add language that Seller's obligations shall be 'at no cost or liability to Seller' or that Buyer shall reimburse Seller's reasonable costs; (3) clarify that such additional documents shall not 'expand Seller's obligations, liabilities, or representations beyond those expressly set forth in this Agreement'; and (4) add that any such requests must be related to 'ministerial or administrative matters' necessary to effectuate the Closing.

p_229.title: Undefined 'Timely Manner' Standard
p_229.description: The phrase 'in a timely manner' appears twice but is not defined, creating ambiguity about when Seller must perform these additional acts. This vague standard could lead to disputes about whether Seller has complied with its obligations and potentially expose Seller to claims of breach for failing to act quickly enough under Buyer's interpretation.
p_229.user_recommendation: Define 'timely manner' with specific timeframe (e.g., 10 Business Days).
p_229.model_instructions: Replace both instances of 'in a timely manner' with a specific timeframe such as 'within ten (10) Business Days after written request' to provide certainty and prevent disputes over timing compliance.

p_231.title: Binding Without All Party Signatures
p_231.description: The language 'whether or not all parties execute each counterpart' could create ambiguity about when the Agreement becomes binding. While standard counterpart language, combined with the electronic signature provision, this could theoretically allow a party to claim the Agreement is binding even if signature pages are incomplete or if there are questions about which version was signed.
p_231.problematic_text: whether or not all parties execute each counterpart
p_231.user_recommendation: Consider clarifying that both parties must sign for Agreement to be binding.
p_231.model_instructions: For clarity, consider adding after 'whether or not all parties execute each counterpart' the following clarifying language: '; provided, however, that this Agreement shall not be binding unless and until executed by both Buyer and Seller.' This reinforces the protection in Section 16.21 and eliminates any ambiguity.

p_23.original: 2.2	AS-IS, WHERE-IS.  THE TRANSACTION CONTEMPLATED BY THIS AGREEMENT HAS BEEN NEGOTIATED BETWEEN SELLER AND BUYER.  THIS AGREEMENT REFLECTS THE MUTUAL AGREEMENT OF SELLER AND BUYER AND BUYER IS RESPONSIBLE FOR CONDUCTING ITS OWN INDEPENDENT EXAMINATION OF THE PROPERTY.  OTHER THAN SELLER’S REPRESENTATIONS AND WARRANTIES EXPRESSLY SET FORTH IN THIS AGREEMENT OR IN THE DOCUMENTS TO BE DELIVERED BY SELLER AT CLOSING (“CLOSING DOCUMENTS”), BUYER HAS NOT RELIED UPON AND WILL NOT RELY UPON, EITHER DIRECTLY OR INDIRECTLY, ANY REPRESENTATION OR WARRANTY OF SELLER OR ANY OF SELLER’S AGENTS OR REPRESENTATIVES.  OTHER THAN SELLER’S REPRESENTATIONS OR WARRANTIES EXPRESSLY SET FORTH IN THIS AGREEMENT OR IN THE CLOSING DOCUMENTS, SELLER SPECIFICALLY DISCLAIMS, AND NEITHER IT NOR ANY OTHER PERSON IS MAKING ANY REPRESENTATION, WARRANTY OR ASSURANCE WHATSOEVER TO BUYER AND NO WARRANTIES OR REPRESENTATIONS OF ANY KIND OR CHARACTER, EITHER EXPRESS OR IMPLIED, ARE MADE BY SELLER OR RELIED UPON BY BUYER WITH RESPECT TO THE PROPERTY INCLUDING STATUS OF TITLE TO OR THE MAINTENANCE, REPAIR, CONDITION, DESIGN OR MARKETABILITY OF THE PROPERTY, OR ANY PORTION THEREOF, IT BEING THE EXPRESS INTENTION OF SELLER AND BUYER THAT, EXCEPT AS EXPRESSLY SET FORTH IN THIS AGREEMENT, UPON BUYER’S ELECTION TO PROCEED WITH THE TRANSACTION AS PROVIDED FOR IN THIS AGREEMENT, THE PROPERTY WILL BE CONVEYED AND TRANSFERRED TO BUYER IN ITS PRESENT CONDITION AND STATE OF REPAIR, “AS IS” AND “WHERE IS”, WITH ALL FAULTS.
p_23.revised: 2.2	AS-IS, WHERE-IS.  THE TRANSACTION CONTEMPLATED BY THIS AGREEMENT HAS BEEN NEGOTIATED BETWEEN SELLER AND BUYER.  THIS AGREEMENT REFLECTS THE MUTUAL AGREEMENT OF SELLER AND BUYER AND BUYER IS RESPONSIBLE FOR CONDUCTING ITS OWN INDEPENDENT EXAMINATION OF THE PROPERTY.  OTHER THAN SELLER’S REPRESENTATIONS AND WARRANTIES EXPRESSLY SET FORTH IN THIS AGREEMENT OR IN THE DOCUMENTS TO BE DELIVERED BY SELLER AT CLOSING (“CLOSING DOCUMENTS”), BUYER HAS NOT RELIED UPON AND WILL NOT RELY UPON, EITHER DIRECTLY OR INDIRECTLY, ANY REPRESENTATION OR WARRANTY OF SELLER OR ANY OF SELLER’S AGENTS OR REPRESENTATIVES.  OTHER THAN SELLER’S REPRESENTATIONS OR WARRANTIES EXPRESSLY SET FORTH IN THIS AGREEMENT OR IN THE CLOSING DOCUMENTS, SELLER SPECIFICALLY DISCLAIMS, AND NEITHER IT NOR ANY OTHER PERSON IS MAKING ANY REPRESENTATION, WARRANTY OR ASSURANCE WHATSOEVER TO BUYER AND NO WARRANTIES OR REPRESENTATIONS OF ANY KIND OR CHARACTER, EITHER EXPRESS OR IMPLIED, ARE MADE BY SELLER OR RELIED UPON BY BUYER WITH RESPECT TO THE PROPERTY INCLUDING STATUS OF TITLE TO OR THE MAINTENANCE, REPAIR, CONDITION, DESIGN OR MARKETABILITY OF THE PROPERTY, OR ANY PORTION THEREOF, IT BEING THE EXPRESS INTENTION OF SELLER AND BUYER THAT, EXCEPT AS EXPRESSLY SET FORTH IN THIS AGREEMENT, UPON BUYER’S ELECTION TO PROCEED WITH THE TRANSACTION AS PROVIDED FOR IN THIS AGREEMENT, THE PROPERTY WILL BE CONVEYED AND TRANSFERRED TO BUYER IN ITS PRESENT CONDITION AND STATE OF REPAIR, “AS IS” AND “WHERE IS”, WITH ALL FAULTS.

p_25.original: 2.4	Independent Consideration.  Seller and Buyer agree that $100 of the Earnest Money Deposit (“Independent Contract Consideration”) shall be non-refundable and shall be paid to Seller immediately upon request by Seller.  The Independent Contract Consideration has been bargained for and agreed to as additional consideration for Seller’s execution and delivery of this Agreement.  At Closing, the Independent Contract Consideration shall be applied to the Purchase Price.  If this Agreement is terminated for any reason, notwithstanding anything to the contrary in this Agreement, Seller shall be entitled to retain the Independent Contract Consideration.
